150468933.review:
I really like this one! But, it comes with some caveats. It's a well written game with great dialogue, fun gameplay (if you enjoy the puzzle half of survival horror more than the action half) and some downright inspired atmosphere sometimes. But at the end of the day it drops its more biting commentary for a kind of milquetoast horror supernatural concept. Instead of using the intrinsic horrors of the setting to amplify the survival horror overarching plot, we instead get anime and ghosts. Not that that's inherently wrong, but doesnt fit what the game was building up for. I find myself disappointed and left with a sour taste in my mouth because the first 2/3s of the game are genuinely fantastic for stealth/horror. Basically, if you go in expecting a horror romp with some decent commentary as a side theme, you'll have a blast. But if you buy what it sells naturally as it goes on like I did, I think you'll find yourself pretty disappointed in the story. 

Still, I think overall its a great game with some fantastic ideas and I hope these devs continue to improve and make some more awesome and fucked up horror thats just a little more focused in the future! 

TLDR: I'd say overall its like a 7.5/10 Great gameplay and fantastic ideas held back only by an unfocused plot and tedious last third that dont soil the overall positivity i feel, just dampen it

That's the weirdest part for me, honestly.[/spoiler]

149971514.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a game I really like in terms of its concept and vibe. It's not unusual for office culture to be lampooned, criticised, or taken to bizarre directions but this is the only example I can think of where that environment is turned into a survival horror game. The way this manifests is pretty neat in terms of how it influences the game's structure wherein it's based around various levels of social hierarchy within the company system that the game allows you freely travel between. It also has cute novelties like having your inventory being justified by typical stuff you'd see office workers eat or use for work. 

The gameplay for Yuppie Psycho is very lacking, however. Waiting around in observation of enemy movements is not unusual for stealth games and it has a presence in the horror genre too. But the difference is that, in those games, you generally have an active role in how enemy ai works and you're given a lot more gameplay options than waiting under a desk until the threat moves away. Since the game provides virtually no options of interaction beyond that, it's entirely reliant in how these threats manifest itself. To the game's credit, this comes in a variety of forms. This can be a full screen beam of lights to actual monsters roaming about. But the thing is that none of these threats save for one boss do anything about you hiding which just makes these encounters a dull game of patience until the threat in any room leaves an opening for you to move and none of them are capable of catching up to you anyway (aside from the aforementioned boss) so it's usually easy to avoid them regardless.

The other element to the gameplay is the resource management. Reading the reviews on here is funny because of how many people got filtered by the concept of resource management which is very common in this genre; yet, I seem to be the odd one out in thinking the game is very generous in how many resources it gives you. In contrast to something like Resident Evil or Signallis, your resources are never for direct combat and you never have to think about using such resources to eliminate threats within a given area. There's no "fight or flight" dilemma in this game. There are limited saves  but the game is so generous in its handouts on witch papers that saving is trivial and they always slap down a save spot with a piece of witch paper before any major boss/setpiece so it's rarely tedious if you end up dying. The game's structure is also fairly linear despite how it's laid out so it's also not really a case of considering pathing when utilising your saving resources. There's also pencils, and while a bit more scarce if you're being liberal in using them, once you realise there's only a few instances where you actually need to use them and that avoiding mines is easy it also becomes trivial as a resource. Health only becomes an issue depending on how good you are at avoiding damage and admittedly there are certain setpieces and bosses which can drain you pretty hard, especially if you played carelessly the way I did. But again, the resources are so generous here that I could actually get away with playing carelessly and justify it by abusing the health items. Since the entire resource game comes down to these 3 resources and you have unlimited space in your inventory, maintaining them feels like an afterthought due to how generous the game is about giving them to you. I'm genuinely baffled by the people who find this aspect frustrating. I'd love to see them play something like Pathologic or Fear & Hunger if they think this game is rough about it.

The third core aspect of the gameplay is psuedo-adventure game puzzle solving. This is amusingly the game's strongest point and frankly what's going to be taking up most players time. While the actual solutions are usually pretty straightforward and obvious, on occasion it does provoke you to investigate areas more to get clues about how solve certain puzzles. This is bare minimum when it comes to the design of these games but I do think a bit more thought was put into this aspect of the game because it does encourage you to jump between floors and snooping around to grasp any sort of solution. They could have pushed this a lot harder to the point you're making interactions with NPCs that change the layout of levels or playing around with item interactions more, but I'll still take this over waiting any day.

The narrative provides solid hooks due to how bizarre the general atmosphere is and how NPCs seem to have no real reaction to it but I don't think this is dealt with in a satisfactory way. Named characters all fit into office comedy stereotypes but nothing is done with them in the narrative beyond their one note joke. Despite the setting, it doesn't seem to have anything it wants to explore regarding office culture or any specific drama that comes with that. There is light commentary about the cutthroat mentality of classism but aside from two characters this is largely ignored. In both of these cases the whole concept is treated as a joke despite the legitimately horrifying ramifications of it that the story implies. Nobody seems horribly concerned about what their place in the hierarchy means for their social status nor is there any questions asked about the actual ethics of Sintracorp even having this hierarchy to begin with. The side characters just tacitly accept everything and even in the ending when you end the curse none of these characters seem particularly phased or particularly care about it, which gives off the impression they never had much stakes in anything that happens in the plot. There are some potentially interesting plot beats such as [spoiler]Inay's relationship to the robot[/spoiler] or [spoiler]Chapman's relationship with his father[/spoiler] that could have played into larger aspects of the narrative's theming but they end up getting tossed aside and made mostly irrelevant.

Another issue I have with the plot is just how generally detached Brian is from it. He's portrayed as the straight man who's the only one aware of how crazy the setting actually is, but beyond the obvious love interest in Kate; which is obscenely trite and boring, he has no stakes in anything. The core of the story is moreso about the family dynamics of the companies founders and while I do think there's some spice in that it comes off as limp because Brian has nothing to do with any of it. We see this dynamic play out from Brian's perspective but he never feels obliged to invest himself in that drama or has anything to say about it. He's a white bread protagonist who acts on heroic impulses and that's about it. The most his investment matters is simply as a goal to end the curse and his relationship to the Sintra ai to a lesser degree, but the latter doesn't play off of the family dynamic in any way whatsoever despite later plot twists. There is solid hooks about the curse's origin, but the story is way too vague about the family's general goals or ethics to make any of that interesting within the grander scheme of the setting. We have no idea what sort of business Sintracorp even is or how its founder operated or what motivated the owner to [spoiler]adopt Domori specifically[/spoiler]. The most we get are vague clues about their household dynamic which only gets explored in the alternate route, but even in that case it's too underbaked to be satisfactory.

This review has been mostly negative but despite it being deeply flawed I do find it interesting enough conceptually that I don't flat out hate it. I love the monster designs and the general quirkiness is extremely charming to me. I've grown to find more value in novelty than polish/depth when it comes to games these days and Yuppie Psycho fits that bill. But I just can't help but feel so much of it is missed potential so I can't recommend it.

149006956.review:
An amazing pixel horror game that has:

• Multiple endings (based on what you decide to do rather than dialogue choices)
• No jump scares
• Great atmosphere and soundtrack
• Humor
• Not too difficult bosses and puzzles
• Pixel art and cutscenes 
• Saving (the way it saves you don't overlap save files so you can click a save file that's from the past and start from there, great for different endings and it shows the date and time you saved)

Possible cons

• No auto save/save only using items in game (I didn't have any issue with this as I didn't die often and the way it's set up you get an idea when you should save before going further/there is one exception of auto save if you're going towards those endings)

• Not too difficult bosses and puzzles (If you're looking for a game that'll really push you to think and survive this might not be the game for you, but this is how I saw it, you might see the game differently)

Overall I highly recommend this game if you're interested in the premise, the only thing is I wish there was more to do/earn lol I got 100% in 24 hours, but despite this I'll honestly still keep replaying the game since I genuinely really love it, if you happen to know of other games like this please feel free to let me know!

148415127.review:
This game is more in the genre of Weird Fiction imo than strictly Survival Horror, but I 100% mean that as a compliment. Yuppie Psycho delivers on eerie and unsettling set pieces, story, and critter design without falling into common survival horror pitfalls of jump scares or horribly convoluted puzzles. Fascinating world building (my favorite part), good controls, great art direction & art, endearing characters, good music, and fun side bits to discover. The story is satisfyingly Weird and Creepy throughout, and the protagonist is endearing in an anime kinda way.

My only two big complaints are:

(1) The (semi-optional) Promotion Test bits are more RNG than skill or problem-solving based and wind up being more frustrating than fun.

(2) Late my my first play through, I felt like the story started to come apart at the seams. Toward the end, things felt under-explained in a way that took me out of the experience, but considering there are multiple endings, I'm hopeful that future play throughs will fix this and create a complete story.

Other than that? One of my favorite survival horror puzzle/p&c adventures in a long, long time. Would love to see more content set in the world established by this game.

148285925.review:
I absolutely loved this game and first of all I want to thank the developers that they included an option to disable the flashing lights, because otherwise I probably wouldn't have been able to play the game. Thank you so much!

Overall, I think the game is pretty balanced in a lot of different aspects.
The story has the right mix between horror and comedy, the puzzles are not super easy but very intuitive, and the gameplay itself is also easy to understand but in combination with the puzzles and the survival still gets challenging several times.
I love that there are two possibilities to finish the game storywise, although at first I was mad because I thought I just missed stuff in a linear story and couldn't get back to finish it.
When I replayed the game though to play the missing part, I realized that you enter a whole different story and ending and I enjoyed it a lot.
If you are the type of person who wants to 100% a game or at least play a lot of different endings or additions to the ending, you'll have a lot to do, because there are so many small possibilities to add extra scenes at the end or get achievements. 
If you are okay with just doing both story arcs, I recommend that you read a walkthrough after to at least read about all the small or bigger things you missed.
All in all the story is just great and suspenseful and has a lot of horror and comedy WTFs and nice touches and ideas everywhere.

As someone who really likes a good 2D pixel graphic I really loved the graphics in this game and I also laughed a lot about the VHS tapes.

So yeah, I fully recommend this game and even if it doesn't sound like the type of game you like to play, you should check out some let's play videos or streams of it.

147880077.review:
[h1] Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition: A Wacky Corporate Adventure! [/h1]

In the quirky realm of corporate workplaces, Sintracorp stands as a beacon of eccentricity. Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition, developed by Baroque Decay, invites you to step into this unusual world. As Brian Pasternack, a seemingly ordinary newcomer to Sintracorp, you'll quickly realize that normalcy is in short supply within these walls.

From the moment you enter the high-rise headquarters, you'll encounter a cast of peculiar characters. There's Mr. Chapman, seemingly repulsed by your humble background, setting off waves of imposter syndrome. Then there's Mr. Hugo, whose passive-aggressive tendencies emerge during your onboarding. And let's not forget Ms. Sosa, an avid fan of video games and horror films, who's practically invisible to her coworkers. Strangest of all is the witch, wreaking havoc within Sintracorp, and your first task is to stop her, as though you were plugging a financial leak.

Yuppie Psycho is an adventure game that delves into this crisis through exploration. You'll navigate eleven floors of Sintracorp, occasionally dealing with some backtracking. However, the headquarters offers visual diversity, with areas like a garden, library, and cafeteria, occasionally enhanced by animated cinematics.

Equipped with corporate camouflage, Brian wields his most valuable tool: a briefcase. It's essential for carrying the myriad of items you'll collect as you explore.

Unraveling this corporate witch hunt isn't always straightforward. You'll rely on item usage, conversations, and Sintranet assistance from the company's AI. Thoroughness is key, as you explore every nook, interact with everyone, and scrutinize your surroundings.

Yuppie Psycho doesn't focus on direct combat; instead, it has Brian use pencils strategically to fend off fixed foes. With limited health and various hazardous objects, Brian becomes a resourceful chef, concocting restorative recipes. Occasional stealth elements also come into play, offering simplistic hide-and-seek encounters with threats.

The game excels when coworkers' behavior becomes increasingly bizarre, blurring the lines between witchcraft and corporate efficiency. It's a poignant reminder that corporate culture can be as perilous as sorcery, corrupting innocent individuals into power-hungry monsters. However, the unforgiving save system and occasional lack of direction can be as demotivating as a condescending reprimand from a snooty boss.

In "Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition," the blend of wackiness, mystery, and corporate satire creates a unique and captivating adventure. While it may have its frustrating moments, the overall experience is a testament to the game's charm and creativity.

146321318.review:
[h1] An absolute must try 2D psych horror [/h1]

[b] TLDR: [/b]
A beautiful  2D pixel psychological horror with an in depth and well done story.
No combat, the hard part will be the somewhat obtuse puzzles; yet makes it incredibly fun and satisfying when you figure it out!

[i] Gameplay [/i]
Approximately [b] 13 hours [/b] of gameplay without completing all achievements however, I'm definitely going to play again to see it through and get the alternative ending.
Puzzles can be somewhat frustrating and obtuse, especially if you play it in increments like I did, so having forgotten and no real journal to go off I'd have to run around and try to remember what I was doing beforehand. Otherwise, I do believe it to correlate really well with that "OH" moment.
The horror element of "boss" fights(puzzles) I found were well done and enjoyed them thoroughly.

[i] Graphics [/i]
An absolutely stunning 2D pixel game with some not so much pixel cutscenes (and some VHS footage) add a very nice cherry on top. The character design for your coworkers and for abnormalities are fun and interesting. Definitely not your normal everyday office building. Each part of the building has something else to offer and has it's own interesting theme.

[i] Music [/i]
Thoroughly enjoyed every part of the sound design, never found myself bored. I found it really added to the horror element, giving me a few jump scares here and there (although i am someone who scares quite easily).

[i] Story + [/i]
I really love the story. I found it interesting and fresh. It keeps you engaged as it slowly develops and quickly unravels into a wonderful chaos.
The dialogue with every character felt personable, well developed and gave me a few chuckles here and there.

144512882.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a charming little adventure game, featuring a likeable protagonist in a scenario that starts out relatable and quickly veers into the surreal. Anyone who recalls the delight of the classic Resident Evil games would feel right at home with its mix of exploration, simple puzzles and resource management.

The game isn't bug-free, some design choices could have been done better, and the in-game visuals are nothing to write home about. But gorgeous pixel-anime cutscenes and absurdist corporate humour help the game stand out in a sea of indie slop. As part of a sale or bundle, I'd easily recommend this game. Thanks, Tomar.

144376513.review:
An incredibly funny (and sometimes terrifying) satire on Corporate America, specifically the Yuppie culture from the 80s, not unlike American Psycho.

I find almost every part of this game really compelling. The story is interesting and gets you hooked from the very start, the characters are incredibly charming and well written, the art may not be too impressive at first but the portraits and especially cutscenes and cgs are beautiful, and the music and sound design are amazing as well and can add to the humor and/or horror and switch back and forth at a moments notice which keeps you on edge as well.

In my personal opinion, the story in the last quarter becomes a little lackluster, but lackluster in comparison to the rest of the game still means great.

Not to mention for the price its a great experience, has tons of secrets and side content, lots of replayability and it goes on sale quite often as well.

Its worth picking up and giving a try, even if you don't get too into it i'd say its still worth it as its a really unique experience and yet another masterclass in indie horror and gaming in general.

142482320.review:
This game is absolutely amazing. Go in as blind as you possibly can, get the ending you get naturally, then go through again and 100% it. This game is so worth it. 

There's no easy way to explain this game, its a survival horror game in the sense that you hide from enemies and take damage if you do it wrong, and have very little in the way of defense. It is also filled to the brim with engaging puzzles with multiple ways to solve them, that you really have to unhinge your brain and immerse it in the world to solve.

The setting and story is what really sells this absolute masterpiece. You are a bumpkin nobody, given the opportunity of a lifetime. If you have ever, or will ever, step foot in to an office this game will stick in your brain the rest of your life. The corporate hellscape blend of occult beings, American Psycho, and a splash of anime (androids and cyberspace and the overall art style of cutscenes).

It's truly such an interesting artistic criticism of the absolute chaos and disorganization inherent in corporations that grows things so strange you wonder how they can physically be in front of you, but there they are!

The witch is also a great analogy how in companies you are always under someone's thumb, always being watched and controlled every single moment. Hugo is the perfect example of a coworker ready to....... well spoilers. Play the game its awesome.

 You'll see Hugos and Martas throughout the entirety of your life. Whenever something goes really weird at work my partner and I just look at eachother and get glassy eyed and say "KILL THE WITCH".

DID I MENTION THE DEV PUT IN HOURS OF FREE ENDGAME CONTENT??? FOR FREE??? BUY THE FREAKING GAME.

142065303.review:
Yuppie psycho
Eres Braian Pasternack un chico que recibe una carta contrato de una de las empresas más grandes del mundo, sintracorp. Desde el momento que firmas sabes que algo anda mal con ese lugar, sin saberlo te asignan a un trabajo “especial”, cazar a la bruja que está aterrorizando al lugar. 
El juego me pareció excelente, no era lo que esperaba, después de un rato te das cuenta que no es una simple aventura por el parque, si no, que debes saber organizar bien tus guardados y explorar cada zona minuciosamente en busca de provisiones porque más temprano que tarde te das cuenta que el juego es un survival horror de manual, tendrás a tu disposición distintos entornos, mas precisamente pisos, con los cuales accederás a través del ascensor. Los guardados funcionan en el momento que uses una fotocopiadora y un ítem llamado “papel de la bruja”, que se consumirá al guardar al más puro estilo residente vil (los primeros). La salud del jugador se perderá al recibir daño por ya sea trampas o enemigos, el juego cuenta con un sistema de cocina básico en el cual al tener ciertos ítems podrás preparar consumibles para aumentar la salud, es necesario buscar suministros si no quieres morir en la búsqueda de la bruja. Hablando de la salud en el transcurso del juego nos encontraremos con trampas, enemigos y jefes, como también una buena cantidad de puzles bastante entretenidos. Para cerrar, la historia me pareció bastante interesante, posee varios finales, con distintos cierres de trama. Un buen juego si buscas algo diferente.
 10 / 10

141593706.review:
You should read this carefully because while I agree with everyone that the main gameplay is enjoyable, there is one glaring omission in these reviews: the complete absence of quality-of-life features.

First the “save” system. I understand if you can only save at certain locations – that’s just like Resident Evil or Dark Souls’ bonfires. But then to push it further by limiting the number of saves AND not have an auto-save system? OK, well now I guess I have to plan my life around playing this game. God forbid something comes up at work/school/family or my pet gets sick. Say goodbye to your progress for the past hour.

Oh, and I can’t skip those long, dialogue heavy cut scenes? THANK YOU. I love having to go through the same cut scene over and over again because I have no idea what to do, let alone when to save. Finally, I usually wouldn’t complain about not knowing what items you can interact with, but the in-game graphics are worse than NES. No exaggeration. The dialogue and cut scenes have good pixel graphics, but the in-game environments are basically made up of stick figures and squares. 

The positives are legit: fun characters, quirky story, and nice world building. Sadly, there were so many times I muttered to myself “this isn’t fun” because of the above reasons. And once a game stops being fun, I just can’t recommend it.

140044338.review:
[h1]YUPPIE PSYCHO[/h1]
ENG/ESP
[ENG]
[b] I love my job[/b]

Welcome to Sintracorp, the most well-known company in the world! You have the honor and the possibility to become a valuable employee of our company, having access to an unenviable salary and to a permanent social status improvement at the moment of signing your contract. The details of your work and a brief description of our facilities will be explained below, with a final personal opinion at the end of the review:

[u]-Employee Brian Pasternak, your job in this company[/u] is rather simple: as a hunter, your objective is to kill the entity known as "The Witch", who has been living among these walls for years. Due to the confidenciality and the importance of this job, it is required that you keep it a secret. All the company will be at your disposal to investigate and to perform daily chores. Check the drawers, shelves, desks and any object or item that may be strange to you, as you never know where you will find batteries, pencils, or the valuable witch papers used for printing.

[u]-Second, and continuing with the previous point,[/u] you will be able to move between the floors of the facilities to reach (almost) all the places: from taking a break eating in the cafeteria to replenish your health (which we hope it won't suffer too much throughout your day), visiting our offices zone known as The Hive (please be careful with movable desks), to taking a good break in our garden.

[u]-At the moment, our facilities are suffering from a bad condition[/u], so you will need to use external tools, such as flashlights, glow sticks, etc, to explore the building. We recommend that you take special care with dangerous areas, such as the security room, the poisonous zones or the human resources office.

Personally, this game is wonderful: it has terror, a lot of comedy and very fun moments. Moreover, I love exploring all Sintracorp, you'll never know what you are going to find (or what kind of danger you'll face). The story of the game is very good, it keeps you in suspense for you to want to know mora and more. Overall, and therefore, [b] I recommend this very good game[/b] to those who like terror, humor and to explore creepy places, besides to discover a story as gloomy as it is cool.

[ESP]

[b]Me encanta mi trabajo[/b]

¡Bienvenido a Sintracorp, la empresa más conocida de todo el mundo! Tiene usted el honor y la posibilidad de convertirse en un valioso empleado de nuestra compañía, teniendo acceso a un sueldo nada envidiable y a una mejora de estatus social en el momento que firme su contrato. A continuación se le explicarán los detalles de su trabajo, además de realizar una breve descripción de nuestras 
instalaciones:

[u]-Empleado Brian Pasternak, su labor para con la empresa[/u] es muy sencilla: como cazador, su objetivo es matar a la entidad conocida como La Bruja, quien vive entre estas paredes desde hace años. Debido a la confidencialidad y la importancia de este trabajo, deberá mantenerlo en absoluto secreto. Dispondrá de toda la empresa para
investigar y realizar sus labores diarias. Investigue los cajones, las estanterías, algunos escritorios y cualquier objeto que le resulte extraño, nunca se sabe dónde encontrará baterías, lápices, o los valiosos papeles de bruja usados en las fotocopiadoras.

[u]-Segundo, y continuando el anterior punto,[/u] podrá desplazarse por los pisos de la empresa para realizar sus propósitos: desde tomarse un descanso con varios alimentos en la cafetería para rellenar su salud (la cual esperemos que no sufra  muchas decaídas a lo largo de su jornada), visitar nuestra zona de oficinas conocida como La Colmena (tenga cuidado con los escritorios móviles), hasta tomarse un merecido descanso en el octavo piso, el jardín.

[u]-Actualmente, la empresa sufre de su estado actual[/u], por lo que deberá emplear herramientas externas, tales como linternas o barritas luminosas, para explorar a conciencia las instalaciones. Le recomendamos que tenga especial cuidado con áreas peligrosas, tales como la sala de seguridad, las zonas emponzoñadas o el despacho de recursos humanos.

Personalmente, el juego me parece una maravilla: tiene toques de terror, mucha comedia y momentos muy divertidos. Además, el ir explorando toda Sintracorp es espectacular, nunca sabes qué te vas a encontrar (o con qué tipo de peligro te vas a topar). La historia está bastante bien, te dan ganas de saber más sobre la empresa, esa misteriosa bruja o básicamente qué ha pasado para que Sintracorp acabe como está (además de querer ir a un sitio específico al que aún no he podido acceder). Por tanto, [b]recomiendo este juego tan bueno[/b] a aquellos que les guste el terror, un poco de humor y explorar ambientes tétricos, además de aquellos a los que les guste ir desentrañando una historia extraña a la vez que chula.

139973068.review:
So, this game was pretty crazy, but it was fun.  It's got its horror elements, but I wouldn't say that it's necessarily scary.  Creepy, for sure.  Some parts were pretty dang funny.

This is one of those games where if you put it down for a while and come back to it, there's a good chance you'll be lost, because the game only really gives you direction within the first half of it.  If you haven't been paying attention to what people are saying, it's difficult to figure out what to do next.

There is lots of stuff to find.  Your character has health and inventory.  There's not really any combat.  Mostly avoidance and hiding.  A great deal of gameplay focuses on finding paths and figuring stuff out.  So, I guess I'd call it a retro-horror-fantasy mystery game.

The story is pretty complex and there appears to be much symbolism, especially when it comes to making fun of corporate uselessness or stupidity, but also the paranormal parts of it are intricate.  It's easy to miss a lot of what's going on, especially if you try to rush through it.  That said, you'll likely find a lot of answers to your questions by reading fan speculation discussions online.

There are multiple outcomes within multiple outcomes.  So, the majority of the game's value is replay-based.

A couple things I didn't like, or just didn't work for me:  There's no map.  I get lost and make wrong turns all the time, in games and in real-life.  I don't think a visual map would have been unreasonable to include, especially when it came to inaccessible areas.  Saving is limited by certain items in your inventory, which became frustrating because I would try to conserve saves and end up being killed by something stupid and lose a good half-hour of progress.  Also, while the majority of players are probably not misophonic like I am, the soft, wet mouth whispering that could be heard on certain occasions really pissed me off.  It's right in your freaking ear and I wanted to punch something.  I'm probably just crazy, so I dealt with it.

Ultimately, this game was a lot of fun.  Give it a try.

139755587.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a hell of a ghost story, sometimes funny and sometimes serious. The art, sounds, and soundtrack are great. I liked the characters. I ran into some trouble with one early puzzle. Overall I enjoyed it and would recommend it.

It's charmingly silly. You have a coworker who dresses up in a cutesy cartoon frog mask when he goes out to help the local monsters kill people. Your company hires a motivational speaker dressed like a 19th century French cavalryman, complete with horse. You work in an office full of corpses and pools of blood which everyone just works around. It's ridiculous and fun throughout.

And it's a ghost story. Over the course of the story you encounter horrible creatures and uncover loose clues, bits and pieces from different characters in the office. The key ghost, the Witch, has some known ("known"?) properties which you learn in due time. There's a history to this place behind the Witch and her connection to it. The reveals come slow and don't stop. Those ghost story reveals build up the tension in a way the art and music reinforce wonderfully. The game feels appropriately creepy, and also appropriately inappropriately silly, in the most wonderful way.

I like the art. The pixel art suits the game well, and the animated pixel art cutscenes are beautiful. It's sometimes cheery and sometimes unsettling, gruesome, or both. The cutscenes, sprites, and character portraits show each character's personality in a wonderful way.

I love how the sounds reinforce those feelings. The office sounds bring a mundane quality that is sometimes scary and sometimes funny, and the horror aspects sound appropriately squishy and gross.

The soundtrack is amazing, too, all over the place in the best way. It includes upbeat piano sounds like "Meet and Greet" as well as creepy piano ("Something's Not Right") and creepy I'm-not-sure-what-instrument ones like "I Can See You." Many tracks fit right in with the setting ("Meet and Greet" with less energy could sound like hold or elevator music), match some sounds but not the tone ("Not What they Seem" and its creepy droning and beeping; "It Hurts (Do You Look Like the Devil)" sounds like a spooky arrangement of printer malfunctions), or clearly stick out as weird and unusual ("Her Children" sounds pounding and frantic). The music brings an appropriate feeling to every scene.

I like the characters. Each coworker has their archetype, but their own personality within that expressed in the art and writing. They work well together by working poorly together. And there are so many nameless minor characters commenting on offices, work, careers, etc. in fun ways. Every character is slightly unsettling in some way that adds to the story's tension. I like them and I don't know who I can trust.

If I had to complain about anything, it's probably the puzzle of the second (?) big monster encounter. I had an idea how to solve [spoiler]the spider in the library[/spoiler] and I had the right general idea ([spoiler]to do something with the mines[/spoiler]) but couldn't figure out the specifics. ([spoiler]Since the mines reacted to the spider but as non-hostile, I thought I ruled that out, and didn't think to use the push-carts to trigger the mines since the pushcarts are apparently inanimate -- I assumed the mines only react to living things[/spoiler].) I got around this by looking at a walkthrough (which I did for most of the rest of the playthrough) and I don't regret it.

It's a fun game. Would recommend.

138950344.review:
I can't properly express how much better Yuppie Psycho was than I thought it was going to be. My perception of it going in was something pretty janky but fun and lighthearted, oh boy was I wrong. This is a masterclass in storytelling that had me completely immersed from the start. I'm an avid adventure game/pnc player, and the puzzles were at a great difficulty level, not too obtuse for you to connect the dots properly, but were also thought out enough to make you stop and think about what you are actually doing. More importantly everything makes sense within the world they made, and if you think you can do something, you can probably do it, which was very refreshing to see in an adventure game. More importantly, there's so much "hidden" fantastic content that was added to this game in a free DLC patch (I only played after it was added, but I know what was added) and it's honestly fantastic content, which is such a plus to the developer for giving us this for free. The content added with the DLC is some of the strongest parts of the game, just really out of the box puzzles and great alternative path stories and mystery. As a whole package Yuppie Psycho is excellent.

I should add, I'm not much of a horror person, and there are definitely parts of this game that scared the crap out of me (if you know, you know), but for the most part its all very tasteful and manageable for someone like me who's not super into horror. The horror here is more psychological in nature, and does so much to build the story and atmosphere which rope you into a fantastic mystery adventure game. 

There are some light "survival" elements in Yuppie Psycho I should mention. I never felt too strung out on resources, but at the same time the threat of dooming my play through from overusing resources was in the back of my mind the entire game, and added to the psychological horror and how attentive/stressed I was at times. I will say I don't think Yuppie Psycho having survival elements detracted in any way from the adventure/puzzle nature of the game, and actually added a good amount of weight and reward to exploration and unlocking new areas. I think the way limited resources were implemented worked about as well as I've see in an adventure game which leans more traditional and less action focused. If I had any gripes whatsoever, maybe they could give you 1 or 2 less health items over the course of the game, but that's really it.

All in all, Yuppie Psycho is one of the best adventure games I've played in a long time, if not ever. I really don't know what else to say. It's exceptional 10/10.

137147265.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a spine-chilling, pixel art horror game that will leave you on the edge of your seat. From the moment you step into the dark and twisted world of Sintracorp, you'll be captivated by its gripping story and unique gameplay.

The game's retro-style graphics are both nostalgic and haunting, creating a sense of unease as you explore the eerie corporate offices and encounter sinister creatures along the way. The atmospheric soundtrack adds another layer of immersion, heightening the tension and sending chills down your spine.

The gameplay is a perfect blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and survival horror. Each step you take requires careful planning and strategic thinking, as you navigate the perilous environment and encounter challenging puzzles that require your wits to solve. The tension rises as you encounter bosses and face life-or-death situations, keeping you on your toes at all times.

Yuppie Psycho also shines in its storytelling. The plot is filled with unexpected twists and turns, keeping you hooked and eager to uncover the dark secrets lurking in the shadows of Sintracorp. The characters you meet along the way are memorable and well-developed, adding depth to the narrative and making you emotionally invested in their fates.

One of the aspects that sets Yuppie Psycho apart is its attention to detail. From the hidden secrets to the clever Easter eggs, the game is filled with surprises that add replayability and make you want to explore every nook and cranny of Sintracorp.

In summary, Yuppie Psycho is a captivating, spine-chilling horror game that delivers a unique and immersive experience. With its retro-style graphics, gripping gameplay, and engaging storytelling, it's a must-play for horror game enthusiasts who are looking for a thrilling and memorable adventure. Don't miss out on this gem of a game!

136778645.review:
[h1]WELL HELLO, MISTER DEVIL![/h1]

[b]Yuppie Psycho = Resident Evil + The Davids Lynch and Cronenberg + Junji Ito[/b]


This is one of those games that has been lurking in my backlog, waiting to strike like... A coiled serpent, perhaps? I had forgotten I had it but since I've been on a horror-dive lately, I decided I needed to hit that install button.

I'm very glad I did.

Yuppie Psycho plays like a lofi Resident Evil minus the guns.  That isn't to say there aren't enemies, hazards, and boss fights.  You just deal with them by running, hiding, or other more unconventional means.  You primarily dash about the dark complex, solving puzzles, finding secrets (there are a lot), and gobbling up all the bizarre character moments you can get.  From the horror perspective, it's not really a jumpscare game.  It is an occult-infused mindworm that tries to get at you on a subconscious level, and that is far more appealing to me.

As much as it is a straightforward journey into horror, it is also equally part corporate satire, homages to horror/mystery greats, and short bursts of mostly lovably wackadoo characters. The presentation is a weird mess of chunky pixels, fluid anime cutscenes, 𝖠 𝖤 𝖲 𝖳 𝖧 𝖤 𝖳 𝖨 𝖢 𝖲, and FMV goodies that all seem to blend together into a delicious, gory, smoothie.

It's also the kind of game where you can mess up your progress very easily, miss hidden items/secrets, and also has a few annoyingly tedious moments.  You can restore any and every save you make (just don't make too many, like oldskool Resident Evil, saves are limited), but I did at once need to backtrack about 4 hours of gameplay because of one, easily missed item.  These problems are not nearly enough to hold the game back for virtually any indie horror fan, however.


[i]Sign the deal with the Devil if you...[/i]

✅ Have a sweet tooth for the forbidden candy of occult horror
✅ Love games that reward exploration
✅ Are more than a touch mad and crave the surreal

[i]Leave through the lobby if you...[/i]

❌ Prefer emotional writing/horror. It has its moments, but the characters mostly serve as zany archetypes.
❌ Need to solve your problems by 'sploding them away.
❌ Want difficult puzzles. Persistence is more important than ingenuity in Yuppie Psycho.

The game has received Overwhelmingly Positive reviews for good reason.  I think it stands on equal footing with the more well-known indie horror titles out there and I consider this a classic.  Though it isn't without problems, the love that was put into development is very apparent and it even carries on outside of the game..... [b]::mysterious and spooky gestures::[/b]

134999520.review:
I started playing the game and got a tad confused because, despite the horror tag, I didn't really notice anything out of the ordinary... soulless coworkers mindlessly walking down corridors that don't even look at you, water dispensers that never get refilled, an elevator with nonfunctional buttons, computing equipment from a past era, some manager going around the offices while riding a horse, esoteric forces that prevent you from leaving the building, whole corridors and offices with no light sources whatsoever, unhinged guys attempting suicide by hanging themselves with their neckties, human corpses hung from ropes attached to the ceiling... you know, just pretty standard stuff for an office environment...

However, it wouldn't take long for me to finally uncover something deeply disturbing... I was going around the offices on my floor just minding my own business until I noticed a neat, unattended cabinet. I obviously opened it to take a peek at its contents, as everyone would do in this situation. However, what I discovered instead shook me to my core... the cabinet was actually [b]empty[/b]. I kid you not, there was [b]nothing[/b] inside. No office supplies, no archived paperwork from the last decade, not even a single forgotten piece of clothing. Just a blank emptiness staring back at me. But wouldn't you believe it... every other cabinet I inspected afterwards [b]was empty too!![/b] And that's when I realized there was something really wrong going on with this company.

So yeah, I kept playing and apparently there was a witch or something? idk, I somehow managed to break the curse afflicting the company and beat the game. Unfortunately, I couldn't double-check the cabinets afterwards since I ended up leaving the company but I have no doubt that those won't be remaining empty any longer 👍

134907335.review:
[b] TLDR: [/b] this game is incredibly dear to me despite its flaws (which i will get into in the later portion of my review) and i would 100% suggest this game to people who enjoy RPG maker style games, mysteries, and supernatural elements especially if it's on sale. you may need to pull up a wiki from time to time, but for me doing this does not tend to hinder my enjoyment of the game. while yuppie psycho might not be perfect in certain aspects of its delivery, this game is a HUGE step up from baroque decay's previous game "the count of lucanor" and the plot is INCREDIBLY solid.

[b] light spoiler warning ahead! [/b] nothing too major, but if you dont like hearing about gameplay elements and like to go into things as blind as possible, avoid reading ahead.

[u] the good: [/u]
i absolutely adore the visual style! i won't go into this too much considering the promo art and previews give a pretty good idea of what the final game has to offer, but the ambience around the cutscenes (and in general to be honest) always hits the mark for me. i've also always found the plot of yuppie psycho to be compelling and interesting, no matter which route i take (the game has two main branches with a few sub branches). 

to me, the various tasks that you need to carry out all slot together quite nicely and caused me to never feel as if what i was doing started to drag out albeit for one section of the game; while i enjoy the gameplay itself and the various mechanics, i have some gripes with them that i will be discussing in the next segment. though i've run into a bug or two during my many hours of gameplay, the dev team is active in their discord and is quick to respond to feedback regarding bugs and errors that players have run into. 

[u] the bad: [/u]
before getting into some of the jankier aspects of the actual gameplay, one thing that's always bothered me personally about yuppie psycho is how some character dialogue ends up cutting off and oddly segmented over the course of two boxes. it's more of a quality of life issue than anything, but sometimes i felt my immersion in the narrative being ruined by a single word of a character's speech being cut off and continued in a seperate speech box when the game could've easily been put into a single box with a smaller font or seperated into one box per sentence (as an example).

now, onto the actual gameplay aspects. the way the save system works in yuppie psycho means that there are a limited number of saves. as much as i love this system, i have run into times where i wasn't able to get as much done in game as i would've liked to before saving. it also doesn't help that witch paper are also used as a currency in late game, which means if players haven't been saving sparingly then they may be unable to access certain items that aid with gameplay.

there are also a couple "stealth" portions of the game that rely on you waiting for something cyclical (such as enemy mob walking paths) that are fun and challenging when you first start doing them, but become frustrating and tedious when paired with the fact that aside from a key moment in the game, there are zero autosaves. this means that if the last time you saved was pretty recent but decently far away, you're going to have to walk all the way back to that portion of the game to initiate the sequence again.

[b] CONCLUSION: [/b] the flaws of the game are incredibly worth pushing past due to how far outshone it is by the good. i'm currently working on my third replay and aiming to get all achievements, so i may update this review with more specific gripes / things that i enjoy at some point in the future!

132968882.review:
Some of the surrounding plot points make literally no sense, and I don't mean in a realistic sense, I mean in a simple logic sense. For instance (no spoilers), why would you buy an unusual child with strange conditions to their care because you can't have your own children instead of just adopting a NORMAL one or paying for a surrogate? These cannot be excused as unlikely options considering some of the ridiculous technology and blatant realization of the supernatural evident in the setting.

But ignoring those few quibbles, what you end up with is a ridiculously high quality horror game that reeks of style and atmosphere in the best way possible. It's definitely a wild, crazy ride, and I think it deserves its glowing reviews.

My only true negatives involve just how bittersweet the game is even during the best endings. The implications for some of the characters (the two at the heart of this in particular) is just... utterly heartbreaking and depressing. While not quite OMORI levels of sadness, this is definitely a game that will make you think more than usual and make you shake your head often in a good way.

It's definitely worth the full price, and I'm deeply looking forward to this developer's next project, which will be an instant-buy for me.

132225484.review:
I'm not a frequent horror player and passed over this game upon release, even after seeing it on Garoad's bandcamp site. However, after watching about an hour of a Let's Play recently, I had to stop the video and pick up the game - the story was too fascinating and the content looked more creepy than scary.

Sure enough, the game leans towards the unsettling, and juggles humor, the macabre, and frequent points of tension. It also deserves a "Choices Matter" tag; though trying multiple routes is eased somewhat by the sequential save system.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Intriguing story
+Characters have depth, despite short screen time
+Animations are detailed for their low resolution
+Nice cutscenes
+Puzzles require some careful observation
+Lots of extras, including most of OST on main menu
+Decent replay value: multiple paths, six endings and optional content

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Limited but plentiful saves. Hard on short playtimes, though.
~Not very difficult, except for one frustrating late-game area
~Frequent cursing and pixellated blood, but no animated deaths
~Personally love Garoad's music
~Missable achievements
~Lots of unanswered questions in the story
~Little bit of Japanese culture that may not make sense to some

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Got stuck in one of first rooms in game once
-Enemies on 3rd floor bug out frequently
-Enemies can get stuck on you in text boxes and continue to damage you

131493382.review:
This is the strangest review for me to write, because I truly love this game,

Immediately the first thing to address is why I would not recommend a game with an overwhelmingly positive reception. This article is not for attention and is simply my feelings on to me is a spoiled experience of what could've been one of the best indie games of the decade.

The plot is immediately captivating. The art is fantastic, with varying styles of pixel art and includes some awesome animated cutscenes. The music is sublime, reminding me of visual novels such as Phoenix Wright or Danganronpa. It's all got a great cohesiveness to it and is oozing charm. I can recognise a lot of the inspirations and the creators clearly have a love for games. The horror elements are done well. When the game is at it's best, it shares commonality with resident evil 8.  

So. Why am I giving this review a not recommended? 

I can't recommend this game because of the plethora of bugs and bad game design choices. These repeatedly broke my immersion.

Let's elaborate on these experiences. Firstly, on three separate occasions, I received a gamebreaking softlock or unexpected quit, forcing me to play gameplay and watch cutscenes already pre-experienced. This combined with the fact the game encourages you NOT to save, by having a limited save system caused those backtracks to be significant time commitments. 

Next, some of the AI in the game is pretty shoddy. I've encountered an entire room of AI freeze up until i change areas. I've been detected unfairly and sometimes gotten away with behaviour that should have had me detected. This combined with a specific area of the game (the TV room) lead to an extremely unenjoyable experience that just made me wish I could press a button to get back to the plot. Furthermore, the boss fight at the end of this section punishes extremely hard for mistakes and again, the save is quite far away. 

The balancing of where items were placed and how many of them seems very random and not player tested. I finished the game with a large number of unneeded items, while on the otherhand had to restart sections of the game deliberately because I had taken too much free damage. This sort of game design is severely immersion breaking because I turn my experience from in the mind of the character to remembering that it's just a game so I have to treat it like one. 

As a developer myself, I recognise that these issues may not be the easiest to solve, but I think being released in 2019, it's fair to assume these issues could have been patched by now. 

There are also some spoiler issues I won't get into in this review, but I will leave at: multiple endings should not exist just to exist. They should serve a greater purpose, either for comedy, world building, meaningful decision making and other such examples. Several endings felt like purposeless, often revealing little to no conclusion of the effects of the chosen ending. 

People that play games come under a huge umbrella of categories. Many people will prefer losing oneself in a narrative experience while others may prefer enjoying the gameplay systems. Personally, I don't think I enjoyed much of the gameplay systems when I was not immersed, as they felt archaic and often withheld the progression of the plot. 

To conclude, it's a great game that's true potential is held back. The game simply suffers from it's success. It builds such wonderful character personality, captivating plot and charming music and art, that when immersion is broken from flawed game design and bugs, it hits far harder than the typical experience. This game so deserves to be a 10/10 masterpiece, but isn't, which is why I can't yet recommend it. You'll probably have a good time, but I believe every player deserves more. Horror as a genre for me only works with a maintained deep immersion. When it's going well, this game provides some of the deepest immersion I've had, yet means the breakouts hit so much harder. Regardless of this review, you should probably play it yourself if you like story heavy games, horror games, or the resident evil franchise. Perhaps just play it if you don't get lost in films, games or TV. But to those like me, I can't in good faith recommend Yuppie Psycho.

131392302.review:
Una joya que no se puede perder, una comedia terrorífica en la que la historia te mantendrá en vilo. Acompaña a Brian en su primer día de trabajo. Dentro reseña!

Primer juego pasado en steam deck y ha sido una gozada. Nos encontramos ante un indie que mezcla varios elementos. La historia nos presenta a Brian Pasternack, en su primer día de trabajo en Sintracorp, una de las mejores empresas de su mundo. Al parecer dicho mundo se diferencia en clases sociales según una letra del alfabeto. Al llegar, pondrán a Brian en una de las 10 plantas que tiene la empresa (donde se desarrolla el juego) y con un mensaje de "mata a la bruja", comenzará un primer "trabajo".

Contar más de la historia es hacer spoiler pero en base, a más descubre más quieres saber, de todos los personajes, con su personalidad propia les coges cariño (a algunos más que otros). Una historia bastante adulta, a mi parecer. Con elementos de terror, los gráficos pixel no dan para mucho. Pero la atmósfera y cada escenario está puesto a propósito y no te sientes seguro en ningún lado. Gameplay sencillo, guardados a lo "cintas de resident evil", inventario para usar objetos, metroidvania en ciertas partes, un botón de correr y objetos rápidos (linternas). Hace uso de la luz muy pero que muy bueno. Todo el gameplay, escenarios y terror es la propia parte de "miedo". Pero encontramos por otra parte una sátira, un puteo de personajes,  una sociedad dividida por cuánto asciendes, por quién es el jefe, todo enfocado a la realidad en la que vivimos (de manera exagerada) en la que en muchos diálogos puedes sentirte identificado incluso. Y esa es la parte de comedia (que no se desvía del terror).

Y nos queda una joya de juego que ya sea por la historia aunque no te llame el gameplay como es mi caso, deberíais jugar. El juego dura alrededor de 5-6 horas, con un montón de cinemáticas y finales (estoy contento con el mío).

Aunque he jugado en steam deck offline y por eso el tan poco recuento de horas. No puedo más que recomendarlo pues el guión es una maravilla, los personajes, los diálogos, la atmósfera, son tan buenos que da igual que el juego se vea "pixelado". Sobre todo las cintas donde se ven vídeos grabados realmente con personas (bastante turbios) le han dado un puntazo. Algún sustillo me he llevado sobre todo al principio. 

Acompaña a Brian hasta la cima de Sintracorp e intenta descubrir quién es la bruja. Gracias por leer! <3

130627453.review: This game is for those that enjoy uncovering deep, juicy lore. This game is not for everyone. There is no shame in looking up a walkthrough. 130617548.review:
This is one of the coolest games I have ever played. Period. I LOVED this game, the story is great, the pacing is good, the game actually encourages you to explore and investigate your surroundings, it has an amazing soundtrack, cool and funny characters, it's just a good game. I would give this game a 8/10, only because of 2 things. 

1. THE SAVING SYSTEM IS VERY FRUSTRATING. I get that it works with the story and makes the game more immersive, but it really does make the game very frustrating at times and even can make it not fun anymore when you have to watch cut scenes back after back just because you haven't been able to find any witch paper and you didn't realize you could be killed easily in the next area you go to. 

2. I won't say any spoilers, but I am just going to say the ending that I got wasn't what I was hoping for. The story had very good pacing and kept me hooked and interested pretty much the whole game. But the ending kinda seemed rushed and not as thought out as the story for the majority of the game. But I know there are multiple endings, maybe the one I got just isn't as exciting as the others. But hey that's just me. 

Besides those 2 things, this was an amazing experience and I look forward to seeing what this game studio makes in the future. Because this game is amazing.

128757810.review:
I got this on sale without any prior knowledge of it and enjoyed it much more than I expected to.

It does have a couple frustrating problems in my opinion but overall for me was really enjoyable. The puzzles (barring a few easy ones) are a mixture of clever and fun to solve and... totally inscrutable. You WILL be looking up a few solutions online along the way. Personally, I was pretty careful not to spoil any story elements when looking up solutions, as I found it pretty fun to piece together the random tidbits of lore you find exploring the building and uncovering the backstory behind your first assignment. The story and animation are definitely the selling points of the game for me; this is no walking sim though, I found the gameplay pretty fun and challenging, particularly managing money, items, saves (which are limited to an item) while not really knowing what might come next. On the negative side a few particular encounters will will require a couple of deaths and some memorization to get through, and there seems to be a few times where passing through an area just means you'll take unavoidable damage.
Item management is important but not difficult, barring one issue - in the endgame, there was one particular regular item needed for one part of the ending that I couldn't get after the endgame started. This doesn't effect any of the real endings, but something small during the ending sequence. 

tl;dr It's not perfect but if you like the idea of a game that's basically an absurd mystery anime with horror elements, this'll probably be up your alley.

128165366.review:
words can not describe how much this game means to me. as a wuss and a baby, i was not too excited to try out what's described as a first job psychological horror game, but what i found in the pixelated confines of the game was a unique story with interesting characters and well-played horror that even a baby like me could enjoy, and even come to seek out. 

the game begins rather inconspicuously. you take the mantle of Brian Pasternack, a down-on-his-luck G-class citizen in a 1990's dystopian society. receiving a job offer from the prestigious SintraCorp, Brian packs up and moves to accept the offer. however, within the building, he finds something unlike anything he could have ever imagined in his plain, boring life. the crux of the story hangs on something i would not like to spoil, since this game is best experienced blind. while most of the characters don't have much backstory outside of what's shown on the surface of the game, and while much of the lore is hidden behind increasingly obscure depictions, you still can't help but be intrigued. you want to dive deeper, to uncover each ending and each secret inside of this game. 

the characters are obscure and confusing, which adds to the unsettling atmosphere created. the building seems to warp and distort with each step taken, and what's behind each corner is a mystery to both yourself and the characters. uncovering what happens within the walls of the SintraCorp building is one of the many draws this game has. 

the gameplay is simple, but the horror that the game builds and implements adds incredibly high stakes. the one complaint myself and others have about the game is limited saves - however working smartly is the goal of the game, and i feel the system is not only lore-compliant, but also an intriguing mechanic added to keep the stakes high. dying will reset you back to your last save, which can be frustrating if you haven’t saved in a while… but the game gives you plenty of opportunity to save before major encounters. the game-saving material is also scattered throughout the game, like a reward for exploring the levels of the building. 

the main crux of gameplay is problem solving, puzzles, and self-guided exploration. sprinkled every now and then with a tense moment of fear, the gameplay has a good ebb and flow which i enjoyed immensely. while i'm the kind of guy to look up a walkthrough and follow that most of the way through to get enjoyment, there were moments where I slowly pieced things together myself, and those were unfathomably fulfilling. of course, there were even puzzles that walkthroughs couldn’t help me with – the difficulty of the game is present in its puzzles and exploration, and figuring things out for yourself is what really shines about this game. this goes for both puzzles and lore. 

there are many side-quests and bosses in the game as well, and without spoiling anything, i will say it’s highly encouraged to give them a look. if you get a second to rest between the high-stakes action and boss fights, definitely go get to know your coworkers, as quirky and off as they may be. 

the game does well to establish its horror setting, and the minimalist pixel graphics do well to add to the obscurity of the horror. everything in the game has room for your mind to interpret and make it more terrifying than the graphics could ever do - and that’s a firm strength for the game. that unknown nature, the minimalism, it’s all there to let your mind run rampant with the horror. it worms its way into you. it really hooks you, and makes you feel as if you’re really there. 

in terms of the lore, there’s plenty there if you choose to look. even if it’s obscure, it’s present - and like the horror, it’s up to you to figure it out on your own. plenty of collectables litter the game for you to collect. the atmosphere also tells a story, which give insight to how things were and how they continue to be. each ending of the game gives you more and more than you could have ever imagined, which is why i encourage you to find them all for yourself. the endings will get you emotional, as they are fulfilling extensions of the story you have experienced up until that point. 

Yuppie Psycho pulls you into a world of fear and intrigue as you fight your way through a twisted and distorted building built specifically to give you chills. even for a horror baby such as myself, the horror was built in a way that terrifies you, yet keeps you coming back for more. the characters are well-established, the lore is rich, and the gameplay establishes itself in a powerful yet understandable way. Yuppie Psycho is an experience well worth the price.

127795450.review:
Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition is an indie survival horror that follows protagonist Brian Pasternack. Brian gets an invite to work for an incredibly high profile company despite having no qualifications. Hesitant Brian accepts his contract and finds himself in a dangerous situation that has him checking over his shoulder all the time. His assignment, Kill the Witch. Brian can not disclose his role in the company as a hunter, and must keep a low profile while completing the tasks given to him through his work computer. Take control of Brian's fate through a series of branching options that could end with him leaving or becoming top dog of the company. 
 
The Narrative of the game was intriguing and held my attention even after multiple playthroughs. The branching choices are also fairly easy to identify and tell what would make for an ending split. There's a slight amount of backtracking but not enough to the point it became annoying. Instead I found myself fascinated with the large amount of ending possibilities and minimal repeated actions I had to take for some of them, it was for this reason that I ended up playing the game from start to finish 3 times total. Using items you pick up while exploring, Brian can make healing items, gain upgrades for more light, find tapes/VHS clips, and a plethora of other goodies to help him on his adventure. Everything being held in his suitcase and categorized to easily be found. 

The art of the game is absolutely gorgeous. As a lover of pixel art, the inclusion of some many animated sequences blew me away. Props to the artist for making the animated sequences flow naturally into the game environments. While it may not be something everyone would notice, as someone in the art field it was fantastic to see. Even though the in game art sprites may not appear to be anything special, the environments, splash screens, and animated sequences were an absolute treat. 

The game features it's own 40+ soundtrack that I never once found to be too repetitious or annoying. Each track fit the environment it played in and helped to increase the immersion of the environment. There were locations were I was on the edge of my seat due to the ambiance mixed with the environmental layout. The price for the game is also fair at full value and would buy it at such for the amount of content you are getting. 

The achievements for the game can be a bit mixed as completionists may find some of the achievements tedious to get as there are a few that are dependent upon where you are in the story to get. In addition there is also a no save run achievement, this is generally why someone would have to play the game 2-3 times from the beginning. One ending requires you to restart from the beginning only because you refuse the position from the beginning. The others you can create a save right before the branching about 2/3 of the way through the game. Despite this, I did 100% the game and didn't find any achievements absurdly difficult to achieve. For a no save run the game gives you plenty of health items strewn about the levels, so long as players are searching for items on the levels. I finished the game with over 10+ different healing items and took multiple hits from things during my playthrough. It was also this playthrough I did the control achievement as well. 

There are few complaints I really have about this game, if anything I think the birthday party boss battle could have been a bit easier as that battle ended up using half of the healing items I had made at the party, and I didn't really understand how I was being attacked. All the other boss battles were fairly easy however and I had little problem with them. 
In the second route set I would say dealing with the "enemy" in the residences ended up being more tedious than anything else as it seemed to be more based on chance if I would be able to get away unharmed. In the hallways I didn't have any light around me when hiding so it was hard to determine where the enemy was for this. The one saving grace for this part was that the enemy at least didn't hit very hard so the damage was easy to heal. 

Overall, this was a game I really enjoyed, and slightly regret not playing sooner. The art was fantastic, the music was great, and it provided a pretty interesting story. If you have it, play it. If it sounds interesting get it, and if you're on the fence wait for a sale. This is a game I think all fans of Indie games, and/or survival horror should play. RPGMaker fans may also enjoy this as well due to the similar graphics, survival aspects and story.

127646537.review:
Great game and great concept.

This is the kind of game that at first glance doesn't seem too unique but seeing the artstyle and the story synopsis I got interested. The game is pretty charming and has a good contrast of regular horror and office life horror. The gameplay is limited but works well in context so it never feels like it's dragging the rest of the experience down. 


My gripes are mostly with the story. It starts with a mysterious letter from a prestigious company and a baffling task on your first day of work "KILL THE WTICH" as you explore the company you realize it has become an absolute a hellscape filled with monsters and the abused workers seem not to realized the dire situation they're in.

The story is very basic. In the sense that it feels like it's the last part the developers thought about. It starts strong with an interesting mystery but fails to deliver in the promise made by the set up. [spoiler] During a lot of the story the witch is set  up as a big menace and that anyone in the company could be her. But the end[/spoiler]   [spoiler]it was all a fakeout. The "witch" wasn't even involved with everything that was happening directly and it was all basically a convoluted mistake.[/spoiler] 


Also I was expecting the title to be more relevant to the game's story and gameplay. The protagonist being this meek unexperienced person maybe could be transformed by the violence of this company into the violent witch hunter he was hired to be, depending on your choices. But the MC never really has an arc either way. Which in my opinion is the biggest fault of th game's story.

The game has multiple endings and some do branch out quite a lot so replayability is pretty good, but I still feel there was a lack of emphasis on characters.

All that being said the worldbuilding itself is great. You get to familiarize yourself with the different floors of the company building and as you uncover the mysteries the world opens up. This is one of the strenght of the game design in general


In general I think the game is a good concept and has a unique juxtaposition of artstyles which works great in my opinion. If you  don't mind a bit of an unambitious story it's a great experience. 

I hope the developers get to explore this concept again with a more ambitious game in the future. They nail some things really well and just need to polish some others a bit and they might make an amazing game

126944953.review:
A mystical thriller in which the Player will be made an offer - which is very difficult to refuse....

[list][b]Liked:[/b]
[*]+ Localization into third-party languages
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Interesting plot
[*]+ Multiple game endings
[*]+ Built-in add-on that expands the game
[*]+ Lots of text revealing the game world
[*]+ Pixel graphics
[*]+ Anime style
[*]+ Great soundtrack
[*]+ Trading cards for sale
[*]+ Several possible paths
[*]+ Well designed levels
[*]+ Memorable characters
[*]+ Gamepad support

[b]Did not like:[/b]
[*]- There are minor bugs (Able to upset very much if you decide to go through the game without saving)
[*]- Lack of "new game +"
[*]- There are blunders in the plot[/list]

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Quite an entertaining indie project that mixes mysticism, detective, and everyday life. The plot is able to surprise, especially if the Player decides to move away from the main game to plunge into the add-on. Conveniently, the passage of "additional" tasks - can have consequences in the main game. So having passed the IT department, which became available thanks to the update of the game (and the addition of content from the free add-on) - the player can immediately delete a crowd of opponents from the game who could be dangerous closer to the final.
However, one bug spoiled my mood - when the character was shopping in the vending machine and was attacked by the enemy: after that, the game stopped responding to button presses, and the character continued to stand and do nothing. Unfortunately had to quit with alt+f4 and lose some progress. This problem also works when lifting objects and even in a number of cut-scenes - the player cannot fight back and simply dies.
But I recommend this game to fans of indie games, mysticism and a good storyline.

125859647.review:
Lets say a hypothetical Joe got a job offer, which Joe had not applied for, at a prestigious company that would elevate Joe's social status and increase Joe's net worth substantially. What could possibly go wrong? So much, oh so much. Turns out our hypothetical Joe drew the short straw and gets a view to an ugly underbelly of corporate capitalism.

Yuppie Psycho spins the tale in the nightmare of a horrible workplace along with those unfortunate enough to get caught up within it. To put it short I enjoyed this slice of horror. It's teeth are in the story and character writing which as you progress builds up the horror. The pixel art scratches my nostalgic itch and dulls the grotesque visual shock. The item/interacting was clunky sometimes, took trial-and-error plus some repetition to get use to.

125831823.review: Yuppie Psycho is a neat little spoopy game that takes the idea of a hostile work environment to eleven. While the story and puzzles can be a bit obtuse at times and the horror isn't really all that scary, the phenomenal pixel art and stellar sound design give the game a strong sense of immersion; I enjoyed Yuppie Psycho very much.

124446223.review: full disclosure I picked up and put down this game a number of times, each time I started a new game since it had been a while between playthroughs. That being said each time i had fun and i was glad I did. I love pixel graphic games like this with a little mystery and horror. I would not consider myself someone who would play an intense horror game (though horror lovers, there are moments here). The characters are likable and the writing has some great humor at times in my opinion which helps not make the horror elements too much. I definitely recommend having  a walk-through handy just to avoid frustration since the experience was the biggest draw for me. You're exploring a big office building, while there are hidden details and Easter eggs to be found, getting guidance before losing interest or getting frustrated/lost in the game was very helpful for me.

124421799.review:
I have tried to play this twice: The first time, I got close to the end (I think). The second time I gave up in an hour. Overall, fun plotting and an evocative art style are held back by a shoddy gameplay experience.

Yuppie Psycho builds atmosphere and story effectively, but controls awkwardly. This is very noticeable in fights and escape sequences. The vast majority of my deaths have been from weird pixeljank where my character is one pixel over too far and is stuck on the world, or the enemy is one pixel too far out of a weapon's radius. Attacks and other damaging world events are poorly choreographed, often requiring you to die in order to learn how they work.

The limited save system does nothing for gameplay, and in my opinion single-handedly moves the needle to a Not Recommended. Tension should be built via atmosphere (which the game does well), not from the thought of replaying twenty minutes of walking and inventory management due to a death.

Final verdict: Watch a playthrough online.

A superb Adventure-Horror game regarding the terror of Corporate Office environments. The game is solid in it's presentation and presenting it's challenges that albeit easy, complement the game nicely. The real problem (IMHO) is the narrative in some of it's circumstances and characters. There are two routes that could change the endings, but it honestly needed more work to flesh out their inconclusive narrative and also to describe why the characters exist in this world beyond just a quick exposure. Alas, it's nitpicking at it's best and it has a strong core of horror moments, dungeon exploration on it's level-design and puzzle like structure. 

The design of Vaporwave/Corporate Dystopia brings a charm to the game that is unique, flavorful and brings this indie game to it's biggest potential.

Congratulations for the game and what a crazy ride you lead me through. Hopefully, we can see more of this world and what else will entail.

122061455.review:
Yuppie Psycho is difficult to recommend on the grounds of an obnoxious (however lore-integrated) save system, some obtuse puzzles, and some especially irritating gameplay sequences. It's the Deus Ex: Human Revolution of light horror: An interesting world, engaging writing, more to explore than you will organically find in a playthrough, and a dash of impactful player choices - but man, do these boss battles suck.

There are clearly many things that I've missed in my own playthrough. I reached a satisfying ending that resolved the primary story, but the irritating components of the game have discouraged me from exploring the rest of it.

I can't say it's a bad game, because it's absolutely not - but this is a rare case where I recommend you watch a playthrough instead of playing it yourself - get the story and the atmosphere, but spare yourself the annoyances.
