120708754.review:
This game is incredible.
Yes, it's basically a "walk and interact" story focused game, but it's got actual branching paths, a shitload of secrets, very good writing, worldbuilding, and very good art.  you will get invested in the story, weather you want to or not.
It's a horror game, but not really in a jumpscares and sprinting type of way, more of a "solve puzzles on a timer but the timer is a printer with hands that kills everything it touches" type of way. More atmospheric/existential horror I suppose. That is, except for one section in an old suburban house. That one's just terrifying, even if I never died to it. 

Actually, the most impressive part of this game is how resources work. All of your healing/saving/action items are limited, and you are constantly under pressure for fear of running out. And yet, you basically won't. you'll always be uncomfortably close though. It's the best item placement I've ever seen in a game.  
(except for glow sticks they're a little broken in some rooms, and you can always pick them back up)

I will say that some of the secrets are fascinatingly cryptic, so if you're planning on digging through every piece this game has to offer, I'd reccomend taking a look at some of the steam guides if you get stuck. It's not a very difficult game if (and that's a huge if) you know precisely what you are doing.

119877073.review:
[Review] Yuppie Psycho
Hello, dear friend!
Today, I would like to talk about a very interesting, and in some ways unusual project. Let's see what this game can offer you.
Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition review on your screens friends, let's go!

Not in a fairy tale
I won't say much about the plot.
The action of the game begins with the fact that Brian Pasternak (Our main character) receives an invitation to work in the largest company, Sintracorp. Upon arriving at the aforementioned company, Brian learns that he was not hired as an office clerk, but as a real Witch Hunter. From that moment on, Brian will have to figure out all the supernatural nonsense that is happening in the company, meet new characters, kill the witch. And the primary task: to survive until the end of his first working day.
The plot in the game is really great, it will constantly keep you in suspense, force the player to build their guesses and much more. The story keeps the game going.
I believe that this is the primary purpose of the story in games, it should encourage the player to play the game, and not just be in the game for show.

Adventures of the Young Witch Hunter
Location from the DLC, if during the passage you do not see this place, it's okay.
I can tell a lot more about the gameplay. The game is partly a quest with finding objects, solving simple puzzles and so on, but it is also Survival Horror. But let's go in order.
Dialogues with characters play an important role in the game. Like it or not, you will talk to the characters quite often, while the dialogues themselves are pop-up windows with text. Sometimes we will even be given the right to choose.
The dialogues are very interesting and reveal the characters. True, there is a flaw associated with the localization of the game in Russian, but this is not critical.
Now let's talk directly about the gameplay. As I said earlier, the game is partly a Quest.
We will periodically have to think about what to do with this or that object, solve puzzles, interact with characters - which will often let us know what to do with this or that object, and, among other things, will tell quite a few interesting facts about the history of the company.
It is worth saying that the puzzles are very simple, but they do not become less interesting from this.
In addition to being a quest, the game is also not a bad Survival Horror. We have a battery flashlight, which tends to run out, we can only save with the help of a photocopier for a special resource that we will find in the process of passing. There are only 2 auto saves for the whole game. In the future, in order to save, be kind enough to fork out for a special piece of paper, and sometimes even for a cartridge, if suddenly the copier standing next to it turned out to be empty.
As you may have guessed, Brian's fighter is useless, so the only way to survive an encounter with an enemy is to hide from him. This mechanic is fully revealed in the DLC, but we'll talk about it a little later.
I also want to talk about boss fights.
Each battle with them is unique and requires an individual approach, but alas, there are only 3 of them in the game, one of which is not a mandatory and hidden boss at all.
The gameplay turned out to be very interesting and does not let the player get bored, he periodically dilutes hide and seek, running errands back and forth, solving puzzles, etc. The location, it would seem, is not large, the action of the game will take place exclusively within the framework of one 10-story building, but this playing field turned out to be quite interesting and even diverse.
I liked the gameplay, despite the fact that I do not like this genre of games. And this, in turn, says a lot.

Hidden Content
To my surprise, not a small fraction of the content in the game is hidden. Starting from video cassettes that contain mini horror films (and they also act as a kind of collectible items that are hidden on the floors). Many notes that will tell us a little about Lor, as well as new dialogues with characters that did not exist before. The developers were not too lazy to add even a hidden boss. By the way, DLC can also be attributed to hidden content, and that’s all, because in order to activate the add-on, you need to perform certain manipulations, and a person who simply follows the plot rails will not even get to the location where this action needs to be performed. Therefore, a person who loves: to climb everywhere, to touch everything, learns much more, compared to a player who simply follows the rails of the plot.
Important!!!
What I didn't say is that if you just follow the storyline, the player will be left with no content, or will be left with a ton of questions (To be fair, some of the answers are still hidden). Just by going through the game, most things will be clear to you, because they are directly told to you, but there is also a large share of hidden content that is very interesting to delve into.

Addition
It's time to talk about the free add-on. As I said above, not everyone can activate this DLC, activate it:
1. Curious
2. The player watching the guide.
The add-on itself does not bring anything in terms of gameplay. It is simply intended to expand the plot by showing some moments from the other side. It added a boss (This is the one that is hidden), and added 2 new endings. The endings themselves are mutually exclusive, if you have not activated the add-on, then the endings will only be from the list that is in the main game, and if you did activate it, then you can forget about the endings of their original game, only those that are in the add-on.
Apart from the ending, the addition does not change anything, if you do not take into account the fact that one section from the DLC strains and scares 2 times more than the entire original game.

Musical Accompaniment
How to put it this way... the music in the game is simple, but it affects your immersion, it just fits perfectly into the gameplay. For all its simplicity, the musical accompaniment is recognizable, if even six months later they turn on ost from this game, I will recognize it.

Visual Style
And again my favorite Pixel Art.
If I may say so, the visual style of the game is not detailed pixel art, the cutscenes themselves are drawn in Anime style, but also decorated in pixel style. The windows with the images of the characters themselves are detailed, but in the game itself there are large coarse pixels, but this is by no means a bad thing. The developer managed to perfectly convey the spirit and atmosphere of the game, and this is the main thing.

Outcome
Yuppie Psycho - A great example of how to create a great game, it's not the budget and PR that matters, but the fact that the developer is sincerely interested in creating a good product.
Is the game worth the attention?
— Yes, if suddenly the price tag of 300 rubles bothers you, in such cases, having seen the game on discounts, it’s still worth thinking about buying.
Let's talk about the pros and cons.
PROS**
1. Good plot,
2. Nice soundtrack,
3. Not annoying and interesting gameplay,
4. Free DLC,
MINUSES**
1. Crooked Russian localization
2. Hidden DLC.
9,5/10

119389031.review:
[h1]Yuppie Psycho[/h1]

Just like the only other Baroque Decay game, The Count Lucanor, Yuppie Psycho is simply an extraordinary display of what's possible. A game where everything fits together. The graphics, the art style, the audio and sound effects, the atmosphere, the depth, the story and the horror elements. Everything merged into an almost perfect experience. I just like Yuppie Psycho a little more than The Count Lucanor. But just because of the setting. So these are purely personal reasons.

Maybe not everyones cup of tea, but I love the idea of ​​limited safe opportunities and consumables. It's not like you're going to run out or anything, unless you're completely brain dead and feel the need to save every few seconds like some modern gamers do. It's a game where you have to think for yourself, where you have to figure things out and plan a little in advance. Not much, but a welcome sight when you think of most modern games, where everything is dealt to you on a silver tablet and you have to use as little brain power as possible. Baroque Decay games pay homage to the purest idea of ​​video games. A game that you actually play and feel like you've accomplished something while playing. And not like watching a video, where you can interact from time to time.

[b]Summary:[/b]

If you like horror, mystery, adventure, fantastic stories and lore, exploration, great characters, twist and turns, multiple endings and wonderful world building, don't think twice and just give them your money. And while you're at it, also buy The Count Lucanor. It's a bit shorter, but still worth every penny. Yuppie Psycho offers around 10-15 hours and the former around 5-10 hours of quality gameplay. Have fun!

119208232.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a hidden gem and deserves to get more attention. I probably would have never tried this game either if I didn't get it through Humble Bundle.

I am a person that on one hand loves horror games but on the other hand just can't play them by myself, especially not during nighttime or in a dark room. It perfectly captures the horror of how working in a big company might look like inside our heads without relying on jumpscares and the likes of cheap horror. There's a lot to explore and I felt like exploration was always rewarded - either with useful materials or a secret. The characters are all great, especially Brian, who actually feels like a relatable main character on his first day at Sintracorp. 

One thing I enjoyed about the game is that it doesn't guide you as much as other games and that you're basically able to explore most of the company from the moment you enter it. It also got the perfect length with roughly 8 hours for my first playthrough. It got multiple endings and an alternative route as far as i know so there's some replayability through that. Also, big plus for including concept art and soundtrack and offering owners of the original game a free upgrade to the Executive Edition. 

Yuppie Psycho gets a big recommendation for me if you are brave enough to play it and if you are fine with pixel graphics - in my opinion Yuppie Psycho mastered the art of pixel graphics, horror and storytelling/world building and will give you a "good" time that's worth your money.

117404028.review:
The story is sufficiently intriguing and I find myself enjoying the twists and turns. The mystery is engaging enough to have me constantly theorizing while playing the game and when my expectations are subverted it's in a believable and satisfying way. The story pulls me in well and as a result I find the horror scenes to be be tense even with the pixel art style and I think it lends credence to the quality of writing. It was also very nice to see characters point out obvious story details that seem obvious such as two people looking similar. It was quite refreshing to see and I didn't realize how prevalent the "characters are oblivious for plot" issue was until this game gave a break from it.

There is a restricted save system that requires the use of items to save your game. In my opinion this can be a good or bad thing but for purely gameplay intents and purposes I think it's done well enough that I find myself generally happy to engage with it despite being the type that doesn't like limited saving. However the program itself is somewhat susceptible to crashing when alt tabbing. This unfortunate event occurred with my game after an extended period of not saving due to limited resources. It's worth mentioning that as of editing this review there is apparently an engine update coming soon that will likely fix some issues including the alt tab crashing. 

I'd recommend the game regardless, just be aware that if you play it before the engine update you may want to be either more efficient with your save resources than I am or be aware of the risk taken when alt tabbing, or play it windowed (I dont remember if there was a windowed option). It has an intriguing and well written story and as far as i can tell there's a good amount too. The design in horror elements can be genuinely tense and eerie and overall it's a well crafted cohesive experience. While I'm at it save for the crashing I didn't experience any gameplay bugs.
117404028.developer_response:
Sorry to read about the crash.

A engine update is coming in the few next weeks, solving this issue and imrpoving the user experience.

116280510.review:
This game has an amazing atmosphere, the graphics are great and the soundtrack slaps.
I really wish I could enjoy more than that, however, the gameplay is needlessly frustrating.

1) Resource management doesn't make the horror aspect any more exciting or immersive.
It just makes the game a pain in the ass, because if you mess up you will likely have to backtrack a lot due to both save points and save chances being limited.

2) The above issue is even more frustrating due to there being many sections in the game where you have to figure out what to do through trial and error. You will frequently be unable to tell what damages you until you interact with it and lose a bunch of health, for example there are static or non-engaging NPCs which will hurt you if you try talking to them.
There's a particularly annoying example of that on the 2nd floor where you're put into a series of minigames and the first one involves inreracting with boxheaded people in a dark room with a solitary spotlight. They constantly walk around the area and most will damage you on contact. The only way to tell which one is safe to interact with is by looking at the back of their head, which means you have to wait until they are walking in the right direction AND while they're in the small circle of light, otherwise it's too dark to tell. To top it all off, you're not given any instruction or hint for what you're actually supposed to do.

3) There's a lot of missable items, interactions and sidequests which you're cut off from by progressing through the main story without any warning. If you wanted to get the most out of the game without resorting to a walkthrough, you would have to comb through every floor of the building for changes each time you complete any task.

4) The fact that the plot is kinda stupid and doesn't make much sense doesn't help much either.

114943703.review:
[h1] VERY underrated! [/h1]
[i] Underrated in the sense that [b]the game should be even more acknowledged[/b] as of yet. This may change since it is coming out for Switch and PS4 this Summer 2022. [/i]

This is an adventurous 2D horror game with a lore that expands itself depending on what route you decide to take in it. You take control of the main character Brian Pasternack, whose last name means Parsnip in various languages (including my own). In the beginning of the game, you receive a mysterious letter with a job-offer you simply “cannot” turn down.
Upon taking the job-offer to work at the large company known as Sintracorp, you bind a contract hidden under a certain spell. From here on out you are given tasks unraveling the mysteries of Sintracorp–it’s a gorey and engaging story that will leave you wanting to know more. At times it had me a bit shaken and thrilled since the OST can be very eerie, giving uncertainty of what will happen next. In essense it leaves you feeling on edge as you unknowingly go through the more humorous and cheerful segments of the story and learn that the worst things have yet to come.
[u]I discovered that there were numerous routes you could take throughout the game that changed your apprehension of the lore completely.[/u] [u] [b]
I strongly advise you to save regularly and play through ALL the routes to discover the actual truth behind all the mysteries as well as finding alternative ones![/b] [/u]
I have played games with similar game mechanics in the past but this one hits different. It will take quite some time until I discover a game comparable to this. I give this game 10/10!

114917044.review:
Spectacular!

I can only think of one potential negative that MAY apply to a certain type of person so I might as well get that out of the way first: if you're the type of person that plays multiple games in rotation (3 plus games), you may forget what it is that you were planning on doing next i.e. similar to losing your place like a book.

I did read through the negative reviews to consider alternative takes however, I fail to consider "I want infinite save resources" as a genuine issue nor do I consider the other nonsensical dribbling throughout the review section as such.

The pixel style gameplay was outstanding and a massive step up from The Count Lucanor (Baroque Decay previous title).

The game surprised me multiple times however the moment that stands out most is when I had completed it, the realization struck me that I never went to a certain location. I reloaded a previous save file (automatically ordered by the game for ease) and went to that particular location > the entire 2nd half of the game changed for me. Outstanding.

Naturally the plot kept up and changed accordingly but so did every plot arc, ending/s, set pieces, more areas opened up etc > the list goes on.

114639427.review:
[h1]Un Survival horror encantador[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[i]El juego me compro con su atractivo pixel-art, me agrado con sus personajes, me engancho con su historia y me enamoro con su diseño del mundo y sus detalles. [/i]

[b]Historia[/b]: Su historia presenta un misterio atractivo, el cual deberemos ir revelando poco a poco si así lo deseamos. Es un juego que te obliga a conocer su historia para llegar a un final, sino que te invita a hacerlo y te premia con más información del mundo (y alguna que otra cosilla interesante) por ser curioso.

[b]Jugabilidad: [/b] Clásica de survival horror, pero con un toque de aventura grafica. En cada parte del juego podremos escondernos en armarios, o debajo de escritorios para escondernos de potenciales peligros, también deberemos racionar los recursos (que son finitos) para llegar al final del juego. 
Muchas veces deberemos interactuar con el entorno mediante a abrir nuestro inventario y utilizar opciones como “mirar” o “usar” sobre algún ítem que tengamos y en frente de determinados objetos para activar secuencias. Esto ultimo puede parecer molesto, pero lo cierto que en ningún momento se siente incómodo.

[b]Personajes: [/b] Tiene una cantidad de personajes muy variados y enigmáticos, los cuales iremos conociendo más íntimamente y ayudando a medida que avanza el juego. Personalmente no hubo ningún personaje que no me gustara, cada personaje tiene su encanto.

[b]Estética: [/b] Un pixel art muy cuidado y atractivo. Los objetos están bien representados en pixel art de manera que siempre se puede distinguir uno de otro claramente. Las cinemáticas pixel art del juego son muy buenas.
[hr][/hr]
[/i]hace tiempo que un juego no me daba tantas ganas de re-jugarlo para sacar sus múltiples finales y desentrañar sus secretos.

Recomiendo comprarlo a su precio completo, que de por si es barato. [/i]

114493973.review: Yuppie Psycho may have an odd name, but don't let that deter you from giving it a try if you're into RPG Maker-esque horror games! The production values for a pixel art styled game are extremely high, and the writing is excellent to match. The introductory plot is the main character "Brian" has just come out of college in Japan, and somehow gets a red letter granting him a job at a super high prestige corporation called "Sintracorp." However when Brian gets there all is not what it seems as a witch is haunting the place! From there you must solve the mystery behind the haunting, and who you can and cannot trust. The game is full of well made puzzles that will test your timing and planning. Beware there is a decent amount of miss-able stuff so you may want to save often in case you need to go back later(or use a walkthrough.) I recommend seeing all six endings to get a full picture of the story. Overall I highly recommend it, and I will definitely be checking out Baroque Decay's other games!

114374348.review:
Do you like pixel horror games that are action based?  Then this is for you!

The world of the game itself is fantastic - imaginative, dystopian and creepy as hell, but with a somehow hopeful element to it.  The game play is standard horror game play - stealth away from danger or figure out how to outwit rather than overpower your enemies, all wrapped up in a cute pixel package.  

Except there's monsters.  
And a witch that appears at unexpected moments.  
And some rather intense coworkers...

And those VHS tapes.  God, the VHS tapes.  Those are really not cute.

Maybe 'cute' is the wrong word - but this game has style, some amazing pixel anime cutscenes and a compelling plot that I followed to the end, along with some hidden secrets for those who are interested.  (I won't spoil them here).

I hope you make a sequel game or a manga, or an anime.  It would be fun to delve further into the messed up world of SintraCorp!

113451333.review:
[h1] Malleus maleficarum para oficinistas [/h1]
Que un equipo pequeño de desarrolladores españoles se las haya arreglado para crear un survival horror tan original y con tantos secretos y finales es simplemente impresionante. Cada planta de ese edificio Sintra es una aventura surrealista imposible de predecir, los enemigos casi siempre estarán al acecho y en algunos momentos los recursos escasearán hasta tal punto que no solo nos preocuparemos por los alimentos curativos, sino también por si podremos guardar la partida en las impresoras que vayamos localizando, ya sea con los tóner o con los papeles recogidos en el inventario. Con esto no quiero echar a nadie para atrás, pero hay que dejar claro que el juego no regala las cosas ni lo pone fácil, es decir, cumple con lo que se espera de un juego de supervivencia. Cuantas más zonas desbloqueemos más se notará el daño de los enemigos, pero a su vez ya nos habremos familiarizado con los atajos y con los trucos para evitar ser detectados o ser dañados; las mesas, armarios o conductos de ventilación serán el pan de cada día. 

Es difícil comparar este juego con otros títulos, porque a mi parecer no tiene sentido el ponerle al lado de un [i]Resident Evil[/i], sin embargo, el ambiente que mezcla la rutina de un horario laboral con un mundo paralelo, mágico u onírico (de pesadilla más bien) me ha recordado mucho a la saga [i]Persona[/i] y a esos chavales uniformados que tenían que ir al colegio de día y enfrentarse a monstruos y amenazas sobrenaturales en mazmorras, torres o dimensiones chungas por la noche. En [i]Yuppie Psycho[/i] los currantes que te encuentras han normalizado lo irracional y apenas se inmutan. Por ejemplo, [spoiler] si aparece un soldado napoleónico a caballo en el despacho, si un gas venenoso se esparce por una sala o si unos labios gigantes salen de una pared dispuestos a devorar al que pase[/spoiler]continuarán con sus quehaceres y hasta celebrarán fiestas de cumpleaños. 

Este comportamiento tan raro es el que nos sacará alguna carcajada en algún momento de relax entre tarea y tarea. Otro tema curioso y muy japonés que trata el juego también es la tecnología, concretamente la inteligencia artificial, pues básicamente partimos de la pregunta ¿cómo sería cazar una bruja en pleno siglo XXI con  la ayuda de una guía virtual robótica en una era capitalista, insensible y egoísta? A partir de ahí con este videojuego uno se terminará preguntando asimismo ¿qué es peor, una burocracia jerárquica y explotadora o una maldición de ultratumba? ¿Cuál es el auténtico infierno? Mi nota 9/10.

109960541.review:
EDIT: Can confirm with twice as many hours into this as before, this is still one of my favorite Bit Horror/Indie Games EVER and completely stand by buying this ASAP for a memorable experience.
This is probably one of my favorite games, and I have quite a diverse list of games that are my favorite (Bioshock, Bayonetta, FF12, Haunting Ground for example). I really really REALLY like horror and got into the RPG Maker/bit graphics games a year or so ago. Horror and non horror alike, this is the best game in that category/genre I have played so far. I for sure thought I was not going to find this as fun and as intriguing as I did and I can't wait to 100% it achievement-wise. Some parts are a bit hard, but the good kind of hard that makes you want to keep going forward and figuring out what the heck is going on in the story. It def is not rage-quit hard by any means. I actually *wanted* to investigate and get the things I needed to progress. Finished in one sitting because I couldn't put it down. I would highly recommend this as its one of those games I occasionally think about randomly on how good it was, and wish I could play it the first time again. Without spoiling too much, just get it. Going in as blind as possible is actually the best way to play this. The only gripe I can see people having is the save system which is similar to RE1 with the ink roll and typewriter. You need "spirit paper" and you must save at a copy machine and have spirit paper on hand to save. I found this not as hard as it seemed, and felt like there was more on the line if I went out exploring which amped up the horror aspect. But there is nothing stopping you from saving "safely" in between hard parts. There were 1 or 2 times I was a bit aggravated in the game, it was a time where I did die, and another I couldn't figure out where to go, but its so few and far between its nothing to complain about. I got this game on a 2 for 1 sale in the Fall with Count Lucanor, and although I got Yuppie at a discount, knowing how good it is, I would absolutely buy it full price. I thought Mad Father was going to be my favorite in this genre, but Yuppie blows it out of the water. And its a long game! Much longer than most RPG Maker/Bit type games. If you take your time and don't look up anything, and just explore the world, I say its at least 8 to 10 hours, which is wild for a game like this!! If you like horror and the 64-bit games and mystery, you're going to love this! Just get it. Worth every minute I played!

106351020.review:
Yuppie Psycho takes a lot of pot shots at corporate life through its mix of horror and comedy. It’s actually a pretty conventional adventure game at its core, but with some thematic mechanics to tie it all together. Like having to drink coffee to heal yourself. Or save the game by putting your face on the printer. Or use office supplies to battle and solve puzzles. 

It all takes place at one location, Sintracorp HQ -- a highrise with a surprising amount of real estate for a ten story building. Almost impossibly so. It’s full of secrets and hidden cubicles, serving as its own character in a way. You’ll get to know the different levels like the back of your hand, traveling up and down, completing both menial and atypical tasks for your colleagues and superiors. 

Highlights include herding marketing people by catchphrases, and fighting a dot matrix printer that puts even Pyramid Head to shame.

Recommended if you enjoy twisted adventure games.

106052730.review:
This was quite a great game.

I loved the art style. All the cutscenes, all the sprites, the animations, everything looked fantastic. I absolutely loved it. The audio too was great, all the music and sounds especially when you don't expect certain sounds, like the random ASMR sounds and such, all of them were great.

The story was quite good; it had a lot of funny moments, a lot of scary, opressive moments, and it was a lot of fun.

One part I quite enjoyed a lot is the little things. The random events that can happen and the side objectives, like the Videoclub side area, with all their random weird ARG creepy videos, I loved it. It added a little something to look out for, something to wonder about as well, besides the story. I liked it. That and also, towards the end of the game, the ASMR sounds being used to instill tingles and chills, it was great.


As for the bad parts, I did find it quite tough to get all the endings on the original route as I had to replay through a lot of content to get them compared to the second new route, which is a lot easier. I also found the rare typo here and there like with the forest goblin, I know some of his text is bad on purpose but I think I remember seeing a typo that didn't appear to be on purpose. I managed to also find a crash when inside R. Corvos's office when interacting with the left cabinet, the text box appeared and the initial text too, but then everything froze. I have no idea what happened.

Also in the beginning, when you start the game, setting the gamma is quite annoying as one tiny click would send the gamma flying in one direction sometimes, which made it quite hard to get the gamma right. Maybe it's easier in the options menu but not at the actual start of the game. Also, it seems that unless you follow multiple guides closely, you'll likely miss a lot of stuff, which I don't really like. Heck, even I, who thought I checked thoroughly, happened to miss quite a bit.

Lastly, there was one instance when I played a certain cassette tape where I could actually walk, which made it, I think, the only one that was like that. I didn't realize it until a bit towards the end of the cassette that I could walk to discover an interesting scene. I didn't like that it was the only one that was like that and had basically no indication that I could walk except for a little flicker of the character, which at least that is a little something but not enough, a minor thing but felt like mentioning it.


Overall, it's a great game with a good art style and audio. You should give it a go.

105703492.review:
Baroque Decay ya me dejó claro que sabía hacer indies con calidad con El Conde Lucanor, pero con Yuppie Psycho han mejorado absolutamente en todos los aspectos. 

Con la premisa del primer día de trabajo del protagonista, nos adentramos en una empresa que esconde muchos secretos oscuros, personajes variopintos y un humor tremendo. Pero no penséis que se queda "solo" en eso, los momentos de tensión y mal rollo cada vez irán apareciendo con más frecuencia mientras vas explorando el tenebroso edificio ya que la exploración es un elemento muy importante debido a los cientos de detalles que podemos conocer, objetos que iremos necesitando, puzzles muy interesantes y varios finales que merecen la pena ver.

Un punto que me ha encantado es, como detrás de su singular humor, hay criticas al mundo laboral y/o empresarial actual. Ha sido toda una sorpresa esto ya que esperaba un survival horror más con algún toque de humor como El Conde Lucanor.

En resumidas cuentas, si te gusta los juegos indies y/o survival horror, Yuppie Psycho es una experiencia imprescindible para todo jugador. No deja indiferente, para mi se ha vuelto de mis juegos favoritos sin lugar a dudas.

105475154.review: Yuppie Psycho is a 2D pixel art mashup of Resident Evil, American Psycho,and Monkey Island. While it might look like some youtube fodder 5 night at freddys trash, a closer inspection reveals a game with some of the best pixel art I've ever seen (in the cut-scenes), a genuinely intriguing story, fantastic soundtrack, and full of great characters and dialogue. Gameplay is pretty simple, you'll mostly avoid enemies by stealth, manage items and resources (including a Resi-style ink ribbon save system) and solve puzzles similar to what you'd expect from a 1990's point and click adventure, complete with the kind of frustration some of those old games had. There's nothing as bad as say, Zak McKracken and the Alien Mindbenders, but you'll probably want to use a guide at points, and definitely if you want to see all the endings. Overall, i award Yuppie Psycho 9 brick phones out of 10

104002314.review: This is a review I'm writing immediately after finishing my first playthrough of this game, and what this game has showed me is nothing short of a wonderful survival horror experience and as big fan of the genre I enjoyed every second of it. The progression of this game starts with everything seeming rather small but expands much more than what you would initially expect and exploring every corner of these dark offices is very rewarding. Even when you're literally told what to do you can always stray away from the path and find something else to distract with or even lose yourself in. On top of all that this game has some amazing sound design that really nails the atmosphere, some pretty good writing and characters and a lot of content packed inside a rather dense but considerably short game. This game is a hidden gem in the horror genre and I implore you to try it out.

101752747.review:
I hate abandoning games mid-way, I really do.
And I tried to give this game a fair chance... I spent several hours trying to follow the story and find the "fun" in this game, but when I reached the first boss fight and realized I now needed waste my time finding strategies to defeat it - I just gave up :(

Graphics:
The graphics is simple 8-bit graphics, nothing to write home about.
I wouldn't call the game "scary", 
Unless you consider blobs of red pixels "representing" blood scary...

Sound/Music:
There is no voiceover.
The music is atmospheric, but pretty basic.

Story:
The characters themselves are drawn in "anime" style, if you're into that kind of thing.
The story is kind of idiotic.
It's not a serious story on one hand, and not really a funny game on the other.
Maybe if you never heard a joke in your life - you'll find it funny.
But in general it's just knock-offs of jokes you heard in countless other games, movies and tv shows.

Summary:
It's not that the game is so bad it's unplayable.
It's playable.
There's just no reason to waste my time playing this game over any other game (that I'll actually enjoy playing).

I can understand that a game like "To the moon" doesn't have flashy graphics or complicated game mechanics. It doesn't need to - it's here to tell a story. It's all it does, and it does it well.
While Yuppie Psycho tries to be an action-adventure-puzzle game, while being a tiny indie game with pixel graphics.
And that just doesn't work...

100574850.review:
[h2]Pixel-y horror delight[/h2]

Yuppie Psycho is one of those titles I stumpled upon by simply searching on steam. I thought it was appealing and bought it right away, finishing it in a couple of days. 

It reminds me of years ago, when I used to play [i]many[/i] "RPG horror games" and Yume Nikki-alike.

Of course this product is quite different, but it gave me a positive feeling.

[h3]Easy to play, easy to follow[/h3]

The gameplay itself is pretty simple. It's a sort of "hide and run". I think of it as an easy game with some intense moments.
What intrigued me was the actual [i]story[/i]. It isn't complicated or anything, it's just a nice story, well written.

[h3]Interesting setting[/h3]

Having many floors to explore allows the game to stimulate your curiosity. In fact, I wondered for the whole time why the building was so strange. Moreover, the co-workers acting like nothing was happening really helped setting this "strange" aura around everything.

[h2]Worth it![/h2]

If you want to play a pixelated horror game, this is for you. It has a classic gameplay and a good story overrall. Maybe the ending was a bit too predictable but it's fine.

Recommended!


Check out my other reviews here:
https://steamcommunity.com/id/bodolovsello/recommended/

It is a really amazing game.

The game has a somewhat coarse pixel art but that looks extraordinarily good, interspersing some very well done pixel-anime style animations, it misses some more but it is still great.

The game is, so to speak, a survival horror. The atmosphere perfectly accompanies the adventure and as soon as you enter a little full it makes you want to explore the company as much as possible and discover its secrets.

The story is immersive and engaging, along with the recently added free DLC that expands and ends the story makes for a complex and complete adventure.

The duration is relatively short, a shot made the game should not last more than 4-6 hours but you will leave a lot in the pipeline. The approximate duration taking out all the endings plus the DLC should be approximately 16-20 hours.

Baroque Decay Games, homeland developer, gives us an impressive and essential story for those who like mystery with a touch of horror. The game costs every €

The only thing I regret is having finished it completely (I am missing some achievements but mainly from collecting collectibles) it has left me wanting more, to discover more about Sintra Corp, about the witches, about the 6th floor.

I can only say, thank you Baroque Decay Games, for this great experience.

99418400.review:
This game is really good when you're solving puzzles, exploring the building, and reading dialogue. It's REALLY BAD when it tries to add other gameplay elements. 

Enemy AI is frustrating and makes some entire floors a pain to visit since you spend so much time hiding. Boss fights / minigames don't explain what you're meant to do, and what you're meant to do often turns out to be finicky to pull off consistently. Player movement is fine for exploring but feels clunky once you need to move a certain way at a certain time. And some enemies are basically designed to kill you on your first encounter (or at least seriously wound you), so you reload and approach it differently.

All of this would be less of a problem if the game didn't have an ink-ribbon style limited save system. I understand this is meant to make you more cautious and care if you die, but this isn't a survival game like Resident Evil, it's a story game. The fear of dying comes from knowing you'll have to read through all the same dialogue again, or worse, you'll have to complete a really annoying boss or minigame again.

This game has a lot of good stuff going on, which plenty of other reviews already praise it for. But the "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews gave me the impression this game is highly polished. I'm leaving a review to point out this problem that affected my enjoyment, so that others get a more full idea of this game's pros and cons.

99403350.review:
None of it made any sense.

It's not bad, it's just not good.

Graphically, we all know good pixel art and this one is not. The animations also aren't worth mentioning. Pretty much all the game is made of the same assets but they are more of less hidden by pitch black darkness or fog, or colored lighting. The character design is horrible. They're not much but they are enough to be repulsive. They're also as deep as two portraits above ten lines of dialogue.

Storywise, it's a mess. It is half horror, half goofy, but 100% complete nonsense. There is a non-subtle satire of corporate society, but because it is pushed to the absurd and because it has no link to the story, it remains meaningless. Almost none of the characters have any role to play in the unfolding events, and definitely none of the enemies have any relation with you. They have no will, they just hurt you because you happen to be there. Often, some plot elements are introduced, only to be completely forgotten afterwards. It's worse than the typical mcguffins because they have no incidence at all on the plot.
[spoiler]Get the book -> "The book is useless, and I already had thousands of copies anyway"
Get the videoclub membership -> Does nothing
Get the familiars -> Does nothing either
Get the dagger -> "I won't let you use it. In fact I'll destroy it."[/spoiler]

The puzzles also are a mess. Although most of them are straightforward like activating switches, using the right item at the right place, and so on, the most important ones which will affect the plot are on drugs.
One example :
[spoiler]When you beat a giant humanoid mechanical spider, an owl escapes. You find the owl in some other place, and you need to put sleeping pills in a fountain for it to be groggy so you can snatch its jeweled eye so you can enter a crypt, and if you found and lit all the altars around the building you will then meet Jesus which will tell you a story about what's going on, only to find out that this story is not true.[/spoiler]
You don't really have any choices either. There are lots of different endings and some parts of the game can change entirely according to what you did or what item you possess, but nothing warns you that it may be the case. You can be roaming around looking for things to do and suddenly you've triggered an event that will force you into the next stage of the game. So you never know what you should do first. You spend most of your time not knowing what you are doing or why.
And the protagnist is so stupid he has to be taught he can hide under the desks or inside closets. There are monsters everywhere killing everyone but he only accepts to grab slices of cheese and sodas. Can't even just say he needs to takes a piss to ditch a dire unfolding event. It's pathetic more than anything.

But the atmosphere, the ambiance, is well delivered. It still is the cheap distorded sounds in a pitch black room with enemies lurking, but it does the job. Although there is magic involved and nothing is explained or thought through, even if it is one those stories where no matter the clues you have you just know the writers can pull anything out of their asses whenever they want, you still want to know what's going on and it keeps you in.
Sadly, the only scary thing is the save mechanism. You're not scared of what the silly grotesque slowpoke enemies might do to you, you're scared that you'll have to do the last 30 minutes all over again if you fail. You cannot risk trying things out when you most need to try things out or you will have to do it all again. You don't know where you'll be able to save, you don't know how many times you'll be able to save.

Overall, not that bad as I make it sound, but not good either. The game is working as intended and delivers whatever it was supposed to without ups or downs or tense or intense moment, that's about it.
I didn't like it but obviously a lot of people did. Maybe it was just too shallow and nonsensical for me.

99076007.review:
Overall really enjoyed this game! The atmosphere is stellar --it really nailed the sense of black comedy while still being creepy as hell. Bright colors, great visuals that do a lot with simple pixels, and a level of surreal weirdness that forces you to just take whatever fucked up shit is happening at face value gives the whole game a sort of nightmarish quality that I really liked. The sound design is also killer (on top of the great soundtrack). 

Survival encounters were tense without veering into frustrating; I did find a few of the puzzles kind of obtuse, but I'm not so good at puzzles, so I'm maybe a bad judge here. The writing was genuinely funny and heartfelt, too, as well as offering a fresh take on the well-traveled ground of "work sucks and corporations are incomprehensible soul-sucking entities". 

The limited availability of items to save your game was an interesting idea, but I'm not sure it really impacted my play experience either positively or negatively. I didn't save constantly like I might have in another game, but I also never felt in much danger of running out, and honestly I'm not sure running out of it would have enhanced the feeling of survival or resource management that much if I had. I also sort of felt underwhelmed by the endings: [spoiler]I kept waiting for the other shoe to drop with Brian, for something big to be revealed about him and especially for the Yuppie Devil suit to become a super significant element, given its prominence in the official art and also how striking an image it makes, but aside from an implied connection to Rei's father it's sort of an afterthought. I don't MIND the protagonist being just a well-meaning Everyman, exactly, but it felt like ultimately he ended up lacking a bit of depth compared to the Sintra family drama[/spoiler].

As a bonus, the collectible VHS tapes and plot relevant art gallery showcase some really fantastic horror art in and of themselves.

97914828.review:
[quote]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31884377-If-It-Is-Insane/]Check out my curator page for more awesome spoiler-free reviews[/url] 
[/quote]

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Yuppie Psycho is a well crafted piece of surreal horror that captivates the player with ever expanding and new scenarios while formulating a clearly defined target: Kill the Witch.

[h1]The Animosity of Working[/h1]
Working is a big part of anyone’s identity. People define themselves with what they are doing and who pays them for their work. Yuppie Psycho more or less directly captures the player with its atmosphere and the MC becomes an extension of reflection. Brian, the MC, is thrown into a situation of absurdity, yet it remains somewhat understandable. Everything is surreal, but it makes sense in a twisted kind of way. Everyone has gone insane to a certain degree, but a job can be worth your sanity. 
At least it is more than nothing. At least you are more than nothing.

[h1]Working All Day[/h1]
The gameplay of Yuppie Psycho is somewhat tedious, because it has been inspired by nothing else than “The Witch’s House”. Brian mainly just runs around and uses items from his inventory to collect other items. Often puzzles are involved which are not to difficult, yet they remain extremely entertaining.
Often Survival Horror Games are extremely hard to make them challenging and the riddles become too abstract, just to mess with the player. 
While there is a charm to it, Yuppie Psycho is a lot more casual and becomes playable for someone who does not want to repeat the same sequence often. 
Yuppie Psycho is a lot closer to the first Resident Evil in terms of design philosophy. Only the ability to fight back is something that Yuppie Psycho does not offer. While boss fights exist (and they are often really atmospheric and pretty good for such a game albeit the limits show), they are the exception. Frontal Engages are just not an option, because the player lacks the means to fight back. You are not a trained killer, you are just a random guy that wants to survive. 
Personally I think that the gameplay is the weakest part of the game. It is not fun, but it carries the momentum of the atmosphere and is vital for the experience. Changing something would ruin the intended immersion. 

[h1]A Good Worker Is Always Vigilant[/h1]
Ressources are limited and can not be farmed. Everything has value and can be used one way or another. This means that searching through everything is a virtue that has to become a quality of the player. Loot everything, nothing is holy. Yuppie Psycho stacks the odds against the player. No specials power, even saving the game is a limited resource.
Yuppie Psycho asks you to stay tuned and never let your guard down. Luck favors the prepared. Always stay prepared and you will master your job.

[h1]Dark Elements[/h1]
This game is scary. No cheap jumpscares, but psychological horror that combines with the stress to survive. While no real punishments exist, the imagery and themes are scary enough to confuse the watcher. A lack of light and a good knowledge of color palettes formed a visually interesting spectacle that sometimes transcends pixel art. The music is good, but somewhat forgettable. It firmly lands in the “good ambient music” category.
To get the greater picture, the player has to remain interested and focused. Witch means that you have to pay attention to any detail that crosses your way. There are always two layers to anything that you see and that is not good for your understanding, but it will pay off, if you keep asking the right questions.
Ḁ̮̳̼̉͞ḷ̸͚̗̪̰̩͉̀̒̔ͅŵ҉̪̟̻̩a̰̯͕̔ͩ͝y̴͉͎̝̮̭ͯ̅̅ͤs̮̜̙͕ͣ͟ ̞͙̼̲͕̹̦̜̿̏̈͜f̶̻̫̖̳̞̯͊ͅe̟̺͖̜̬ͯ̅͋͜ȧ͙̻̥̓͟r͖̮̦̤͇̙͎̄͒ͭ͟ ̲̺̞̙̄̽͜ͅd̬͔͍͖̦͍̝ͬ͡u̡̲̱͙͇̥̐́ạ̳͇̥̗̬̈́̆͐͢l̻̗̾̊͝i̭̰͍͋ͤ͂͢t̴̰̪͑͆̄̃y̸͇͇̟̖̤͂̂̚

[h1]Parody Elements[/h1]
Yuppie Psycho is extremely entertaining in terms of social critique. Useless unions, extreme motivation boni, indifference to your colleagues and a lot more. If you have ever worked in a big company:
Yuppie Psycho will feel right at home. I can not stress how funny this game becomes, if you get the references. I imagine that someone in the staff was like: What if we took every stereotype of the modern big company workforce and turned it up to eleven. And then they just rolled with it.
Absolutely hilarious.

[h1]Problems[/h1]
Playing through Yuppie Psycho is a slog at times. The gameplay just is not enjoyable, because it is supposed to be trial and error at times. While Yuppie Psycho is not too difficult, dying is extremely scary just because of the thought of repeating actions. 
Limited saving like in Resident Evil has become an outdated concept. There are clear problems with it: It demotivates the player and encourages to spoil oneself to make sure when to save. Making an interesting game that is too tedious to play through always steps closer to the Pathologic line: 
Great to watch and discuss, but terrible to actually play. 
Checking everything is also tedious and has to be repeated, if the loot tour ends with the death of the player. 
The biggest problem I have with Yuppie Psycho is that many aspects feel relatively isolated and do not connect with the greater themes of the game. At least they are not obvious enough for an untrained eye such as mine and many things stays shrouded in mystery. While the approach absolutely has some strong points and adds to the surreal flare, it makes some aspects dubious and good and informative discussions can lead to nothing. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Yuppie Psycho absolutely nails its intentions and atmosphere. The individual scenarios and the dialogue as well as the visual design carry the game and this makes Yuppie Psycho extremely entertaining, but it slightly overstays its welcome and the gameplay can be off-putting.

Great soundtrack. The art style really stands out at times, but the pixel art most of the game takes place in does it somewhat of an injustice. The level design is usually good, and I enjoyed the vast majority of the puzzles you're presented with. It also has some great characters in it and a fun sense of humor. Boss fights are unique yet kinda boring when you understand what to do. However, there are cool little interlude/miniboss things that add fun variety. That said, gameplay tends to center around avoiding enemies - which also gets boring. Overall the story was interesting and I wanted to find out more and complete the game. 

After I completed it I realized I missed a lot and felt like I didn't get the full story. This was actually a little discouraging as I wasn't sure I wanted to re-play it because of the aforementioned boring parts. I may go for a completionist run, and it will go much faster in theory, but completing a game and feeling like you missed or actually missed major/revealing story elements isn't my cup of tea for this type of quasi point-and-click action-adventure game.

Still, this is a recommend because it's a unique game and weaves an interesting story. I hope the developers put out more bizarre games like this.

Overall it's a fairly well made game, and there's only a couple reasons I can't really recommend it:

1) It's short - 7 hours for one play through for me. But it's not a complete show stopper, depending on if you get it on sale.

2) My main issue is the saving. I nshort, you use a limited/consumable resource in game to save. And you can only save via objects in the game. If there was a save-and-exit option that forces you to load that particular save when you relaunch the game, it'd be tolerable. But I often found myself not wanting to play any more, because I have no guarantee that I'd be able to play for a bit and then save my progress when I wanted to. And even if I could play for a short bit, save, and then get off, I'd quickly run out of the consumable item for saving. Thematically, a fun choice, but the overall a bad decision for a game

95465448.review:
What a marvelous little adventure this has been. Yuppie Psycho is the single most complex RPGMaker game I've ever seen and played. Remember all those compelling horror RPGMaker titles we used to play and love 10 years ago for free (majority of which are here on Steam now by the way)? Well, this game is exactly that, but on steroids.

Yuppie Psycho makes excellent use of scripts, sound and video effects to convey exactly what it wants to and does so in the best way possible. The sound design is really good, the pixelated artstyle does fit the overall theme (and budget I'd assume) and, coupled with some good quality anime cutscenes and fantastic sprites, it truly manages to create a great atmosphere.
But not only that, the storyline while a little short, is really well crafted, with multiple threads parallel to one another and multiple endings with the same level of mystery, bittersweet resolution and complexity that a Silent Hill from the days of old could provide. I dont compare just any title to sacred milestones of the past such as the SH series; it is my firm belief that this small gem, if polished a little further, could reach its full potential very soon. For now it has all the qualities of an indie classic and it absolutely deserves to be played.

The player takes the role of Brian Pasternack, a nobody with no qualifications out in the boonies that is suddenly summoned for immediate employment in a megacorporation in the big city called Sintracorp. Upon arriving with his new suit just freshly ironed by his mother, Brian will discover that the work environment is not only toxic, brutal, dark and gloomy, but also... deadly.
Shortly after becoming acquainted with some of his new colleagues, he will receive his first task: Kill the Witch.
Despite the silly premise at first, coupled with small genuine moments of laughter where comedic reliefs come in to help ease the tension of the adventure, the game holds no punches: there are some pretty brutal scenes, ranging from simple murder to people bathing in blood and more psychological horror such as being bullied by colleagues, crunch, and all the typical terrible working conditions that a megacorporation with little scruples provides: The little everyday horrors that human beings in such environments have to face. Those are then intertwined with the more fantastical takes that often spin those concepts up to 9000.
To face all this, Brian will have to use a full invntory system with classical point-and-click elements in full ADV fashon, with the added benefit of being able to craft healing items. He can also hide under desks and inside closets, move objects out of the way, use flashlights and glowsticks to keep track of where he is (there are lots of pitch black areas) and occasionally make use of the dialogue system with multiple choices to trick people - ahtough this one is more of an addition  for flavor at the end of the day.
The overall tone of the adventure is very gloomy as you'd expect, with very brief moments of positivity [spoiler]being mercilessly shattered[/spoiler] sprinkled throughout.
I admire the bold choices made to highlight the state the player is in after each ending, which provides an additional extra scene detailing some of the things Brian has missed for a future playthrough, or simply adding more lore to some of the characters. This is one of those games that wont spell out anything for the player: lore bits and pieces are scattered in each ending and to complete the big picture for a satisfactory conclusion you "have" to play every path.
This is also rather important because at the end of the day one has to be prepared for a continuous string of misfortunes, secret plots, and twists that will spiral Brian towards an even gloomier series of events. 
Make no mistake, there is no joyful ending at the end of the tunnel. The player can only choose how deeply [spoiler]it will sink into depresssion and bitterness[/spoiler] and every second of it is well thought out.

It is rare for me to care about a bunch of 8 pixel frames but Yuppie Psycho definitely managed to make me do so. This is a pretty big accomplishment by itself. I have no doubt that in time, this title may become a classic in its own right.

93862926.review:
First off, this isn't a strictly negative rating. As many have wished before, I wish there was a neutral option for reviews, but considering how frustrated I am at the moment, I let my feelings take the reins and decided to go with not recommended. For all intensive purposes though, this is actually "neutral". This will also be spoiler free.

Is this a good game?

Yes

But also no.

Yuppie Psychos greatest strength is how well it drives you to want to know what in the world is happening. Things become more and more bizzare as the game goes on and it's pretty much impossible to predict what's going to happen next, which means it's really easy for the game to intrigue and surprise you. The story in general is done really well, and I appreciate the fact that there is multiple endings. This alone was enough to make me want to push through for a very long time because I was invested.

The other thing that the game does well (most of the time) is push you towards your objective. At the beginning especially they walk the fine line between too hard and too easy very consistently, and simply paying attention pays off a lot. The game often gives you fairly direct clues, but it's delivered organically so it's not overbearing and you can miss it if your rushing or distracted.

Unfortunately, this is the end of good things I have to say about the game, and from here on we will be talking about the issues, and I'm going to make clear some red flags so that you can decide if this game is worth it for you. Honestly, I'm surprised this game has an overwhelmingly positive rating despite these issues, but I'm willing to admit that some of these might just be the game clashing with how I play. When all is said and done, I'm just trying to provide helpful information.

1. Long periods of waiting. 

This game is definitely not the first, and surely not the last, to struggle with this issue. Yuppie psycho is half adventure game and half survival horror game, and as such, there are many many segments where you need to avoid enemies that are patrolling areas. There are a ridiculous number of times where your sitting and waiting way longer then necessary because the enemies take 42 years to start the patrol cycle over or turn around. I'm not even an impatient person, but eventually it got to me because it happened so many times. Several "bosses" are major offenders here, and one in particular is absolutely ridiculous, which is a shame because thematically it was my favorite. Dying and having to reload seriously compounds this issue and propels it to maddening heights however, because you very well might have to redo these segments multiple times, meaning you wait over... and over... and over... and over again.

2. The executive edition. 

Yuppie Psycho released additional content after it was released that added a bunch of stuff, which is good right?

Well, sorta. 

The problem is they took this as an opportunity to change a bunch of things and move a bunch of shit around. You might read this and be like: "So? why does it matter if I haven't played the game yet?" Well dear reader, that's because it fucks up half the guides and walkthroughs. Trying to find help on what to do in this game is a nightmare. If you don't ever use guides or walkthroughs then this point is, of course, completely moot. For me though, as a working adult that likes to optimize my free time, once I spend a certain amount of my limited existence trying to figure out an objective it's walkthrough time, because I want to like, experience the whole game. So, If your like me and you've left the shame of "cheating" by the wayside in favor of not spending 3 hours walking in circles trying to find what you missed, be aware that finding the answers to your pleas for help can be a frustrating experience of it's own because the developers pulled a DS2:SOTFS.

3. Limited resources. 

No, for the love of god, don't take this as me saying that limited resources are bad. Horror games use limited resources to build tension, and it's incredibly effective. Dead space 3 is a fantastic example of how much you can hurt your game by removing this barrier. However, the necessity of limited resources in Yuppie Psycho is highly debatable, and to be clear I'm talking more about the saves then I am the health items. You need to use an item to save, which would be fine, except it makes problem #1 even worse. I wanted to save infrequently because I didn't know how many save items they would give, and because of this there were many times I had to restart areas (that take a long time). The fact that they give you a good amount is irrelevant, because many games often give you a surplus early and then as time progresses you get less and less. You have no way of knowing if this is the case on your first playthrough.

As for health items, I thought for the most part it was balanced well. Personally though, I restarted many areas so I could take less damage and conserve healing, so while technically self inflicted, this also increased tedium as a result of the games mechanics.

4. The dreaded point of no return. 

It boggles my mind how this is still an issue after video games have been around this long. I understand the point of no return, and I understand why it's completely necessary in a game with multiple routes. What is unforgivable though, is having no clear indication that you've reached it. There is nothing I'm more thankful for then when a game is like, "yo, be careful because you wont be able to go back here anymore." Not a single time has this ever ruined my immersion, much less the experience.

You know what DOES ruin the experience though? Finding our you just ruined your entire save file (ruined meaning certain things you would have wanted to do or get are locked, not that the file is literally broken) because you passed a point of no return way back. This is much less of an issue if your already planning on replaying the game or if the game is short, but the thought of having to go through all those long sections full of waiting that Yuppie Psycho is stuffed with is soul crushing when your already frustrated. 

So, I'm going to do my best to warn you when you've gone too far without spoiling anything so that you can avoid this. As far as I know you should still be able to access anything before this point, so simple adhere to this warning: DO NOT GO TO THE PARTY. IF YOUR AT THE PARTY AND YOU HAVEN'T COLLECTED EVERYTHING YOU WANT TO COLLECT, RELOAD.

In summery, I believe Yuppie Psycho is an engaging adventure game with a fantastic horror narrative that's unfortunately bogged down by it's incredibly weak and tedious survival horror mechanics. I think the game would have benefited much by committing to the adventure game side of the experience and leaving most of the exhausting survival horror mechanics at the wayside. Now that I've already committed so much time to playing already I'll of course finish, and because of my OCD brain I may even force myself to go through again to get all the achievements, but the truth is this was easily an experience I could have skipped in favor of watching a well done playthrough so I could see the story.

If you don't have a problem with/can suffer through the negatives that I listed, then you should get it, because it really is a unique and engaging story experience.

But if any of those things I listed dredge up PTSD memories of past experiences that have subjected you to the same infuriating or exhausting problems, you should probably give this a skip.

As an adventure game / narrative experience it's an astounding 9/10 or 10/10

As a survival horror game it's an abysmal 2/10

Feel free to comment and tell me what an idiot I am for not being able to appreciate everything this game does, and have a wonderful day.

91611402.review:
TL;DR: Its really good!

Yuppie Psycho at first look isn't the type of game I would've considered to be something I'd enjoy. Top down 2-D survival horror is not my wheel house, but a friend basically threw this at me and said "PLAY IT" and I was all "Okay", so I did, and I actually had pretty good time. Without going into spoiler territory you play as a regular dude who got a job offer out of nowhere to work at whats essentially the world's biggest mega-corporation. Taking the opportunity, when you get there nothing seems right from the get go and things only get weirder from there.

Gameplay is fairly straightforward, WSAD to move, E to use or examine, ect. The real meat of the gameplay is puzzles, searching the environment for stuff, and hiding from things that want to kill you. The game seems to be a decent length considering its a survival horror with multiple endings from a indie developer and not a AAA studio, my playthrough ended up at 12 hours, and that was with a friends help and finding most (but not all) of the optional side stuff. The game feels like its the right amount of stingy when it comes to resources. I never really ran completely dry but I came really close at points. For big "boss" encounters they felt appropriately hard but not frustrating, with some brain power you can figure out what to do, then you just need to do it (which is where the hard part kicks in). In my playthrough I encounter no real game braking jank, Yuppie Psycho was basically glitch free.

Music wise the game is fantastic, they got the same guy who did the VA-11 HALL-A soundtrack in to do this. The menu music, tracks for when things get creepy, the songs when the plot kicks it, they're all pretty great. Personally I see the art as a mixed bag, the standard zoomed out sprites for regular people end up looking like they have noodle limbs and matchstick arms, along with no real expression you can see, the dialog sprites for characters however are much better and expressive. The animated cutscenes go even further, and are a genuine treat when they pop up.

The spook factor is pretty good, the devs made good use of sound and other things besides "haha I made the loud noise :)" to make parts of the game decently unnerving. They got me pretty good a couple of times, though the game introduces more comedic elements near the mid point of the game that kind of take the edge off, which I think they could do without. Despite that the game did a really good job making me feel "Wow I wish I wasn't here right now"

PROS: Spooky, good music, lots of secret stuff, great finale

CONS: noodle arm sprites, is funny when maybe it shouldn't be

I say Yuppie Psycho is an 8/10 video game, would recommend.

90703425.review: Yuppie Psycho is a 2D survival horror. You take the role of Brian who's got his first job at a big company. From the moment you step inside the building weird and surreal things start to happen. As you progress it gets weirder and weirder. The story is good, presentation is creative. There are lots of criticism about today's big companies, hostile workplaces, toxic collegaues and much more. They really captured the feeling of being shy and nervous because of your first job and first day at a big company. This is a survival horror game so, expect lots of backtracking. You solve puzzles, fight some bosses, avoid enemies and try to do what you are being told and that is to "Kill The Witch". That isn't going to be easy because Witch is constantly hunting you and she's trying to block your progress. There are no auto saves. Just like in the older Resident Evil games you have to save manually. If you die, you are sent back to your last save. I think the game isn't too challenging, there aren't any cheap deaths or enemies that instakill you. If you explore every part of the areas you visit, you are going to find lots of healing items and special papers that lets you save. The soundtrack is really good. After finishing the game, I'm still listening to it. Overall Yuppie Psycho is a unique game and I like it.

90597245.review:
I had an absolute blast with this game. Interesting characters, well written story, and a unique setting. I heard office adventure/survival horror and was curious, well they definitely pulled it off. I typically don't play adventure games like this. Usually I take a long time to work my way through them, this however was very fun from start to finish. Nothing in the concept or story dragged to where I felt the need to put it down. Quite the opposite I wanted to continue playing all the way till the end.

And you know what, I'm still playing it! I did finish the game and get one of the endings. But there are multiple and there are some rooms and events I didn't trigger my first play through. Now I'm hunting down all I missed. The game play is a standard adventure style. You have an inventory system and must use it to progress through areas and trigger story events to move on. There are boss battles and how you tackle those are unique. (One of my absolute favorites was TV Head Man). The puzzles are not overly complex and that I praise the game for. I'm not one for puzzles. It had just enough to make me think about my surroundings, but not overly complex where I was putting the game down to try again later. Game play and puzzles 10/10 (for me)

The music is downright amazing too! I caught myself staying in certain areas just jamming out to it. 10/10

The story is very unique. I didn't think I'd enjoy it as much as I did. These games can always be a hit or a miss. The characters are well written and there's enough crazy things going on to want to know more about these characters and what the overall plot turns out to be. I won't spoil anything at all, but I wasn't prepared for some of the crazy shit that happens in this game. Story/Characters 10/10 (All hail Sosa, I want to be in her goth club)

Graphics are in that nostalgic 8bit/16bit whatever you wanna call it bit style. I love it. The cut scenes are awesome looking as well. 10/10

Length of the game is fairly short. As you can see I beat it in about 15/16hrs. I wish it was longer! However I do state I missed some areas and events that I'm replaying to figure out how to unlock. So there is probably more content here that I did miss. For a game that's only 16 bucks, get it. If you read this and saw the trailers above and it seems like a game that'd be up your alley. Buy this. I want this dev to make more games, because this one knocked it out of the park for me. I'll also be buying their first game as well The Count Lucanor and I'll leave a review of that as well when I finish that too.

I can't hype this game up enough. Buy it already and enjoy!

90491607.review:
La verdad es que este juego me tomó  por sorpresa ya que, hasta que no salió no supe de su existencia. Me avisaron de Yuppie Psycho porque saben que adoro este tipo de juegos.

Para hacerlo más simple, Yuppie Psycho es un juego pixelado de Puzles, de miedo, pero de miedo de admitir que he soltado algún gritito y de tener que sobrevivir a este primer día de trabajo.

Durante toda la historia seremos Brian Pasternack, un joven que ha sido seleccionado para trabajar en Sintracorp, la empresa más grande del mundo y, realmente, nos tienen un trabajo un tanto inusual.

Ahora bien, profundizando un poco más sobre el juego, la historia me ha gustado bastante. Me ha tomado por sorpresa la personalidad de muchos de los compañeros y los giros que dan algunas de las conversaciones ya que, sin lugar a dudas, te hace muchas veces entrar en tensión, te toma por sorpresa o realmente te hace pensar qué está pasando por aquí.

Cada personaje es muy bueno e incluso acabas tomándole cariño a alguno que otro y ganas de estrangular a otros tantos, haciendo incluso creer que todo lo que pasa es a causa de ellos, hasta que aparece otro y, nuevamente, logra confundirte. Por lo que, realmente, acabas encontrándote con personajes distintos, bien definidos y que, desde luego, te hará cambiar de opinión muchas veces sobre quién está detrás de todo lo que ocurre.

Aunque el tema de la historia para mí no es algo tan original, sí es cierto que la manera en la que está desarrollada es muy buena, en el sentido de, aunque la frustración se presente en algún puzle o en algún nivel, las ganas de ver qué pasará después de hacer eso están ahí.


Sin embargo, el peso que tenía para mí la historia y el llegar al fondo del asunto era muy importante y era la principal motivación para continuar avanzando y repetir fases de ser necesario. Sentí que, tanto al llegar a la parte importante como al final de la historia, pasó demasiado rápido en comparación al nudo de toda la historia. Quizás de la manera en la que se planteó era suficiente, pero realmente hubiese estado genial alargar un poco más la historia y que no fuese algo que finalizara tan pronto.




Algo peculiar con lo que me encontré en el juego es que no tendremos la libertad de guardar la partida siempre que queramos ya que, para ello, tendremos un papel especial, el "Papel de Bruja" el cual es el que nos permitirá fotocopiar (en una fotocopiadora, por supuesto) nuestra alma y estar a salvo por si llegamos a morir en algún punto (recuerda siempre mirar estas fotocopias, es bastante interesante lo que te puedes llegar a encontrar).

Este aspecto es algo que me tomó por sorpresa ya que anteriormente no había jugado a algún título que realmente me hiciera pensar cuándo era el momento adecuado para guardar. Cuándo creía yo que era necesario gastar este valioso papel para seguir avanzando o cuándo ya había avanzado lo suficiente y no quería volverlo a repetir.

Sin lugar a dudas el miedo lo tenía siempre en el cuerpo. Aunque tenemos de sobra, sí hay veces que por miedo llegas a guardar cada medio segundo y, otras veces, te toma por sorpresa algunas situaciones dentro de la historia que te harán repetir un buen trozo del juego y realmente replantearte tu existencia.




Los puzles realmente no son complicados, ni tampoco aburridos. Son algunos frustrantes y me parece sublime la manera que han tenido de combinar junto con los puzles, las imágenes y un sonido ambiental que te hace estar en tensión y he de admitir que alguna que otra vez he gritado. Por lo que, creo que en este aspecto han hecho un trabajo más que increíble.

La jugabilidad tampoco es algo del otro mundo ni es nada difícil de aprender, y tampoco es que debería ser complicado para este tipo de juegos. Tendremos algunas habilidades como escondernos y podremos hacer uso de algún que otro objeto de manera puntual, pero nada más.

Si necesitáis un resumen rápido sobre el juego y si realmente es rentable hacerte con él, la respuesta es: SÍ. Aunque hayan aspectos negativos, estos no superan a todos los aspectos positivos que tiene y lo mucho que se disfruta a la hora de jugarlo.

Si tuviese que destacar algo, para mí sería el hecho de que, sin ser un juego hiperrealista han conseguido tenerte en tensión y pasar miedo en muchas de las situaciones, forzándote a poner todos tus sentidos aunque realmente no lo necesites porque, la adrenalina y ese sentido de supervivencia están ahí.

Podéis leer la reseña en nuestra web: https://www.indiefaktory.com/2019/05/review-yuppie-psycho.html

O en nuestro grupo de Steam: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/IndieFaktory

90041256.review:
[h1] Yuppie Psycho [/h1]

Pocos juegos me hacen sentirme identificado con el protagonista, o siquiera un poco con este mismo, pero yuppie psycho fue una excepción. Brian pasternack es un protagonista con el cual puedes sentirte identificado por las decisiones que toma o por la actitud y personalidad que posee, el cual es un trabajo que yuppie psycho logro construir. 

Yuppie Psycho tiene una historia, una trama que te atrapa de forma casi instantánea, una historia bien planteada que llena de intriga el progreso del jugador, con empleados los cuales además de ser nuestros amigos, demostraran el trabajo de los desarrolladores en mostrar lo bien estructurados que están estos en cuanto a forma de hablar, personalidad he incluso forma de pensar, dándole vida a este videojuego, o mejor dicho, a esta empresa. Un género survival horror que te hace sentirte en los pies de nuestro protagonista, el cómo tienes que esconderte de un peligro que no puedes afrontar, explorar con la luz de la linterna o usar sabiamente los ítems que vas recolectando para no fallar en tu misión. 

Son características que sobresalto de yuppie psycho por ser excelentes en su género, logrando generar este ambiente tenso que pone al jugador en alerta, este ambiente tenebroso, tétrico que cada vez va siendo más impactante acompañado de una banda sonora que acompaña en la experiencia del jugador en su primer día de trabajo en el videojuego, melodías que además de ser un importante factor para mantener este ambiente “tenebroso”, es uno de los que más me ha gustado en estos últimos meses ya que sabe acoplarse a la situación de turno.

Si bien yuppie psycho logra generar esta atmosfera al jugador, no llega a ser más que esto, en ningún momento puedes llegar a tener un susto por algo que viste o por algo que escuchaste en el juego, con suerte pueden ser muy pero muy pocas las ocasiones, pero no lograr llegar a este punto de ser un jumpscare o similar, que, a pesar de no ser el objetivo principal de este género, si pudo ser un buen añadido a este mismo ya que momentos para jumpscare tiene de sobra. 

Aun así, yuppie psycho no deja de ser un excelente juego, que recomiendo encarecidamente a todos. Si bien no tiene una duración “exageradamente” larga, vale completamente la pena las horas que ofrece, de lo único que me arrepiento de este juego, es de no haberlo jugado antes. Pues para ser tu primer día de trabajo, no está nada mal. 


[b]►9/10◄[/b]
