89803566.review:
Normally I wouldn't give this game a chance just because of the artstyle for character sprites alone, but the portrait art and the animated cutscenes more than make up for the character sprites. Other than my personal bias regarding the sprites, the game generally does look nice and interactive objects are clearly identifiable, and when they aren't, the darkness is doing it's job of setting the mood. The music is surprisingly good, too. Each song felt like it fit what I was feeling at the time, and the absence of music is used well. The story was interesting enough for me to want to see what happened next, and I ended up liking most of the characters. Most importantly, the gameplay was fun. There was a good variety of puzzles, and none of them made me feel too stupid or bored. Enemy encounters usually resulted in running away from them and hiding under tables or in closets, but there were "bossfights" that change up what you have to do, and the game usually gives advice on how to approach them in subtle but not too subtle ways.  Lastly, there were plenty of times where the game did spook me, but it didn't rely too much jumpscares, so I liked it. Having to traverse through dark corridors with somewhat limited light sources was fun despite having to navigate around roaming enemies at times. 

Overall, I liked it a lot. A somewhat quick game to beat, but it didn't feel short. I look forward to playing more from this developer if they can keep up the same quality in future games.

89241048.review:
A blood filled workplace satire survival horror comedy. Brian Pasternack is on a low rung of a caste system until the day he receives a letter from a major corporation wanting him to appear for his first job, later revealed to be working as a witch hunter. A witch having been corrupting the company for decades. With most of the corrupting influence and employee attitudes being directly or a metaphor for work and social issues. Monsters are ignored or worshipped, work is done over and around dead bodies, your job is targeted at lower class people to lure them into the company as hunters and sacrifices, employees looking for promotion attempt to get their rivals killed, employees make excuses of getting used to the company culture, not wanting to quit with it looking bad on their resume, or needing to help the team as reasons to stay with the company.

Good soundtrack and sound design. Satisfying puzzle for navigation and the corrupted bosses and enemies you encounter, lots of secrets with multiple endings with the updated version that released last year adding an alternate path for the endgame. Cast of likable and appropriately hateable characters. Well done and mood fitting manga influenced pixel artwork and short cutscenes.

Screenshots: https://twitter.com/Legolas_Katarn/status/1376103030756499464

88998188.review:
[h1]Terror, Humor y mucho pixel [/h1]
 Yuppie Psycho se nos presenta en esta executive edition como un survival horror de oficina en 2d pixelado. Ambientado en unas oficinas de los años 90, con mucho humor, personajes muy locos y que no se cortan en soltarte lo que piensan de ti, horror psicótico y con muchos easter eggs, pero infinitos: desde la búsqueda incansable por todo el edificio de VHS de películas caseras a puertas y habitaciones ocultas.
No os esperéis “por su apariencia” un juego cuco o sencillo. Las muertes están a la vuelta de cada esquina y los sustos asegurados, con esos agentes de vigilancia en persecución por zonas muy oscuras, y Brian con unas lastimosas barritas de luz y un simple café para curarse un poquito.
Consejo, id varias veces a la cocina y BUSCAR bien en cada lugar y cajón ingredientes y alimentos para curar a nuestro amigo Brian. Lo vais a necesitar.

Gran parte de Yuppie Psycho usa cinemáticas propias de un juego de terror, pero lo absurdo de la ambientación y cómico de sus diálogos, rompen la tensión y esa atmósfera de horror y agobio de sus escenarios, para darnos a los jugadores un respirito, y que pensemos: bueno, no ha sido para tanto.
El juego juega con el jugador con ese horror Psicótico de matar por matar. De descabezar y acuchillar a tus compañeros de curro por estrés y el agobio que produce estar sentado 12h en un cubículo a media luz dándole a las teclas sin descanso alguno. El horror estilo american Psycho, de ese sobresalir por encima de todos sin importar el precio ni lo que nos cueste, mezclado con las historias de terror japonesas, dan el toque perfecto a este juego, y lo hacen, diría yo, único en su genero.
Jugablemente, Yuppie Psycho navega entre una aventura gráfica y un survival horror. Se controla maravillosamente bien con mando o con teclado. Por un lado tendremos esa búsqueda infinita de objetos, y puzles sencillitos por todo el edificio y por el otro, los monstruos y ambiente infernal que quiere matarnos. Y no solo eso, si no que el toque de supervivencia viene dado también por la escasez de objetos de salud y puntos de guardado, los cuales necesitan de objetos para ser activados, algo así como las cintas del primer Resident Evil, pero aquí con tinta y folios. Os aseguro que encontrar uno os hará dar palmas con las orejas. Aunque esto anima a jugar sin guardar durante largos períodos de tiempo, para ahorrar papel, pero también es peligroso por las muertes…

El edificio es enorme y tiene una cantidad proporcional de secretos, rutas alternativas y zonas opcionales. Eso también da lugar a un par de momentos del juego en el que la forma de progresar en la historia varia, dando lugar a varios finales. El DLC gratuito y añadido en esta edición, añade nuevas salas y nuevas formas de ejecutar y finalizar nuestro trabajo en la empresa.
El apartado visual es magnifico, tanto en las zonas de juego como en las cinemáticas, el equipo español de Baroque Decay ha realizado un trabajo muy cuidado y precioso, incluso con las escenas de actores reales de los VHS de cine amateur de terror. De 10.
La Banda sonora viene a cargo de Michael “Garoad” Kelly y crea una atmósfera escalofriante cuando tiene que ser escalofriante y tranquila o de reposo en las zonas de dialogo.

Yuppie Psycho es para mí una verdadera joya. Intenso y escalofriante a ratos, y cómico y alocado en general. Con unas 22-23h de juego para ver todos los caminos y finales. Un gran descubrimiento que me ha encantado jugar a solas, sin directos, disfrutándolo poco a poco. Leyendo cada dialogo y comprendiendo la historia. Una historia de empresas, ejecutivos, familia, brujas y ¿sapos?
Sin duda alguna, muy recomendable. 
Reseña completa en mi blog: [url=https://lamazmorritacasioscura.wordpress.com/2021/03/24/jugando-a-yuppie-psycho/] [b]Jugando a: Yuppie Psycho[/b][/url]

Yuppie Psycho tells the tale of a large corporation rotting from the inside with charming 8-bit graphics. The story is good, the characters and enemies are memorable, and the gameplay, while simple, remains engaging from start to finish.

There are no jump scares in this game whatsoever - but the ambience, the sound design and especially the monsters make for a truly unsettling experience. One that manages to never feel unfair, at that.

Definitely recommended - do yourself a favour and play it in the dark!

88395708.review:
Really unique survival horror game with an emphasis on parodying corporate culture. This game was an absolute blast to play. Fun office environment to explore, great ambiance characters and dialogue throughout. 

The music is composed by none other than Garoad of Va11-hall-a fame and this is in no small measure responsible for elevating the games overall atmosphere during both calm and intense moments. This is actually what led me to this game in the first place mostly, but I'm glad to say that the game itself has much more merits than just that of the excellent music.

The gameplay is very resident evil inspired in that you have limited saves that are tied to a usable item, as well as general resource management playing a big part in the gameplay experience. You'll of course find some puzzles and there are plenty of hidden items and content scattered throughout for you to explore and discover. There's not really combat, and most encounters involve you running/hiding or puzzling a way out of the situation.

The graphics while rather minimalist (outside of the cutscenes and portraits) are extremely effective and get the job done quite well. I won't lie that I often have a stigma towards pixel art games that are minimal to this level but this game really proved me wrong and served as a healthy reminder that you shouldn't judge a book by its cover. Just because a game with pixel art doesn't look like Shovel Knight doesn't mean there isn't a ton of creativity and love put into it.

I would strongly advise that any avid fan of horror games owes it to themselves to check this one out. Even more so if you work a dumb desk job in an office building as you'll get even more enjoyment out of the workplace satire.

I almost didn't play this game, since my backlog is so huge, and now having finished it... yeah, that would've been a real shame.

There's nothing to complain about, really.
While the story in and of itself may not be the most original (or at least the premise of it), it's certainly good and well executed, but moreover the setting is very interesting and enjoyable. Obviously a lot of thought went into making it all come together - and all of the weirdness is just par for the course.
As far as the gameplay goes, it's fairly straight forward (so long as you pay attention; you know the drill) and of course there's no shortage of missable extras and callbacks to things you may have previously encountered.

The soundtrack just fits and the atmospheric work is splendid.
While the pixel graphics aren't anything fancy during the gameplay (well, except the obvious character portraits), during cutscenes, they're absolutely amazing.

The idea is nice and unorthodox, but the game is ridiculously difficult. Some parts of the game play like a fun adventure game. You are talking to characters, exploring, collecting items. Then suddenly fast-paced action begins where you have no chance without crazy quick reflexes and sometimes a lot of practice.

This is made much much worse by the fact that saves are limited. You can't afford to save the game after each little thing you've done. So when you're taken by surprise by another unexpected action portion of the game, this usually means replaying, sometimes quite a lot.

I've decided to give up on the game. The difficulty itself or the limited saves mechanism alone would not have made me give up. But these two aspects combined make the game incredibly frustrating and simply not fun anymore. Seriously, I've played platformers with spikes and stuff that were much less frustrating than this game.

Let me be clear, I love what this game could be. The story is really interesting, the art style is well done, and the game play is a good mix of old school console action with puzzles.

However, there are many bugs in the game engine. The sound randomly drops. The game will randomly crash, just dumping you back to desktop. Scenes will suddenly stop progressing and you have to alt-tab out and kill the game from task manager. This is couppled with a limited save mechanic. Normally having a limited number of saves would instill a sense of caution and suspense, but when the game crashes regularly and you lose 30 to 60 minutes of game play, the save mechanic just becomes irritating.

I've seen discussions where people have posted this and the developer response has been lackluster at best.

Do not buy this game if you don't have the patience to repeat lost game play due to crashes.

I hope to see patches in the future that fix this. I would love to finish this game and change my review. I'm not holding my breath though since the game has been out for awhile.

Yuppie Psycho,es el nuevo juego de la compañia que creo el conde lucanor. En este nuevo videojuego, acompañaremos a brian en  su primer dia de trabajo. Lo que tenia que ser algo rutinario en cualquiera empresa,se va al garete,cuando cogemos el ascensor,nos plantamos en la planta 10, y ahi nos enteramos de que tenemos que matar a la bruja que asola la empresa.

El juego se nota que viene de los mismos desarrolladores,ya que graficamente es  igual al Conde lucanor y usa ciertas rutinas que se usaban en dicho juego.

Pero eso si, hay 5 caracteristicas donde supera al conde lucanor.

1 Mas largo y con mejor historia.
2 Pequeñas cinematicas, el cual el otro no tenia
3 Mayor cantidad de puzzles,mas objetos y mas gore que el conde lucanor
4 Los jefes finales son geniales,no son duros...pero te mataran varias veces hasta cogerles el truco
5.Corrige el tema del guardado,en el anterior perdias monedas por que no te daba la opcion de si querias guardar o no,aqui si te la da,eso si,se cambia las monedas por toner`s y papel de bruja.

El unico aspecto negativo que le veo,es que si quieres sacar algun final en especial,esta muy rebuscado como conseguirlo

Importante comentar que en este juego,hay que mirar bien los recursos tanto de comida,como guardado.

Un gran juego,un survival horror con ciertos momentos de comedia,que ademas al ser la version executive edition,te incluye 3 horas de contenido adicional, nuevas áreas para explorar, 3 nuevos jefes y 3 nuevos finales. Recomendadisima su compra y en rebajas aun mas.

85600250.review:
One of the most unique, weird, bat-shit insane games I've ever played, with an incredibly enthralling story. The contemporary/futuristic/alternative-history setting where an Apple/Microsoft type company started by a lone genius and then him and his family ran into some... bad luck, is alone, an interesting idea, of course, but;
the idea of an office building haunted by a witch so they have to keep hiring witch hunters and giving them medieval material to use for a modern setting, the cubicles being a literal maze, employees crawl around on their knees and eat wires and act like goats, the lead of HR is a giant pair of lips that wants to taste you to determine your worth, a man wearing a soldiers uniform who is literally on his literal high horse to tell you that you're garbage unless you work at this company (it's bull-shit, btw), a man who dresses/looks like/maybe just is the devil who appears from time to time to make you question if you're actually just the milquetoast you seem to be, the fact that nobody seems to do any actual work, paper you photocopy YOUR VERY OWN SOUL ONTO, all culminates into a captivating, thrilling, surreal story.
This is literally one of the best horror games I have ever played.
I usually don't go for surreal... anything, really, not that I dislike the idea, but because I like things to make sense. I find the only time surreal forms of media are ever any good is that whatever is going on, be it the story, the visuals, the characters, or just the way everything combined is portrayed, is so completely fascinating in and of itself that the very odd surrealism of the media itself doesn't hit you as 'weird! WTF is going on?!". You don't even think to ask why something surreal happens when it happens, or if they occur to you, you gloss over them because they don't feel important. The only other surreal thing I've ever felt this strongly about is the movie Mandy, the revenge movie where a man's wife is kidnapped by a cult. There were so many things in that movie that logically didn't make any sense, but I never asked why there was a big ass wasp the cultists had in jar or ignored the fact that 'how can those bikers know whenever that... ocarina... horn... thing is being blow' because 1) everything is so interesting that I don't care, and 2) I don't feel like I need to know or that it's not important.
Also, the idea of using an office building as a horror setting is brilliant. I know it was done in a couple movies like Mayhem or whatever, and I never saw those so I can't comment, but I love the unique use of a brightly lit, completely calm area like this a setting. I think most people are sick of asylums, hospitals, even prisons, but the reason why a lot of those are used are because people don't typically go there everyday, they have a stigma around them, they can make people feel uncomfortable for a variety of reasons, unsafe, even. But you go to work almost every day, and you probably feel relatively safe in said work space. Brightly lit, professional, you probably have coworkers you're close with, there's an intense feel of organization and cleanliness are things I think of when I think about working in a cubicle (although the organization and cleanliness is probably all surface, since a lot of companies are either totally chaotic in terms of internal issues or do sleazy things underneath the table or both). I know I have only mentioned movies but I'm sorry, this game is too weird and unique to compare to most other games I know, but the type of setting reminds me of the Stepford Wives, which took place in a bright, beautiful suburban neighborhood, where all the creepy things were hidden in plain sight, often as the most pleasant things in the neighborhood.
I wish more games came out like this.

85370365.review:
It all started with a steam sale and a thumbnail.

I saw this game listed on sale for the Winter Sale and I was immediately drawn to that pixel art.
The "overwhelmingly positive" reviews had to be justified by something, right?

I took a look at the preview videos and trailers and without giving away much, the developers gave me exactly what I needed and wanted to make this purchase; they didn't give any details regarding the story other than the quick synopsis of how your main character is where he is.

The artistic choice of pixel art is always a grand [b]10/10[/b] for me. It's not just random pixels on a screen, but rather a beautiful job of conveying the atmosphere of the game. The music goes hand-in-hand with the pixel art too. Together, it creates an environment that envelops and captures the player into a sense of emotion, relief, thrill, and horror.

[h1] Your choices matter, and the timing of your decisions will affect future events. [/h1]

So unless you're just going for speed run, don't quickly jump to the next objective! They've hidden each event and ending carefully as you progress. There are going to be very tiny windows of opportunity to see and experience them, so [b]interact[/b] on and [b]backtrack[/b] everything!

These last 13 hours weren't completely split apart. I spent 4 hours before I had to sleep the previous day, and 9 hours straight the next. There's so much to figure out and piece together in this game, and I'm not even done getting to the bottom of it all.

If you like horror, mystery, story, and puzzles, GRAB THIS GAME!!!!

85324816.review:
Brian Pasternack, un joven de clase baja que vive en una zona pobre a las afueras de la gran ciudad, recibe una carta con una misteriosa oferta de trabajo en la sede principal de Sintracorp, la mayor y mas importante empresa del mundo. El contrato que allí le proponen no parece dejarle claro cuales serán sus funciones dentro de la empresa, pero todo parece indicar que su trabajo consistirá únicamente en "matar a la bruja".

Tras su anterior juego, el genial "El Conde Lucanor", la gente de Baroque Decay Games, se supera con este "Yuppie Psycho", Planteando un juego repleto de personajes y situaciones tan bizarras como interesantes, dejando atrás la estética lúgubre que caracteriza a este género de juegos y sustituyéndola por una mas colorida, llena de paredes blancas, cubículos de oficina y luz de fluorescentes.

En esencia "Yuppie Psycho" es un survival horror mas centrado en la exploración que en el combate, este último si bien está presente, suele resolverse en forma de puzzles o pruebas de habilidad y sigilo. Por otro lado, el juego recompensa la exploración, no solo con material de oficina muy necesario para la supervivencia, sino con información sobre la historia de la empresa u objetos importantes que pueden modificar el transcurso de la aventura, llevando al jugador a alguno de los múltiples finales.

El apartado visual del juego es una verdadera maravilla, píxeles gordos como puños, si, pero con mucho arte. Tanto decorados, como personajes se ven de forma clara y están bien animados, siendo agradables a la vista y nada confusos. Por no mencionar sus cinemáticas animadas, una maravilla.

Por supuesto su banda sonora no desmerece en absoluto, estando esta disponible para disfrutarla dentro del propio juego junto con otros extras como diseños del juego, portadas, cinemáticas... No pasan de ser extras, pero es todo un detalle por parte de los creadores del juego hacia los jugadores, detalle del que muchos  deberían tomar nota.

"Yuppie Psycho" es un juego que debería ser obligado para los amantes del género por muchas razones, desde lo original y atípico de su planteamiento, que mezcla con soltura y desparpajo muchos elementos aparentemente difíciles de casar, hasta su desarrollo con múltiples "rutas" y finales.

9/10

85240382.review:
Games like this make me wish there was a "mixed" option instead of a simple yes or no to recommend. There are some good things about the game, but overall, it's a real mixed bag. The story, like the cast, is quite plain, middle-of-the-road, and just... there. I kind of get a self-insert vibe as well, but regardless of that... 

The narrative never takes a strong direction into any potential opportunities it has, and the result is a tonally weak experience with some unexplained plot threads, a confused setting, and [i]real[/i] missed potential. Characters are very surface-level and the writing never uses comedy in service of this fact, but in hand with it, and it's just very off to see a horror game with such an absolutely middling level of self-awareness. There are even moments where it's hard to tell what kind of tone the game is taking, and it sucks, because the concept is there, but the story never leans into any real themes or meaning, and it's baffling to see it miss so hard with all of the pieces generally being in place here. 

I'm not personally a fan of the in-game visuals, and certain aspects of the environment are going to leave you confused as to what's interactive and what's not. You'll be checking everything only to get repeated instances of the same "it doesn't work" message. A single time would have been enough. Otherwise, it's a basic 2-D horror puzzle game with items to find and use in specific locations, etc. There's nothing really special about the game-play, which is why the rest of the experience is so crucial, and when it fails to impress, you're left with a very lukewarm experience.

There's also nothing scary here that goes above surprise jumps and loud sounds, and as stated before, no narrative thread to tie any of it together. There's no particular symbolism or meaning behind the imagery. It's just spooky imagery for spooky's sake, which only causes more vague confusion about the horror elements in the game when they do take place in relation to the world of this game. I've seen everything in this game and am left wondering about the nature of a lot of things in it, and not in the good, intrigued way. Feels more like I'm being cheated because they wanted bloody imagery.

Basically, it feels like someone's naive, first attempt at a horror story in the form of a game. The writing and art assets strikes me as beginner, like a young artist who is still finding their footing. It's serviceable and functional, but it just fails to focus and bring it's pieces together to form anything special, and I think it fails to realize what setups and pieces are necessary to make a unique or fun, or even scary experience, in a game or otherwise.

I can't recommend the game. If you're very curious about it though, do what I did and wait for a sale.

85169706.review:
A clever blend of multiple genres. This is an adventure game, featuring mechanics seen in survival-horror or stealth games, as well as point'n click games. The gameplay is relatively similar to a game like the first Resident Evil, but with less focus on combat and pure survival, more freedom of exploring and maybe more puzzles/interactions.

All of this works really well together, but the writing and pacing is where the game really shines.
It is difficult to tell more without light spoilers so I won't tell more, except that near the end the game gives the impression of going a bit too fast (due to too many questions and issues the player want resolved !), but overall it does pretty well.

Although this is a pixel art game (with huge pixels, which could displease some people), the production is top notch. The game uses close-up animated cutscenes when it needs to, and the soundtrack composed by Michael Kelly (VA-11 Hall-A) is also really good.

Last, there are many optional things to discover, as well as multiple endings, which gives it an air of mystery as well as some more replay value.
Expect around 8h of gameplay for a first game.

I can't recommend this game enough, it far exceeded my expectations.

84336760.review:
The thing about me is that I'm a coward when it comes to scary titles, but I want to not be. The first jump scare that pops up in most things pretty much does me in, and that precludes me from enjoying a lot of horror games and movies. What's left for me is pretty is pretty much atmospheric horror, and while I wouldn't say that description fits YS perfectly, it's still a pretty good fit. This game manages to find that sweet spot of spooky, funny and gripping in a way that I think very few things even attempt to do.

I don't want to talk about the story a lot, other than that I liked it: unwrapping that mystery is why you play things like this, so why let some dude on the internet ruin that for you? Gameplay is a mix of solving puzzles and occasionally hiding from monsters. The dev has by and large made it so that you can play a good chunk of the game out of "order", which I appreciate a lot more than repeated scary hallways with occasional branching paths to the same goal. While it's not total freedom of exploration by any means, the ability to feel like I can explore parts of the building that I'm not supposed to be in yet helps a lot with my immersion.

If you even think this might be for you, I'd suggest picking it up. The writing is good, the jokes are good, the art is great, the story is interesting. Outside of a couple of small sections that felt a bit frustrating, I have no complaints - and certainly they weren't bad enough to put them on blast in a short review. Pick this up, and check out the dev's other title as well.

84165046.review:
El primer día de trabajo en una oficina siempre da miedo, ¿no creéis? De por sí es una experiencia estresante, nunca sabes lo que te vas a encontrar. Si tu primer día de trabajo además incluye ser testigo de varios cadáveres esparcidos por aquí y allá entre los cubículos, monstruos variados escondidos por los departamentos, y unos compañeros que parecen totalmente ajenos a lo que está pasando, la cosa se agrava bastante.

"Yuppie Psycho" viene a ser esto, un juego que coge todos los componentes del trabajo en una oficina, con cosas como los compañeros, el ambiente tóxico, la absurdez de muchos procedimientos corporativos, el miedo al desempleo... Y les da un giro, transformándolos en una experiencia de survival horror muy satisfactoria para cualquiera que haya experimentado cómo es este tipo de trabajo, y que funciona muy muy bien y resulta muy fresca como videojuego.

La estructura del juego es la de un survival horror en que estamos prácticamente inofensivos. Tendremos que avanzar por el juego sin armas, ocultándonos de los horrores que pueblan la oficina mientras intentamos cumplir con nuestros objetivos por los distintos pisos de la empresa, y vamos recopilando objetos para solucionar los diversos puzles que se nos presentan.

Las posibilidades son variadísimas, contando el juego con varias rutas muy diferenciadas en función de nuestras acciones, y con múltiples finales, de nuevo muy diferentes, lo cual contribuye mucho a la rejugabilidad.

El aspecto gráfico consiste en un pixel art de estilo retro, acompañado de unas intros animadas de vez en cuando muy bien realizadas. La banda sonora también está muy currada, siendo muy pegadiza y con varios temas de mucha calidad, y para terminar con el apartado audiovisual también hay que comentar ciertas escenas de imagen real que podemos ver en el juego... Muy curiosas.

Como único punto negativo (para mí) mencionaría la forma de guardado. Es un método de guardado basado en el consumo de recursos, y la verdad es que es algo que nunca ha ido conmigo. Comprendo el propósito de esta forma de guardado, generar más tensión en el jugador, incluir el dilema de si guardar ahora consumiendo un objeto o arriesgarse a seguir un poco más con el miedo de tener que repetir todo lo hecho desde el guardado anterior... Pero siento que no es un método de guardado que se ajuste mucho a un estilo de juego en que a veces no tienes demasiado tiempo para sesiones de juego largas, y en que exponerse a repetir partes puede suponer perder mucho tiempo de la sesión de juego.

En general "Yuppie Psycho" me ha encantado. Me ha parecido una auténtica joya, con una gran historia y ambientación, que se ajustaría increíblemente bien a un manga o una serie, y que me ha dejado con muchas ganas de más.

No puedo más que recomendarlo. Una experiencia laboral inolvidable.

84020038.review:
An overlooked indie horror gem, that rolls with a refined and detailed pixel art-form. Soundtrack is decent and the characters are alright, if not a bit one dimensional at times. Hugo reminds me of Norton Mapes from F.E.A.R and the main character Brian looks like if Midoriya from My Hero Academia had an older brother, idk.

The overall layout design is excellent and the main character actually isn't the focal point or the cause of the whole plot for once, so stuff felt like it happened more organically, without the main character's involvement. 

But I found the game's world building to be far too inconsistent, sporadic and nonexistent to be immersive and worth investing in; the game's world design is just a bunch of concepts/ideas thrown in and mashed together with no explanation and it wants you to roll with it unconditionally - Are we supposed to be in some Cyberpunk dystopia, or in conventional Japan? And why are there rebels and why do they show up only once? That scene felt incredibly out of place, even for a game like this. 

The Synthwave/Vaporwave gimmick has gotten very tired at this point but thankfully here it was used sparingly. The game is a bit short if you know what to do, but it can get unbearably long if you're trying to 100% it. 

Still an excellent work of art to try out and is one of the most underrated indie titles I've seen released on Steam for quite a while.

83598114.review:
What can I say? It's incredible.

Let me start by saying I'm a little squeamish when it comes to horror, I don't handle jumscares very well among other things - yet I always am drawn to the mystery and psychedelic aspects of it. And this game delivers so, so well.

I am a "Yuppie" myself, who's been working at different corporate environments. And this game somehow manages to grasp that uncanny feeling that comes with working for a soulless corporation and twists it into a unique, often humorous terror. 

If you think 'humorous' and 'terror' don't go well in one sentence, let me quote a conversation with a friend I had the other day: "I JUST GOT BEAT UP BY ELDRITCH TV-HEADED PEOPLE AND HEALED MYSELF WITH INSTANT NOODLES STOLEN FROM THE FRIDGE IN THE CAFETERIA". If this doesn't speak to you, then perhaps this game is not for you, and that's ok.

The atmosphere, the setting, the writing and art are so good, it's easy to forget another thing: Gameplay! And this game delivers so, so well. No cheap deaths, there are plenty of interesting ways to avoid/fight the monsters (usually the former, it wouldn't be horror otherwise), and most importantly, the progression in the game really makes you feel smart. Get this, do that, talk to this person. It's like a point-and-click game except things actually make sense. And every step you make grants great satisfaction.

For the record, I've been playing the DLC version, which has some additional content as well as an alternative endgame sequence. I've been playing for 16 hours and I saw pretty much all the content I cared to (which is almost everything!). I didn't have to consult a guide for my first ending at all. And later, when I did, it was merely to show me that I misread a part which got me stuck, the rest I got on my own.

If there's one thing I'd like to complain about is that every time I launched the game I had to re-configure my controller. A little annoying, but this game is such a treat, I really didn't mind, if anything it was a nice ritual to get into the right state of mind.

What are you waiting for? If you've read this far, I'm pretty sure you already know if you want the game or not. Get it! Don't even wait for a sale, those guys absolutely deserve your money. (the DLC's free.)

Feel free to visit my curator page for more charming games! c:
[/url][/quote]

This is honestly one of the games I played this year that engaged me the most and undoubtedly one of the best games of 2019 in my opinion, I went in thinking I would have liked it and even then it exceeded my expectations.

You can expect a puzzle adventure horror game that's kind of reminiscent of old-school RPG Maker horror with some light resource management and multiple endings. What's great is that even if the game's inspirations are pretty clear Yuppie Psycho still manages to make the best out of them and forge its own psychedelic identity.

Gameplay mostly consists of finding the right items, using them in the right places and solving puzzles, often times all at once. I did get stuck or lost a couple of times, but I found that to be part of the fun in finding the solutions, being stuck never got to the point of frustrating for me.

Story-wise the game is interesting enough but its the characters that really make this side of the game special. Music is really good too, VA-11 Hall-A's composer Michael Garoad's style is unmistakable and his tracks fit the various situations perfectly, which contributes in making Yuppie Psycho stand out in its genre.

If you're looking to scratch that RPG-Maker horror game itch or just experience a unique and bizzare spooky game then Yuppie Psycho definitely makes the cut.

83353310.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a quirky top-down adventure-horror game that puts you into the shoes of the perpetually confused Brian, a young man who's just finished basic studies and received an unsolicited job offer from one of the largest and wealthiest corporations in the world - SintraCorp.

Unsure of how he could qualify to work for such a prestigious company with no resume to speak of, Brian quickly learns that this "dream job" is anything but: he must find and exterminate a witch that has laid a deadly curse on the building and its employees.

Yuppie Psycho is drawn in a style that fuses both 8-bit and 16-bit pixel art to illustrate a beautiful (and at times unnerving) gameworld. The gameplay is largely exploring the SintraCorp HQ in a semi-linear fashion, performing mundane work tasks, solving puzzles, and trying to find clues to unravel the dark past of the Sintra family and their ties to the aforementioned witch.

The game waffles between macabre and Dilbert-esque humor (and sometimes combining the two) in its storytelling and cast of characters to really play on terms like 'toxic workplace' or 'hostile work environment', and it's super memorable. While tone of the game is overall serious, there are small bits of humor thrown in to lighten the mood. I wish I could elaborate more here, but the story is the main draw of the game so I don't want to spoil anything!

There is a health bar and limited healing items that Brian can collect, but he cannot fight enemies. He must run, hide, or sometimes solve puzzles to best his foes. The addition of the run button is especially welcome if you've played Baroque Decay's other game, The Count Lucanor, which this game shares many similarities with.

The music is another high point of Yuppie Psycho, ranging from both plucky chiptunes to foreboding and atmospheric ambiance.

If you enjoy adventure games I think this is a no-brainer, just be warned that the exploration and story are the main draws of the game. If you don't keep a keen eye out for clues and listen to the dialogue, you will likely end up stuck revisiting areas several times over, which can be very frustrating.

It is also worth nothing there is a decent amount of replayability here too, as the free Executive Edition DLC added in an entirely new story section that can act as an alternative to the second half of the original game. After you beat it once or twice on your own (I apparently played through the DLC half/endings on my first playthrough), it might be worth looking at a walkthrough to make sure you've experienced all of the branching paths the game has to offer, as all of the endings are worth seeing.

81788037.review:
A pesar de que no tiene tanto nombre como otros juegos del estilo (véase Undertale), creo que Yuppie Psycho es una de las mejores aventuras indies que he jugado jamás. Es un survival horror 2D, con una atractiva e intrigante historia, con una buena duración (8-10 horas), con personajes interesantes y con varios finales distintos.

La verdad es que la trama, aunque en ocasiones pueda ser un poco manida, está muy bien hilada, tiene buen ritmo y muchos secretos * a descubrir, y con los que ir desvelando información. Otra cosa que funciona a las mil maravillas es ese constante juego entre terror y comedia. Cuando tiene que ser un juego de terror lo es, con atmósferas cargadas de suspense, sigilo, música apropiada y algún que otro susto. Y cuando se dedica a la comedia ** también lo clava, con situaciones surrealistas y graciosas.

* Recomiendo encarecidamente rezar en los 3 altares, imprescindible para enterarse de una buena parte de la trama.
** ¿10 horas de Mr. Fileto? Really? XD

En general, me ha parecido una maravilla. Aunque el principio sea un poco lento y su aspecto pueda echar para atrás a los menos aficionados a la estética pixel, hacedme caso, dadle una oportunidad, sino os estaréis perdiendo una verdadera joya.

81458719.review:
TLDR; This game has such a great atmosphere, soundtrack, and characters which make up a mind-blowing experience.

I had a blast playing through this, and I felt it is completely necessary for me to review and recommend this game. I grew up playing a variety of RPGmaker and pixel horror games such as Yume Nikki, The Witch's House, Ao Oni, IB, and Mad father among many others. This game perfectly captures the dark humor and delightful scares that made many of these games so great, without big budget graphics or complex gameplay. The story and characters are compelling in a way that makes each moment and puzzle exciting. The puzzles themselves were never overly difficult and the "boss" sections were always entertaining and stressful in the best way.
I also can't give enough love to all of music and sound in this game. This game is so underrated, and I really hope that it gains popularity with how great it is!

79635478.review:
[code]Curator page here-->[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37670120/] DaRevieweD 50 [/url]<-- [i]New review every Sunday[/i][/code]

Baroque Decay is an indie team made up of creative minds from around the globe~ An up-and-comer in the pixelated, surrealistic horror scene with a cult following.....wdym it's a secret?! Two critically acclaimed titles under their belt; first was [b]The Count Lucanor[/b] (it's next on my list) and recently [b]Yuppie Psycho (YP)[/b] which metamorphosed into its GOTY / Executive Edition- with whole new areas, bosses and additional hours~ congratulations!! 

Full disclaimer, I just recently finished my first playthrough and have yet to start on the extra content!! Besides, the OG experience was already so impressionable that if anything, it should make me long for the expanded YP even more!!


[h1]"First Day Is Hell..."[/h1]

[u]The Gist:[/u]
It's Brian Pasternack's first day. Belonging to the much detested and marginalized 'Class G', he has had to work extra hard to pursue an education that will one day raise his standing within the stratified society. Unqualified, self-doubting- he obtains a job offer from the gigantic, mega-famed Sintracorp that is basically everyone's and their mother's dream job... Was his luck beginning to change? Or did the dream turn into a nightmare??  

[spoiler] ! I'm the lowest of the low. I'm garbage[/spoiler]


[h1][+] PROS;[/h1]

[b](a) The Initiation[/b]
An office survival horror where the goal is to find out what the heck is your responsibility? On that note, you must explore the entire building in search of clues, establish new friendships and not get killed by workplace hazards!! To help you, vendors will gradually be made available; specializing from office supplies, technology and...witch paper supply? If that's not overwhelming enough- running away and hiding from some disgruntled co-workers is also a viable choice. 

Don't forget to take intermittent breaks because you'll soon find that stuffing your face with sandwiches, pizzas, noodles or watercooler loitering make all the difference from life and death!! Of course, if you get bored- you can get acquainted with memos, hidden VHS tapes (painful to watch) to pass the time! What monsters wouldn't let you unwind~If they don't, that's what the "Boss" boss fights are for~~

[b](b) Dress for The Par- Division You Want!![/b]
Setting aside the eye-popping pixel art that alternates between fully animated cutscenes and 3D static environments- the effective presentation has to do with the 10 storeys. Which not only serve different functions, their dissimilarities get further emphasized by unique, red flagged designs and atmosphere. I loved to wade through the darkness with just a glowstick and see the many colors meekly light up my path. My favorite would be the fifth floor because that's where Brian's desk is~ Hard to pick a favorite because they all stand out... and I'm not talking about aesthetics anymore O_X 

Thankfully some characters are still sane, albeit with their own vices. There's the class-conscious Mr. Chapman, who lashes out at suburb trash, the socially awkward Miss Sosa who's seen some things and of course newbie Kate who's from a higher class but kind, fresh-faced to everything like you. The soundtrack is also equally foreboding, with what I can only describe as eighties-like and a mix of East-Asian influences. Every track has that lingering quality of etching itself into your brain and is generally pretty manic. I definitely recommend listening to it again on the in-game player.

[b](c) The Higher You Climb...[/b]
Now the story- utterly weird but feels very real as well. Minus the fictional portions, the idea of [spoiler]greed [/spoiler]bearing consequences isn't revolutionary per se but rather how it was worked in; the inclusion of a whole workplace, the stressing on class (so very Marxist)... Now I haven't worked very much myself but there's a little bit of everything in the core morals for people to take away. 

You could be someone about to enter the workforce, who's very experienced or maybe even almost retiring- there are teachable moments or even ones you've faced yourself! Your first day, some backstabbing co-workers, conflict with upper management, a birthday party gone awry and other livid self-depreciating times that you've braved through!!

[b](d) Not in The Job Description[/b] 
YP is absolutely scary and that's before the deeper minutiae of analyzing the horror beneath. 
1st) The title taught me a new word, YUP that's right! So it means a crazy, well-dressed and established professional. That's kinda contradictory when you think about it but I'll just leave it at that. 

2nd) Next, YP takes place across a single day- which says a lot because as they say first impression is what counts! But it's a time of pure confusion; how would you be treated, what exactly are your duties.. Will you fit in? Won't someone show you the ropes??! And all that is tackled in YP, with more questions than answers. The entire [spoiler]"kill the witch"[/spoiler] directive is basically an illustration of being handed a task that's so baffling, you don't know where to even begin. Lo and behold that's what happened...

3rd) It only grows worse when you factor in the state of workers who have endured the treacherous work conditions longer than you and some barely living (if you can call it that) and hanging in there. Level four was filled with poisonous gas and what better way to show a toxic environment that that!!? 

4th) Throughout your time with the company, you will be subjected to the same demanding, unfathomable happenings. But why has no one spoke out against all these? Fear?? Conditioned to look the other way??? Workplace politics is just not that simple. You hear of some legends who almost toppled the twisted status quo and returned the company into its glory days. But alas, they are but myths...right? Finally, there's no telling what will happen at the end of the day- some may not even last that far and that's where YP' many endings (now seven) prevail.


[h1][-] CONS;[/h1]

[b](i) Slacker!![/b] 
YS has a difficulty curve or it's just a hiccup in the programming. Sometimes in certain boss fights or general evading of pursuers, the alerted enemies take their sweet time to go back to patrolling. Again could be deliberate, but I had to wait for a minute at most for them to go away; the stark offender is a certain instant-catch situations. I guess it's also strange as to why hiding under desks (legs visible), in metal cabinets would even work with them hot on your briefs. It can get pretty awkward as you watch them pretend not to see you. 

[b](ii) Work, W. O. R. K... wOrK?[/b]
Essentially real-life story projected through a pixelated overlay. But the fictitious elements that exist can be very jarring (not a bad thing). Seeing as I was already moved, enveloped by the overarching statement YP told on the workplace and the amoral nature in treatment of staffs. I do feel the impact was lost, just a smidge though... It works since incorporating fantasy has been known to be their signature!


[h1]"-But It's Not The End"[/h1]

In closing, YP effortlessly bakes in sardonic humor with real-life concerns over the workplace by placing a hyper-paranoid filter and under-your-skin imagery to get the urgency across. Though the strange, highly unsettling plot can get incomprehensible, the overall message is clearly delivered, punctuated by a anxiety raising score and wonderfully written characters. Don't be naive however, it will eat you alive with its at times unfair game design and in fact, its greatest moments are easily missed because of the semi-open corporation building but only if you let it~ 

[h1]9.5/10[/h1]

[b]Replaying soon for them extra hours of content![/b]

79561877.review:
English and Spanish (Despues del apartado en ingles):

Don't let the weird title deter you, this is a great survival horror.

The game is a great representation of a toxic work place, everyone who has worked in a toxic workplace will understand all the references, the game has multiple endings and there is no combat, your only weapons are your wits and stealth.

The good:
-Pixel art is superb: Almost everything in the game is pixel art (the only exception are some videos you find along the game, very creepy real footage), all cut scenes are beautifully done in pixel art, as an hobbyist pixel artist I personally appreciate all the effort and love put into this game.
- No jump scares: All horror in the game is subtle or creepy situations, nothing jumps at the screen, mind you, some times you jump because a sound, but that is part of the creepy atmosphere.
- The story and mystery are pretty good, you keep guessing who is the witch and the clues are clever, you draw a lot of conclusions which keeps you from figuring out the truth early (thing that happens to me a lot since I'm a horror fan since a very young age) 
- The sounds effects and music are great, play it with headphones for full immersion.

The bad:
- If you are looking for great cutting edge realistic graphics, this is not a game for you.
- The game does not hold your hand, and as a working adult I was forced to look for a guide since sometimes life kept me from playing for 1 or 2 weeks and I forgot what I was doing.,
- If you are looking for combat, this is not a game for you.
- The main character is kind of a wimp, I tend to hate those kinds of MCs, but in this case I was able to like the guy but I understand if some people can't bring themselves to like him.

Final conclusion: I personally put this game as one of my favorite horror games in 2020, the story does not drag, it has a great pacing and it doesn't over stays its welcome, I got all the endings and loved every minute of the game.

10/10 Must buy.

Español:

Creo que este es una joya que me hubiera perdido de no ser por que Steam me lo recomendó.
Lo primero que diré es que este es un juego survival horror, no hay combate, tus únicas armas son tu ingenio y habilidad para esconderte, algunos encuentros con jefes son acertijos o rompecabezas tipo Zelda.

El juego muestra de manera excelente un ambiente de trabajo toxico, si has trabajado en una empresa toxica podrás entender las referencias, si no, pues por lo menos te prepara para conocer los signos.
El juego trata del primer día de trabajo de Brian, una persona de “casta baja”  en un mundo alternativo, que recibió una invitación para trabajar en una empresa de clase mundial que no acepta a cualquiera en sus filas, pronto descubre que el trabajo que le ofrecieron no es nada normal al igual que el lugar de trabajo, lo peor de todo es que los demás empleados no lo notan.

Lo bueno:
-	El juego está hecho completamente con pixel art (con la excepción de unos clips de video que encuentras en forma de VHS, esos son clips reales bastante escalofriantes y bizarros). Personalmente, como un artista pixel art de hobby, aprecio el esfuerzo y amor que le pusieron a este juego, se nota mucho.
-	No “jumpScares: Nada te salta a la pantalla, no hay sustos baratos, todo es la atmosfera del juego, usando elementos visuales y auditivos combinados en escalofriantes situaciones.
-	El audio es perfecto, la música ayuda a construir esa sensación de que algo esta mal, es muy recomendable jugar con audífonos.
-	La historia y el ritmo de la historia son geniales, el juego no es muy corto ni muy largo, dura lo que debe y no se alarga innecesariamente, si eres fan de los creepypastas este juego definitivamente te va a gustar.

Lo malo:
-  Si buscas los mejores graficos, este no es un juego para ti.
- El juego no te va a llevar de la mano, hay veces en que no podía jugar por 1 o 2 semanas y al volver no tenia idea que estaba haciendo por lo que tenia que consultar guías para ponerme al corriente.
- Entiendo que hay personas que necesitan combate, este juego no lo tiene.
- El personaje principal es un completo pelele, generalmente no me gustan nada ese tipo de personajes principales, en este caso, Brian, fue un personaje que termino por ganarse mi aprecio a lo largo del juego, pero puedo entender que haya gente que no logren tomarle aprecio.

Mi conclusion final: Si te gustan los survival horror con terror sutil y no combate este es un juego para ti, en lo personal creo que es una gema escondida del 2020. La historia dura lo que tiene que durar y tiene un ritmo increíble. Tiene finales multiples y una historia interesante y misteriosa. 

10/10 Compralo

79437486.review:
So I'd like to preface this by saying that I'm a huge baby when it comes towards horror games.

I'm not a big horror guy at all. In fact, I think that Yuppie Psycho might be the first horror game that I've really gotten into, and that's good because it is a fantastic game! It drew me in through it's style and music (Which was done by Garoad, the guy who composed for Cyberpunk Bartender, and who knocked it out of the park on this one too!) and kept me around for its pacing and story. It's unique brand of "office horror" and overall tone has created a very memorable experience, and has been extremely enjoyable to play. There are some minor issues I have with the game, and some of it's subsequent DLC, but they're really minor gripes that don't take away from the overall experience. 

So the game is a horror adventure game inside an office building with a fair amount of open exploration and secrets, and a lot of cool collectibles. Health items and other supplies are littered everywhere, so be sure to check everything you see. You're given loose instructions and are told where to go, but you're allowed to explore a lot more of the building beforehand/before specific events to get a feel on where you're going and what you're doing. The puzzles are pretty simple, but they're cool enough that I never felt bored or stuck doing them, and some managed to be very clever in execution. It's a very fair game, and if you die, it usually feels like your own fault as opposed to the game's. A minor gripe is that sometimes the collision can be a bit wonky on specific parts and feel weird, but it didn't happen often enough to warrant any concern beyond minor annoyance. It also uses a flashlight system where you can run out of batteries, but it's so generous that it's not obnoxious. Its chock to the brim with secrets and collectibles too, and each one adds to the experience beautifully to build and FLESH out the world. 

The story is great, and I'm not going to talk about it in order to not spoil anything, but I would like to say that while I did enjoy the DLC's additions, I didn't like them as much as I thought I would. The DLC kind of loses focus on the setting and premise, and while the new sequences it brought were just as fun as the original, it felt like it didn't fit in as well as it should. I was really hoping for additional content that added to the original experience more than I did additional, ahem*, routes, but even so, it was still really fun, so I won't complain much.

Overall, Yuppie Psycho is really good game. Goes right on my favorites bar. And I wouldn't have it any other way.

79133751.review:
Where do I even begin with this game?

I'm a big fan of horror-lite games—specifically horror games with a pixelated art style like this. What first drew me to this game was the fact that the main character looks a lot like Tohru Adachi from Persona 4. So, I put it on my wishlist and waited for the right time to buy it. Said "right time" ended up being a few days after I lost my own job and needed some retail therapy.

I was completely blown away. From the moment Brian stepped into that building and started getting yelled at by a fellow new recruit just because he wasn't upper-class, I was hooked. And then the scares came. The game sometimes tosses in a jumpscare or two, but the insanely creepy vibe is more than enough to make the terror last.

This game is a goddamn acid trip. More than that, it's an allegory on toxic workplaces. It tells you a story about a guy who started working at a prestigious company, realized that it was actually a nightmare, tried to escape, but couldn't because he'd be branded a failure if he did. All of those motivational team meetings? They just remind you that you're trash whose only purpose is to give your life and blood to the company. All those incentives? Traps to keep the company's hold on you nice and tight. That friendly guy who first greeted you when you got to your office? Don't get on his bad side—he's been here the longest, and he can ruin your life if you dare to challenge his position, intentionally or no.

Writing reviews is difficult. I never really know what to say, beyond that I adore the game and think everyone under the sun should play it. That's how I feel about this game. I recommend this game to any and all horror junkies, people who hate their job, and people who just love Brian's little baby face and his stupid haircut and geeky glasses.

79057109.review:
An intricate, engaging horror-ish adventure game which unfortunately struggles to produce a coherent lore.


The base gameplay formula of players exploring, looting, avoiding danger and pursuing goals is very fun and compelling. The game builds a strong interconnecting environment for players to run around in, full of items and collectibles. It introduces a decently interesting and well written cast of characters for players to meet, gradually developing a tangible relationship with them as the story progresses. The game especially does well to balance its horror elements with the absurd surrealist atmosphere it simultaneously creates, blending together into a really unique feel for the experience.

The gameplay mostly keeps a consistent level of effort and progress to the tasks players perform throughout, although the boss encounters are generally the worst part. Most of the significant encounters where players must accomplish something while under the threat of a unique foe are either too easy, too tedious or too obscure. This is made even worse by the game having a manual, location based save system; where anytime players die they must collect all the items, have all the conversations, and do everything else they did since last saving all over again. Even worse still is that players have to pay for each save with a limited consumable item. So players are further pressured into rationing their saves which further increases the likelihood of a death setting players back a significant amount.

This in all results in the game having very specific phases of frustration. The puzzles themselves are mostly intuitive, the main hangups on the flow of gameplay end up being the parts where players have to deal with an enemy whose gimmick is just not very clear. Which causes repetitious deaths and lots of wasted time redoing things because of the save system.

As good as the writing is the lack of cohesion to the overarching narrative is the biggest weakness of the game. The momentary encounters players have with the various characters and absurdities of the world are great. But the mystery that players are supposed to be uncovering through all this is barely telegraphed. The game occasionally presents inconsequential, random pieces of lore about the world that don't really contribute to understanding what's really happening. Meanwhile the pieces that seemingly are meant to be important are also so vague and random that it really doesn't contribute to any comprehension overarching story either.

The ending, the truth reveal, would potentially have the same impact on the player at the end of the game as it would if players witnessed it at the start. Because by the end of the game players really don't understand the actual world much better than they did after their surface level introduction to it. The truth itself is just not very satisfying, it barely makes much sense. So while the absurdity of the plot is generally its most distinct feature, that absurdity also seems to cost it a coherent lore. Because the lore is just about as spontaneous as everything else that happens, and while spontaneity is great for a journey it's not very great for an end.


Although the specific instances of frustration due to tedious and or obscure enemy gimmicks are a detriment, it's the unsatisfying ending and lack of a consistent unravelling mystery or lore that really hurts the experience. But the experience itself is great. It really does build a unique, fun journey; it's just unfortunate that journey didn't have more tangible depth to it beyond the momentary fun encounters.

If you're interested in finding more games like this I've probably reviewed quite a few on my curator page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38950844-Anoemalous/] here [/url].

78921784.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a pixelated horror game where you play as Brian - Your average joe in his first job at Sintra Corp. Through the adventure you encounter horrors, dark secrets, grotesque scenes. Oh, and friendship!

Visual presentation can be a hit or miss being completely pixelated, aside from the text sprites and animated cutscenes. Personally, the artstyle completed the weird and freakish nature of the setting. 

Audio presentation is excellent. Soundtrack is by Garoad which did an amazing job with the VA-11 HALL-A OST.
Sound design and mixing is great (can still feel the keyboard clicking and clacking in my brain).

Gameplay consists of walking around, interacting with items and points of interest, avoiding enemies and solving puzzles. Nothing too groundbreaking, but it's simple and enjoyable enough. There will be points that don't make it clear where you need to go next, or what is needed to progress so don't be ashamed to use a walk-through for that extra helping hand. The game rewards you for paying attention to your surroundings (*cough* especially to co-workers during the party *cough*).

Story and characters are good for the most part. The more you progress, the more you realize that things are terribly wrong with this company. Brian encounters co-workers whom he befriends to an extent, and they each have distinct personalities. However, other than key characters, much of the cast don't get much of a backstory or character progression, though the focus is just following Brian's wacky adventure.

+ Soundtrack by Garoad which is excellent
+ Good sound design and mixing
+ Puzzles not too difficult yet satisfying to solve
+ Neat, creepy, dark atmosphere and story
+ Multiple endings encouraging more playthroughs (plus the DLC area)

- Pixelated artstyle can be hit or miss
- Little to no character backstory and development for some characters
- Can get lost wondering where to go next
- DLC slightly vague to access, but not too terrible

Overall, 7 noodle boxes out of 10 - A nice and solid spooky adventure.

This game is wonderfully creative, bizarre and a total blast. I had so much fun playing this game.

In this game you are given a task and you have to explore the building, each floor has different obstacles and people and much like zelda, certain things are blocked off to you until you unlock the new ability or item. It's hard to describe because there is a lot of variety in game play, but mostly you'll be exploring, finding items, solving puzzles, defeating bosses and uncovering the mystery of the office and why its so gruesome. 

 there are only a few points of the game that I found frustrating, obviously 1 being the old style way of saving ( much like resident evil) you get minimal saves and if you forget to save after a long period of time and then die, it really sucks. The end game also came without warning as well, I finished my task and was going to head to my office to save but I was interrupted on the elevator and in the end game, and because my last save was so far back, I continued on and beat the game, but I really missed some content because of that, and that kind of sucked. I understand the method and reasoning for that style of save system, but honestly I could have done without it, or at least some key autosave spots, that just save the player some time in the event they do forget. If you like horror, you like mystery, you like puzzles buy it. It's so fun, some annoying parts, but overall a great experience that I highly recommend.

I am quite a difficult person when it comes to survival horror, and despite it's simple appearance, don't be fooled, Yuppie Psycho is one of the best horror / adventure game in the indie space in a long time.

78096559.review:
The only thing worse than a bad game, is a good game that prevents you from completing it because it's broken.

Amazingly creative game, fun to play and had fun all the way up until the ending, where after I earned the 'break the curse' achievement, the game glitched. It wasn't frozen, but one of the final scenes wouldn't progress, no matter what. I watched a walkthrough, just to make sure, and nope, my game glitched. For those that have played it, its after one of the hardest parts in the game, which you can't save for about the last 30-60 minutes of progress you have to make.  There is nothing more frustrating than working your way through a game just to be robbed of the ending.  I'm not going back through this to find out if its a one-time bug, i'm done with this game.

Yuppie Psycho has been out in the wild for a year, seems like they would have plenty of opportunities to fix this kind of thing. Oh, and the controllers don't work - I saw the fix on the discussions, but this is bush league - every other game works with my xbox controller - seems like a great game that could've really benefited from some more QA. And yes, I have updated graphics drivers, a RTX 2060 and a core i7-8700k, yet the game is so full of memory leaks, I can't leave it running in the background and come back later (lost a lot of time this way, too). If anyone sees this, or has similar hardware, it's just not worth it. Great potential completely undone by either shoddy helper libraries or just terrible code in general. Not ready for prime time, would not recommend.

77964286.review:
[h1]What [i]is[/i] 'Yuppie Psycho'?[/h1]
[b]A 2d top-down animated pixelated and story rich game, that successfully combines a 90ties office style with a gore-horror theme/atmosphere along with additional traces of hi-tech [i](mainly related to Sintra herself)[/i]. In this game you start as a newbish guy, that gets invited to one of the top cooperation’s for a job offer. This offer includes and prioritized you having to deal with ‘a certain issue’. As the story unfolds you’ll get to deal with bizarre [i](well, I guess ‘bizarre' is subjective... it depends if you’re working in office I guess)[/i] events  and several ‘life threatening issues’ for yourself and potentially your newly made npc-friends.[/b]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]Very good storyline. I especially liked the idea of ‘Sintra’ (persona: calm and professional hostess and corporation representative), which turned out to be either the ‘evil’ OR not @_@... [i](I‘m not going to give away spoilers)[/i]. Either way it was not what I expected.[/b]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]I did however absolutely hate the boss lvls up to the point that it almost made me ‘not recommend’ this game. I acknowledge that they are, just like the game itself, fairly creatively made with unexpected turns and twists. But their strength/speed [spoiler][i](especially the ‘printer’)[/i][/spoiler] when you’re still trying to figure out what to do is just unreasonable bs. Unskippable dialog after failing a boss battle is an issue as well, and I wouldn’t have mind if there was more food, credits and save options either, along with an inventory bar instead of having to go through a menu all the time.[/b]

[h1]Overall[/h1]
[b]Very good storyline, but not recommended for anyone who hates to deal with challenging bosses while playing an RPG-game.[/b]

- [i]I might try again for some of the achievements.[/i] -

77080131.review:
Yuppie Psycho is one of the few games were I debated getting all the endings on my own. Which is a rare thing.
The game gives off a cyberpunk/vaporwave aesthetic while also being a horror game all in one. 

I was pretty much going into this game because the musician Garoad was composing it. Which, for his work, it's the quality I wanted from the guy who made the entire banger of VA-11 HALL-A (a great game as well.)  While the game is good... it has flaws.

UI is a bit confusing, even after 10 hours. Despite the use of several items that can and should be needed at a moments notice, you don't have any hotbar or even any equip button (Not even to 8-bit Zelda level of equipment). This brings in several problems: Example, you you have to disable mines in several parts of the game and need an item to do that. How you disable the mine is to approach near the mine, then open up the menu, select the item, and then use it. You have to do this several times in the game and some have it where you are on a rushing current, about to run into a mine and must be pin-point accurate to do so. It's doable, but messes with the  flow.

Another example is lights. As expected of a horror game, you have to manage a flashlight and batteries in order go through the hellscape of this corporate building. The problem, again, is that you can't dedicate WHICH light you want to use. You can get a flashlight, a lamp, and glow sticks. All of these have some pros and cons, but you can't just select one light and turn it on and off, you have to go through a selection every time to turn it on and off. I mentioned batteries, right? Well the problem is that if your light is on at ALL it will drain the battery, a limited resource. So you have to rotate through your lights to get the right one, sometimes while something very angry and large wants to kill you. This makes it frustrating to manage my resources and could be solved with just simply better UI and control.

The last bash on this is the inventory button. Yes, button. If using a controller, you won't notice this, but on keyboard and mouse, you will. The button for this is 'i', which is on the other side of the keyboard. The game requires both the mouse and the keyboard at all times. Remember the mines? Well imagine using WASD seeing mines, moving your right hand from the mouse to touch i key, then bounce back to the mouse to select the item to destroy the mine. That's what I did for a good hour until I learned I can redo the key to make it 'b' instead of 'i'. Why 
Baroque Decay thought that 'i' by default was a good idea, I would not know.

But beyond the horrible, and clunky UI, is it good?

Yes.

The games story, characters, atmosphere is perfect and I am only sad that there was not enough of it. I missed a ton of secrets and extras in this game, and want to get back and do more of it.... after I retook into better managing this UI.

Buy it at full price with caution, but if this is on sale, get it.

76204836.review:
UPDATED REVIEW: 

After playing this game two more times after the Executive Edition update, I've decided to rescind my "Do Not Recommend" review. Here are the main reasons why:

+ DLC is free, about 3 more hours of content (thanks devs)
+ One of the new endings/routes goes deeper into story and characters, darker even
+ Not only did they add new content, they added bits n' bobs here and there to polish the game overall 

My original problem with the vanilla Yuppie Psycho was that the Endings left a lot to be desired. Lots of issues, things and people were left without proper resolutions or explanations. Any ending you landed on felt like an incomplete story. That's where the new DLC comes in. 

The Executive Edition glams up the current base game and adds extra bits to the original endings. I will say though, it didn't add much and I still felt unsatisfied. Then I played one of the new routes. The achievement is called "Ending: Goodbye" if you're curious. 

Without giving away much, this route goes into a completely different direction from the original existing routes. There weren't really any guides at the time of writing this cause the update is still fresh so it felt really nice going in blind. If you want a spoiler free guide to it, here is the cliff notes version:

[spoiler]
• Help Chapman promote to 3rd floor
• Do the new area, Surveillance Room. Very important item at the end
• Check out Camera Hub 5, interesting scene 
• With said knowledge of interesting scene, go there and take it (it's for that floor)
• Go to the Wash Closet on 5th floor, use Witch Paper on mirror (don't think you need to do this but there is an achievement for it) 
•After all that, you're good to go, just keep going [/spoiler]

Also, make sure you do all that BEFORE entering the Cemetery otherwise you will be locked out. 

I think it's fair to say that in order to get the full experience of Yuppie Psycho: Executive Edition, you need to play the "true" original route first and then play the alternate route. I am very happy with this new DLC update simply because it covered a lot of things and gave a satisfying result with the alternate ending. There was a climax and you didn't really get that in the original endings, or at least, I felt that way. 

But I digress. Yuppie Psycho is good and deserves the praise it gets. Devs did a good job pushing out this FREE update. Personally, I felt like Yuppie Psycho could have used a little more stronger narrative BUT. I think with this new update, instead of leaving things up on the table, it presents you with an open ended scenario(s). And if you spend a little more time digging around for all the endings and items you will find that this game is very satisfying.
76204836.developer_response: DLC is out now for free! More endings and horror for all! Also, please love us.

75790375.review:
I don't normally leave reviews for things, and when i have they're usually pretty short, but i [i] also [/i] didn't expect this to be such a good game, so i figured i would this time.

[h1] What i Loved [/h1]

The puzzles, while initially simple, give you brilliant insights into the world around you. There are some that are almost impossible to complete without scouring through the offices, speaking to different and equally important characters. Although at the start i must have spent about... half an hour doing one puzzle, because i had missed an item that was in plain sight, i was finding the later (and more difficult) puzzles easier as i figured out what was being thrown at me.

Similarly, the bosses (and standard enemies) were delightfully interesting ( [spoiler] though i never expected i'd fight a printer with four hands [/spoiler] ), and it was refreshing to see every enemy have a unique method for dealing with (or escaping from) them. Navigating certain areas to complete a task while enemies search for you, and balancing hiding with running in each area certainly helped live up to the 'horror' tag this game holds, and more often than not i was reminded of classic rpgmaker horrors like Misao, The Witch's House and Mad Father, all games i fell in love with immediately, and Yuppie Psycho easily joined the ranks of them.

The characters were also amazing, with everyone (bar one, but disclosing who spoils things) making me laugh between the different nightmarish tasks. The game is deceptively long, and despite the short amount of tasks you're given in order to 'Kill the Witch', you'll find yourself interacting with your new work friends often in order to figure out the lore and understand where you need to go and what you need to do. Each character, good and bad has entertaining quirks, and by the time the game is over you'll have grown attached to them, leaving you searching for the best ending to help them all.

[h1] What I Didn't Love [/h1]

While, yes, i did adore Yuppie Psycho, there's always a couple criticisms you can give, and this is no different. 

The endings feel.. rushed. Don't get me wrong, the endings themselves are interesting, and being able to get the ending you want is great, but they aren't [b] rewarding [/b]. As long as i'm counting right, there's four proper endings, but they're just... so easy to get. I saved just before the end of the game and managed to get all the endings in about 30 minutes because of it, and it makes me feel like as long as i rush through the first 80% of the game the only bit that matters is the last 20%. I personally think it would be far better to have us make choices to determine the ending throughout the entirety of the game, because while it'll take longer to implement different paths, you'll essentially be quadrupling (if they stick to four main endings) the time people spend to see all the content.

[h1] Do I recommend this? [/h1]

Yes. If you haven't played a game with good story, fun mechanics, and interesting characters for a long time, play Yuppie Psycho.

I must say I was very pleasantly surprised by Yuppie Psycho.

It is a unique blend of horror and humour that works surprisingly well. The puzzles and exploration are very well paced and you are always constantly finding out new things about its world or characters, and that keeps driving you forward all the time.

Also, the presentation is quite on point. The sound design is superb and the visuals have some strikes of brilliance here and there (specially when it comes to animated cutscenes). It never feels cheap or limited and that really makes it stand out amongst other small indie titles.

If you're into horror games and are looking for new approaches in the genre, Yuppie Psycho has you covered.

Yuppie Psycho is really good, and I think a lot of that is owed to how unique it is. While most stories follow a formula or actively shove foreshadowing hints into the player's face, this game does its own thing and isn't beholden to what it makes. Now it's a commentary on toxic workplaces, now it's a surreal Brazil-esque comedy, now it's a cryptic horror with unnerving hidden secrets. It does all this without abandoning anything, and does it in such a creative, fresh way that it really made me want to keep playing and see everything the game can offer.

Going back to that last bit, this is a game that relies on its easter eggs, creating really important, really interesting secrets that caught me off guard and, like a trail of breadcrumbs leading into the dark forest, brought me farther and farther in. After playing through twice I'm still left wanting more, and I look forward to coming back and playing through a third time in the near future.
