74470545.review:
[i]A friend had an unused key from Humble Bundle and offered it to me as a gift.[/i]

This is a fantastic horror game.
Understand, this game doesn't have any cheap jump scares. It has an amazing take on a large corporation, with countless expendable worker cogs working in it, that has become corrupted and twisted by the influence of dark, supernatural forces.

It has interesting puzzles, some stealth bits, lots of secrets that reward exploration and a dark story that is so tense, you'll feel uneasy with every step you take in any new area.

However, it doesn't really have much replayability behind it, because if you know the story and what to expect it obviously won't be scary anymore. Maybe you'll play through a handful of times to get the various endings, achievements or even piece together the lore of Sintracorp, but after that, you're done with it for good.

Despite that, it is certainly a game that you shouldn't pass up, especially if you are a fan of well made horror.
[i](You can also get the key for this game extremely cheap if you look around.)[/i]

74469858.review:
This game was extremely good imo and has a lot of replay value, I'm definitely going to try getting all the endings and achievements.  It really lived up to my expectations, I was super excited to play it after how good Count Lucanor is, and I'd definitely consider this and Count Lucanor two of the best indie games I've ever played.  You'll enjoy this game if you're like me and enjoy horror games that don't require you to be able to shoot/kill monsters etc.  For the most part you're either sneaking or running, which really lends to the tension.  The tension is one of the game's strongest aspects, along with the sound design.  Definitely wear headphones while playing this.  Not only is the music great, but the sound effects are incredibly unsettling, and are sometimes played just for ambience but make you believe there's a monster around.  Despite how cute everyone is, the game's atmosphere is more disturbing than a lot of horror movies I've seen.  The difficulty is at a good level, there were only a few parts that felt a little tedious to have to replay, but for the most part the limited saving and occasionally brutal enemies make the game better and scarier.  Obviously as a weeb I really love the art style, it's very charming, and the character designs as well as their personalities are diverse and likable.  This game gets an A+ for the extremely cute protagonist.  The extra little details the developers put into the game's world make it so much more enjoyable, like the videoclub movies or the detailed paintings in the gallery, which you only see for a little bit.  This game is great at incentivizing you to do stuff, like by collecting different ingredients you can be promised better healing items, or by making sure to check everything you may find one more paper needed for a vital save.  This is unlike, say, Dark Souls, where I collect tons of items I never use.  Pretty much every item has a super valuable use.  The only thing I felt was missing was more answers, the game's story built up so many questions but didn't answer all of them by the end, but maybe that'll be in an ending I didn't get.  As for the story, it's really well written in terms of not seeming obnoxiously unsubtle, but still explores class and the dehumanization of workers in the name of a company's success.  I don't even work in an office and it was incredibly depressing for me.  Anyways, this game's really really good and Baroque Decay makes awesome games.

EDIT 8/12/21

I just finished the DLC (I’m a fake fan for taking so long after it’s release) and I just have to say it fixed any small problems I had with the game and made it so much more amazing.  This game truly is gunning for my favorite game of all time.  I also gotta say that whoever does the art direction is incredible.  Somehow, Baroque Decay is able to make the most graphic, disturbing sprites out of pixels and I love it.    Call me a coward or whatever but I’m amazed that an cartoony indie game freaks me out more than most horror movies (and horror games) I’ve ever seen.  BD I’m begging you, make more games.  Every character in this game has so much personality and charm that I would love to see more content with them too.  I also feel that this game (along with Count Lucanor) really nail that “horror/comedy” vibe you get from stuff like EarthBound.  It’s got so many twists and variables that it’s honestly hard even after several playthroughs to tell when you’ll get threatened/scared.  Often I was pleasantly surprised when, for example, I hide in a closet wondering if I’ll get jumpscared when I turn my light on again, and then I do, but it’s never predictable!  Overall, it's extremely rare for me to find a game that has a story that interests me, is scary, AND has fun gameplay, this is a great find and I really wish there were more horror games in this style.

74008943.review:
An excellent survival horror adventure with a compelling story, lovable cast, fun puzzles, and several tense moments. The horror element ramped up well, and managed to be frequently creepy without resorting to cheap tricks. The story was interesting, and the setting (both the office and the hints about the world at large) were a great treat. The gameplay was enjoyable, though the resource management (batteries, health) felt too generous--I never ran out of anything.

Overall, the game delivers a branching narrative that is fun to fully explore, and it did not overstay its welcome through multiple replays. I went in mostly blind (store blurb, genre, and trailer) and that definitely added to the experience. Go for it!

The free expansion/DLC added several hours of enjoyment and a lot of polish to an already excellent experience. If you were on the fence on this game, I think this firmly tips it over the line into a must-play!

Now that it's out on multiple platforms (and with Steam Deck compatibility), there's even less hurdles to giving this game a go. Remains a big favorite of mine, with several playthroughs between the PC and Switch versions.

73992474.review:
Yuppie Psycho is a pixel-art horror RPG in the vein of old RPG-maker horror games such as Ib, The Mad Father, and The Witch's House.

This game absolutely oozes character; with wonderfully creative environments, excellently manipulated sound design which enhances every part of the experience, a colorful cast of characters, and writing which intrigues and pulls the player along. Yuppie Psycho is very alluring. That said, it does have it's share of shortcomings.

Many elements of the story feel glossed over. Many questions are left unanswered. Characters are left underdeveloped. Environments are hinted at but left unexplored. The conclusion to the mystery just drops into the players lap in the end, which is very unrewarding. And all of the endings are mostly the same, leaving the player to feel like they have no agency; admittedly, that may be intentional, as it fits thematically with the player being a powerless office worker.

And yet despite all that, Yuppie Psycho is still a strong recommendation; I only make such criticisms because I loved the game, and because Id love to see more of it. But in the end, its still an experience I would recommend, especially for anyone who is searching for a unique experience or who is a fan of horror or mystery games.

73990866.review:
I am a fan of their previous game, Count Lucanor and had to give it a try. 
I enjoyed it, though the story didn't capture me as much as the story of Count Lucanor --- the "Tapes" of this game were very eerie. The sound design of this game , especially the "whispers" and "attacks" were top-notch. 

I enjoy how the game plays on the myth of "The Witch". Like in many other novels, people don't find "Witches" scary until you realize the fundamental questions: What is the limit of their power? What can they or cannot do? How do I defend myself? Where do I hide? Who is this witch? 

There is a lot of madness in this game and I enjoyed that, and uncovering the mystery even if it wasn't as rewarding as "Count Lucanor"'s mystery.

Wonderful horror game that discusses modern wage slavery and the power struggles within corporate hierarchies. I love its take on the office space. Extremely unique in its depiction of body horror and work space terror. The total freedom of movement it allows is very welcome for the genre, and allows for interesting re-exploration which keeps progression worth while. The save system is fantastic, and is a gameplay and story mechanic. Only other game I've seen do this is Lisa: The Painful with it's hardest difficulty. 

Only major complaint is that there are two floors and an event completely ignored or glossed over (floor 6, security floor, and the union workers trying to overthrow the company). I would love to see more done with these areas/people. Although, the game is still very complete in its current state. The ending is a little abrupt especially with its resolution. The alternative endings don't directly influence this moment, yet there are some cool secret endings with the remaining characters. I'd say there is about an hour or two missing from making this game near perfect with it's design and execution. It's definitely worth picking up.

72969301.review:
I received this on Humble Bundle and figured I'd try it out. Game quickly sucked me in with a very interesting story and secrets galore.

The story and "lore" is hands down one of the best parts of this game. I loved trying to piece together the history of this cursed Sintracorp and trying to make the conflicting information seemingly everyone is giving you make sense. The game gives you just enough hints that if you're paying attention to the small, seemingly random, details, you can figure out some twists in advance. Even at the end, however, it doesn't give you everything, and some questions are left unanswered or vague after the credits roll.  Horror is played very well here, with the terror derived from gore and nightmare rather than jumpscares. The characters are rather flat, sadly. They are extremely memorable, and you won't run into anyone and be like "who are they again" but they do not have a lot of depth, though that could be attributed to the place being cursed.

The combat and health system is simple. Some enemies, such as mines, can be disabled using tools, while all other enemies need to be avoided via running away or hiding in cabinets or under tables. The horror is somewhat offset, however, by the overabundance of healing items. If you are paying attention, you will be drowning in coffee and candy bars, meaning any hit can be quickly recovered. If you are looking for deep combat, probably not for you.

The puzzles jump between too easy and point-and-click obtuse. Don't feel too bad if you get completely stuck and need to look up a guide, I did for a couple parts. The bosses are also puzzle based, and they're pretty good, though I definitely going to remember one of the bosses more than the other.

[strike] The alternate endings are mostly just bad ends, with the few that aren't just being minor variations or alternate ending cutscenes. Felt a bit lacking, as I was hoping for some more meaningful choices regarding the ending. [/strike]

Edit: So, they released a new, free, content drop that adds an alternate route with multiple new endings with awesome new lore insights and a creepy new area. I rescind my complaints on lack of endings, exactly what I was looking for!

TLDR: Super cool story, mostly interesting puzzles, [strike] lackluster ending/s [/strike] . Can be completed in a couple hours if not achievement hunting.

72833516.review:
I got the game like 14 hours ago and then proceeded to log 12+ hours in it.

This game is really well done for what it's trying to do and the atmosphere sucked me in. Immersion with headphones and few distractions really gets your blood flowing since the overall design keeps you on edge, and the progression was done well. The game gives you a limited number of resources that you need to manage as you go throughout it and, if you're someone like me, you'll probably end the game with way too many since you opt to almost never use them.

One of the mechanics is light management through use of batteries in a flashlight. I don't think I used more than maybe two batteries in my entire playthrough because of how extremely thrifty I was on its usage, but it also would be much more enjoyable probably to not be so extremely thrifty with the resources you're given. But that's what's great about it too in that you're aware that resources are limited and it really does feel like you need to manage your lifeline as you go through the game (Even if I went through extreme overkill on that front).

The ending felt a bit lackluster to me, but then again I feel like that's the case for most games like this. The build-up and experience add up to a lot more than the conclusion for me. I don't know how to explain it without spoiling anything, but I just feel like it's cut a bit short. None of that changed my overall positive outlook on the game and great experience I had, however.

I will mention that I had to restart the game one time while doing my first regular playthrough due to some memory leak or something causing the game to start to lag, but it didn't negatively impact my experience at all. I also toward the end of achievement hunting discovered that the game is quite poorly coded and my mashing A seemed to have caused another memory leak that needed a restart to fix. Besides those two situations, however, everything worked pretty smoothly despite a couple pathing errors on AI.

The game was a wonderful binge and I highly recommend you play it in a well-lit room during the day if you're a wimp like me.

There were many genuinely unnerving parts in this game. Highly recommend. If you were a fan of Corpse Party, I would DEFINITELY play this.

72820217.review:
[h1] Overview [/h1]
Yuppie Psycho is an interesting Horror- Adventure game set in a world where mega corporations have taken over, or at least Sintracorp. (where the story takes place at) has. The outside world isn’t talked about much, but the lore behind it when it is spoken about is super interesting. You take control of Brain, who has received a mysterious letter to come work at Sintracorp and improve his social status, make an absurd amount of money per day, and other unbelievable benefits. However, things quickly take a turn for the weird and it is up to you to uncover the secrets of Sintracorp. and make it out. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
The story is a mixed bag for me as part of it is told and supported through the environments and gameplay. Initially, I was incredibly enthralled with the lore and story. The side characters are pretty normal yet really weird and the generic workers are these grey, lifeless husks shambling around and working. (The commentary on big corporations isn’t terrible subtle here.) 

In terms of gameplay as a support, you can initially explore every floor in a limited capacity and get used to the map and building layout. You can even get some important items early on if you’re a hoarder or a compulsive clicker/ checker. 

Gameplay also factors into this as the puzzles help reveal the workspace of Sintracorp. You have to explore the oppressive darkness of the corporate archives, solve the puzzles meant to deter truth seekers, and avoid the various mutated/ corrupted workers. The fate of the previous seekers is also awaiting you.

The basics of the story are that you arrive at your first day of work under mysterious circumstances and sign an obvious pact with the devil in exchange for your position at Sintracorp. Your job: kill the witch. While Brian has doubts about real witches, her vile magic is clearly evident within Sintracorp. You’ll eventually meet your co-workers and explore the various floors of Sintracorp as you get closer to the truth while dodging the various horrors that lurk within. At the time of writing, I only have a few endings completed and will go back at a later date for the others as I feel burnt out on the game currently. From what I have seen, they are interesting, but I still had lingering questions about certain characters and their motivation/ history at the endings I DID get to. I won’t go into detail as this is the main seeing point of the game, at least for me. Just know that while things are super vague during the main story, the endings don’t really offer any detailed payoff/ elaboration. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
In terms of gameplay, Yuppie Psycho is a 2.5-D adventure game. You mostly run around the building, talking to people, finding clues and solving puzzles. There is quite a bit of reading to be done so I don’t recommend this game to anyone who was expecting a more action-oriented game although there are some quite tense chases/ encounters. Puzzles can range from “use item X on object Y to proceed” to more involved ones such as directing a monster into a certain direction by using certain switches. I honestly feel that certain puzzles needed more feedback on whether or not the player is doing something right or progressing. I was stuck at a few because I knew I had the solution in my hands, but just didn’t know how to use it due to the limited clues/ feedback. 

Yuppie Psycho goes for a save system like early Resident Evil’s- namely, you have limited save items. Personally, I don’t like them as I felt inclined to save very regularly since save points are VERY spaced out. Although, in retrospect, certain segments are very easy/ short, when I first encountered them, I was super nervous about having to reload a save halfway across the map and having to redo all the item collecting, triggers, etc. Additionally, dying means you also have to listen to the same dialogue all over again. There isn’t a skip function, so I ended up having to mash through dozens of text boxes just to get back to the puzzle/enemy that killed me. This eventually made the game less scary and more tedious/ annoying which ruined my immersion in the game’s visual and audio storytelling.

There is also a health system where you can eat/ drink food items to recover health and craft better haling items by using the right ingredients OR buy items form vending machines. I liked it and it felt fitting. 

[h1] Sound Design [/h1]
The music and sound design are great. The parts that focus more on horror nail it with oppressive, spooky ambient noises and some unsettling whispering sometimes. I should mention that there are a few cheap jumpscares that made me flinch due to just being a loud noise with moderately or mildly creepy imagery on screen. The monsters sound appropriately unsettling. 

Musical tracks are pretty good, but I honestly can’t remember any off the top of my head as I was preoccupied with the story/ atmosphere. 

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
This game uses a pixelated art style to convey its story. I honestly think it looks great, although some designs get muddled due to the pixilation. For example, Brain wears glasses but his character sprite doesn’t have any. The animated cutscenes, while elusive, were fantastic at showing emotion and movement. They were also rendered at a good/ consistent framerate to boot. I honestly wish there were more of them at key moments in the story.

[h1] Miscellaneous [/h1]
Performance wise, I had no real issues to mention. Controls were okay as well since you can rebind the keys from the main menu. There is controller support, but I didn’t touch it in my playthroughs.As a Horror game, I thought that the beginning and ending parts were great and I was on edge. The middle kinda dragged on in favor of plot/ exposition and I felt that it was "spoopy" at best.

[h1] Closing [/h1]
If you like linear, story-focused, horror-based games, I’d definitely recommend Yuppie Psycho. However, just be aware that there are some archaic gameplay systems at work and that while the story is interesting, it doesn’t ever really directly explain or elaborate some of the bigger plot points. While puzzles are overall pretty simple, some solutions just aren't apparent on a first playthrough. 

Overall- 7.5/ 10
Worth getting, but only on sale if you’re wary.

I loved the style, the setting, the characters. But above all, I loved the increasing creepiness as I progressed. While it wasn't outright terrifying, there were plenty of startling moments and some pretty freakin scary monsters. 72814671.review:
This is what happens when you mix Dilbert with The Evil Dead, Fantozzi and Junji Ito in a magical cauldron - Yuppie Psycho, a monstrous prodigy that boasts a unique bureaucratic witchcult setting! Baroque Decay (what a fitting name) managed to strike the balance between horror and comedy perfectly by making them play off of each other like a couple of great actors. Which is an unexpected feat, usually people just ruin both. Despite all the webpunk\vaporwave aesthetic and a protagonist called Pasternak, this game doesn't come off as pretentious. One has to be genuinely clever to be able to carry out all of the above with such pazzazz.

To me, the game seemed pretty basic at first sight, but soon turned out to be endlessly amusing, delivering a package full of savage satire, Lynchean surrealism, the occult, clever social commentary, and tense predicaments. I got lucky enough to go in blind and was utterly captivated by everything that transpired from start to finish. Respectively, I don't want to spoil it for anyone else, so all I can add is that it's challenging (at least it used to be, I'm not so sure about the new edition), the puzzles are great, and the pacing is on point for a horror adventure. Even after beating it, you'd still be asking "what is this game?" while still nodding to the banging OST.

P.S. One of the locations is an art gallery that features Suguru Tanaka's drawings. And the game uses his designs to the full extent. Check the artist out, his works are pure masterpieces!

Yuppie Psycho is a traditional survival horror game with an inspired aesthetic and charming dialogue. The plot is a coming of age story about a kid who's first job is at a haunted office building. 

The aesthetic is opulent, near the end of the game there's a sequence in an art gallery where every single painting can be examined in detail. The care put into rendering this world is inspiring.

Our protagonist is a kid trying to figure out who he wants to be while caught up in a chaotic world that he doesn't understand. In this way the game is like a horror adaptation of 'alice in wonderland'.

The game is engaging, but it relies on 1-off set pieces rather than developed systems to keep the audiences attention.

72495511.review:
[h1] Worth full price, dive into this one spoiler-free![/h1]
I got this as part of the July Humble Bundle, but having finally finished it today (all endings), I would have been happy to buy this straight from Steam at RRP.

You are Brian Pasternack, and you've received a letter with a job offer from the most prestigious megacorporation in the country, Sintracorp.
It's a dream job! Of the thousands of applicants a [i]day[/i] that apply, only a few get in.. but you've only just finished your basic studies. How did you get through the cracks? Why are you here?
More importantly: [i]what is your job?[/i]

[b]The Good[/b]
[list]
[*]Early 90's aesthetic is on-point, bordering on a late 80's vibe with a very post-IBM era of technology bringing some ground to the setting.

[*]Sound design (OST/SFX/limited VA) is great at complimenting the atmosphere during times it's needed the most.

[*]Controls are tight, and the game thankfully pauses when you open your inventory. The "point and click" aspect of the game is very limited as it's not the core focus here.

[*]The story is the type to keep you guessing 'til the end, with small nuggets of information acting as the carrot on the stick to see it 'til its end. The payoff can be confusing at first, even a bit disheartening, but don't worry -[i] your friends are there for you.[/i]
[/list]

[b]The Mixed[/b]
[list]
[*]Jarring sound bugs, but not common enough to destroy the experience. Certain SFX and ambient tracks had a tendency to overlap or persist until a game restart or area change (ie. Office D's coffee machine).

[*]Some NPC pathing issues (getting stuck on environment details).
[/list]

[b]The Bad[/b]
[list]
[*]Anti-Backtracking/Completion design. At two particular points in your exploration, there are two rooms you want to regain access to later to aid in full completion and getting the bigger picture of the story. Unfortunately on one of them, the developers thought it was "absolutely hilarious" to blockade the player by requiring you to know that you have to reset the entryway's barrier to allow access into it after you're done for the story beat. Spoiler: it's not funny to have to restart whole sections to rectify mistakes you can't reasonably have known to avoid. :C
[/list]

72259383.review:
I love Yuppie Psycho. It's a great game with one huge caveat, at least on Mac. (I should try it on my Linux machine more.) The game has strong survival horror elements and uses them perfectly. Part of that is that saving is not trivial. There are limited opportunities to save, so that each time you CAN save, you ask yourself, "Do I really want to save now or keep going and bank my saving ability for later?" Again, this is great in terms of gameplay. It makes the stakes higher. The problem is that the game crashes quite a bit. Sometimes, after 20 or 30 minutes after a save point, the game just vanishes from my screen. That's a problem. If I could save all the time, I would, but then, it would not be the same game.

The game itself is fantastic. It's a survival horror satire that has an interface like Zelda: A Link to the Past but that plays more like a point and click adventure game. The player character, Brian, is never armed and mostly collects objects, figures out when to use them and interacts with NPCs. In a more action-oriented way, he does, however, need to avoid a lot of enemies who all want him dead for some reason and he needs to collect health boosters in order to survive. The game really is a witty comment on work-life balance, how large companies are structured, office politics, hypocrisy in the corporate world and many other similar themes without ever mentioning them directly and certainly without ever being preachy about it.

It works with a keyboard, but I'd strongly recommend using a controller for it, even on a computer. The writing and storytelling are extremely good. The plot manages to be surprising. The mystery is really tantalizing. Clues are dropped all the time, but you never know enough to really know what's going to happen, and the player character is not an idiot: when he's placed in a dangerous situation, he always decides to leave, but an external cause forces him to stay. He's not a gratuitous hero who wants to "fight evil" for whatever reason. On the contrary, he mostly wants to just get out of there, but it's tricky: working at that company is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for him. He has a shaky sense of self-esteem at best and all of that makes him and his relation to other character feel relatable.

If the game just didn't crash, it would be almost perfect.

After the first hour: 

This is a horror game, I don’t like horror games. Except for Resident Evil, I don’t even like scary games, so I don’t like Yuppie Psycho, I might not be the right person to listen to on this one. 

Yuppie Psycho tries entirely too hard to make you uneasy throughout the game and I think it works after a bit. The first ten minutes feels out of place, the writing is weak but gets far better after that strange opening. This is a creepy freaking game, and I thought about what I would show but… I kind of have to show the disturbing parts because that is a major part of this game. I’d be lying otherwise. 

I do want to say the art though is solid, the game is good in every way it should be but it’s just a genre and a style I have absolutely no interest in playing. I feel bad because I want to play more but I also don’t.

As I said, this is a horror game, not survival horror, not action, but a horror RPG for the most part. I think you already know if you like this one but this is mostly going to appeal to the horror niche and anyone who doesn’t like scary games, will want to skip this. 

Quick related question, how many dead bodies would you have to see on the first day of work to excuse yourself and leave immediately? I think my number would be one, and I might even leave if there’s a serious injury. Maybe the main character is a psycho.

71586890.review:
Another great love letter to RPGMaker horror games from Baroque Decay. Pretty much everything is excellent; the story, characters, art, music, and gameplay were all very enjoyable. This game has a great sense of humor as well, with plenty of the satire that you'd expect from the game's office-working premise. I could sing this game's praises in many walls of text, but I think it's better to just say that this is a top tier game that I think everyone could enjoy. My only real complaints are as follows:

1. Obscure, nonsensical requirements for some of the secrets. This one confused me, because the previous game Count Lucanor was so good at avoiding this kind of bullshit design that punishes players for nothing. The worst example is that you can (and likely will) block off an entire area for yourself to revisit later if you do not UNDO a puzzle on your first visit. There is no indication to do anything like this, but if you don't then you lock yourself out of one of the game's collectibles.

2. Underwhelming ending. Thankfully, this one has some room to be improved with the upcoming DLC, but as it stands now the ending just didn't feel like it did enough to match all of the great build up that occurred over the course of the game.

These issues aside, this game was a fantastic and unique experience. I look forward to more from Baroque Decay in the future.

71512061.review: Awesome comedy/horror adventure game.  Took me back to my days playing KQ2 and Gold Rush on my Apple IIGS.

71503812.review:
An incredible indie horror game and a very unique experience!

• Crafted with lots of love, Yuppie Psycho oozes personality from every pore. Baroque Decay accomplishes a tremendous amount with the stripped back pixel style and develops an eye-popping world where almost everything and everyone around you can be interacted with in interesting ways throughout the game. Games like this (indie, horror, and horror adjacent) tend to suffer from lots of 'dead space', environments completely devoid of substance, full of NPCs with stale one-liners and objects with mechanical descriptions and boring uses, whilst this gem challenges you to to think and remember and rewards you with an incredible amount of delightful content to uncover:

• Yuppie Psycho has an absurd amount of fun content for those who enjoy looking around every corner and checking under every rock, whether you're after lore or are an achievement hunter it is unlikely you will find everything on your first playthrough, not because of convoluted mechanics or impossible puzzles, but simply due to the sheer amount of world and amount of items you can play around with.

• If I had to really break out the magnifying glass to find a complaint I'd have to say most of the endings, while not bad or unenjoyable, feel less fleshed out and satisfying than the bulk of the game, like a boring final loop in an otherwise heart-pounding rollercoaster.

• The OST is good, the graphics are good, the story is good, the gameplay is good. It's a game more than worth it's ticket price and can absolutely not be ignored if on sale.

9/10

71437128.review:
[b]Executive Edition update[/b]
It's still a good game, but the flaws still drag it down. You'll almost certainly need a walkthrough, as some puzzles are hard or confusing. There are still points-of-no-return and it's incredibly easy to miss things. The story has now got even more loose ends, yet minimal character development. I did enjoy playing, but every time I had to look at a walkthrough or steam discussion it killed the tension. I still don't like the limited save system, but thanks to previous experience I was able to avoid losing significant progress this time.

[b]Original review[/b]
The game is often enjoyable, but there are too many negatives. The characters and some parts of the game are quite good though.

1: The saving mechanic made me lose a lot of progress several times. Some areas should have a save point or autosave that don't.
2: Some areas of the game are incredibly frustrating, either because they are hard to navigate or have a frustrating puzzle. One puzzle has an item mysteriously appear in the inventory and gives no hint that it is there.
3: There is a point-of-no-return without a warning. Because of it there are many missable items. This can also block the best ending.
4: The story is full of plot holes and loose ends. It gives you scraps of information, but never explains anything.
5: Some people claim they got stuck after running out of some items. Seems very likely, but never happened to me.

I could probably recommend it on sale if the save mechanic didn't require items and there were a few extra save points or autosaves in certain areas. A section at the very end of the game was exceptionally painful.

70646798.review:
Amazingly good game.  What makes it unique is that you're up against ... something ... that is obviously cruel and dangerous, and that is toying with you.  But you don't know quite what this enemy is.  You don't know how to beat it.  The NPCs all act just a little *off*, and you don't know why.  You just try to survive while trying to learn enough to make sense of what's going on.  Survival isn't that difficult - you generally have a good idea how to survive the current incarnation of the "threat."  But big picture, you feel lost and confused.

That's perfect!  This is one of the few horror games that really understands that in order to make the player feel uneasy, you have to put them in a situation where they feel like they don't fully grasp what's happening or what to do.

Beautiful game.

70476510.review:
I'll start with the good: the story is charming and the price is right for the amount of game time you'll get. I was waffling between recommend and not until I realized the list of bad is much longer than the good for Yuppie Psycho.

I was enjoying the game without a guide until I ran into my first real situation where I just plain had no idea what I was supposed to do. I won't give spoilers, but I'll just say a lot of the things you'll need to do are not intuitive in the slightest, and you'll most likely resort to breaking your immersion and flow for the sake of not wandering in circles wasting precious resources trying to figure things out.

A certain point of no return event in the game ups the ante on this requirement tenfold. You can absolutely reach a fail state, in which you have no light sources left and just plain can't progress, and would likely have to start over or at least many saves back to be more resourceful. I tend to like mechanics like this, since after all it is a survival horror game, but in the meta of 2020s gaming it's very rare for a non "souls like" game to stay true to this more punishing style of gameplay.

I also want to say that the turning point in the story includes an incredibly frustrating mechanic that had me very close to putting the game down forever. You're punished many times throughout the game for just not knowing how to deal with new enemies, and it just wasn't so much scary as it was tedious to be punished by the game and not know why. I just realized I wasn't having fun, and I wasn't attached enough to the story to keep going. I came back a while later and decided to give it another shot, and wound up completing the game in that same session.

Overall, I want to recommend the game because I'm a die hard survival horror fan and this one isn't "bad" but I just can't in good faith give it a thumbs up because it really isn't "good" either. If you're running out of survival horror games to play in this dying genre, then sure, pick this one up. Otherwise, go play something fun instead.

One last thing: if you're an achievement hunter, definitely don't bother. It seems all the achievements are broken at the time of this event. I got every ending and have 0% achievements unlocked.

It is definitely a challenging game, however, since there are finite resources (food/witch papers) so it is also a strategy game when it comes to staying alive. It does crash pretty frequently for me, however which is frustrating. That may just be my system though.

I finished this game last year, but only came around to writing a review now...

I really loved this game. I love the theme, I love the sheer creativity of all the places you visit inside the building, and specially the creature design. I won't spoil that here, but they're brilliant.

Then there's the cinema, the VHS tapes, the cute character portraits and the bizarre people you'll meet on your new job. Everything is top notch.

And, as much as I like all of that, it's a small detail that really got me: the fact that SintraCorp's founder is names João Sintra. Any brazillian (like me!) knows a João. It's a very common name in Brazil (and in Portugal too, I suppose), and I had never seen a João in any game at all before. Not even Brazilian games.

Heck, I can count the number of Brazilian characters I've seen out of fighting games in one hand, and I've been playing games since I was 5 (31 now).

I thought this was really cool. And hey, maybe João Sintra is Portuguese, and not Brazilian, but I think the point still stands. On top of the game being great, I got to see a character with a Brazilian name in a game, and that's pretty rare.

68595064.review:
[h1]A Loveletter to RPGMaker Horror Games...[/h1]
Or at least, the ones from the early 2010s.

Recall games such as The Witch's House, Mad Father, Ib, Ao Oni, The Crooked Man, and Misao. Now imagine a game like that, except it's not made in RPGMaker, and you'd get a pretty good idea of what Yuppie Psycho is.

Although it doesn't include a massive amount of endings or deaths like those games, it does feature great sound design, and an interestingly trippy narrative, survival horror elements (healing items+crafting), and a couple secrets and collectibles here and there.

Pick it up if you recognized any of the names I listed, as it has a similar feel, at least to me.

For me, Yuppie Psycho was near-perfect for the first 90% of my playthrough. The gameplay was strong; the characters were great and likable. But the last 10% was very weak. Unfortunately, it's a crucial 10% as it's the conclusion to what the game was building up towards. To summarize this without spoilers, I felt the game does not wrap itself up that nicely, in both gameplay and story.

Maybe I missed something along the way, but here's some spoilers of what I felt was weak:
[spoiler]
1. I did not understand the significance of the art gallery. It felt like it was just there to shock the player, but had no real meaning.
2. I couldn't find any in-game lore that provided some idea of the motivations, powers etc. of the Witch. This makes the Witch seem kind of hollow. It also leaves the last couple of cutscenes unexplained. (Ex. Body swapping?)
3. I really think there should be an oxygen meter and a save point somewhere in the water level. The player is kind of thrown into the deep end quite quickly.
4. Marshall's existence is puzzling. There doesn't seem to be any significance other than helping Brian out in 1 particular scene.
5. There definitely seems to be more to Doshi than what's presented. He has quite the unexpected crucial role towards the end. But there doesn't seem to be any opportunity to find out more about him.[/spoiler]

In the end, I'd still give a recommendation for how well everything else was done.

66695762.review:
in terms of art, this game has everything. sound design, visuals, and the world are all done beautifully. dialogue is quirky and fun (but needs to be proofread. please. i'm begging you.)

outside of an aesthetic experience however, yuppie psycho falls flat on its face... and i wish i didn't have to say that.

i actually loved playing this game. the puzzles weren't at all obtuse or abstract. at many points i felt extremely rewarded for figuring out what to do with the clues the game gave me. however, these puzzles are interrupted by the most annoying bosses i have ever come across. on paper, their strategies don't sound too hard or complicated. however, keep in mind that because this game is primarily a puzzle game, you don't have ANY "attack" options. all boss fights are long, tedious, and feel extremely luck based because they all involve defending yourself by *running away*. running and hiding are your only two options when dealing with bosses until you get the opportunity to use whatever stage hazard there is against them. and don't get me started on the fact that during boss encounters, the game still punishes you even further by *still having them set in darkly lit places*. give me multiple options to take out a boss, or make it less painful. this isn't "difficult", this is ridiculous. if you want an example of this, please look up the 'cursed child' boss fight. it is horrible. absolutely horrible. i couldn't believe what i was being forced to do. 

i mentioned earlier that yuppie psycho's dialogue was one of the things i really enjoyed about it, and i still hold on that notion. the cast felt alive and great thanks to a snappy and punchy script. unfortunately, this then begs the question -- is yuppie psycho's *plot* just as entertaining? no. no it is not. it's not even boring -- it's just a waste of time.

yuppie psycho starts out with the impression that this is going to be a sarcastic game parodying toxic corporation culture, and while the symbolism remains consistent throughout the whole game, it suddenly devolves into trying to actually *tell a grounded story, trying to explain all the supernatural things happening in the company*. 

throughout the game, brian reacts to seeing dead bodies in a "this is gross... but i wonder what's happening?" sort of unrealistic way -- and it was great! i think this was most likely a reference to the fact that this game is dependent on a resource system, and they couldn't just have the main character rummage through corpse's pockets without some sort of reaction, so they make sure to let the audience know that he is definitely seeing the weird shit happening, but that he just doesn't really care (other than finding out the mystery of *what happened* in the first place). they play it straight throughout the whole game! there are literally dead corpses on the floor, poison gas permeating throughout one of the floors, horseshit simply being left in one of the meeting rooms, etc., and no one (other than brian) reacts. it's a sarcastic tone that wraps itself around one big joke -- if corporations could brainwash their employees to not notice such horrible conditions, they probably would. it was a great experience to see just how disgusting the working conditions were in one area before realizing that it just got worse off in the next.

whispers of the witch go around the work place. is she a friend of the employees, or a foe? is she on the top-dogs side, or are they afraid of her? whatever it is, get to work! the weirdness of the witch myth was a fantastic element of paranoia, because although no NPC could clearly tell you what her goal was other than 'taking over the company', the player themselves always felt scared of her presence.

but then... but...then...? 
there's an...actual story?
huh? did i miss something?

so this entire time you were doing a parody story which was working out great, being abstract...
now suddenly there's lore to the sintra family? there's *actual* magic bullshit? and by the way, none of this backstory has anything to do with the commentary on corporations, workplace culture, how employees react to oppression...nothing. just like the parody, *this* lore shit is *also* played straight -- WHY? what was the point? why did you suddenly ground me in reality? oh, and i should mention, none of the lore is at all interesting. tl;dr revenge shenanigans without any logic behind motivation.

finally, there's the controversial save function. first of all, limited saves aren't inherently an issue, as long as the game allows you to create an infinite copy of them. 
...wait, isn't that an oxymoron?
no. let me explain.

in yuppie psycho, saves are created by using photocopiers found throughout the company building. to save, you MUST have a copy of witch paper.  in this game, there are limited resources -- and that extends to cheese.
why is cheese important? well, a character near the midpoint will exchange you one cheese for one piece of witch paper. this is the ONLY way to get witch paper other than progressing forward in the game.
in a game with *only one kind of hazard you can remove* with all the others *eternally remaining where they are* because you can't attack, you are going to be taking a lot of damage. foodstuffs replenish your health.
now you must make a decision. save cheese for good health recipes, or use it to exchange witch paper?
well, of course, you should save it for witch paper, you say! ...but, oh no! i'm taking too much damage by trying to tank enemies in a certain portion! i ended up dying because i didn't want to waste my 2 witch papers! oh my god, i lost hours of gameplay!

remember how earlier i said that boss fights were annoying because there was only *one* way to "fight" them (as in waiting for a gimmick that takes too long and feels like it's reliant on luck)? all the developers had to do was make respawning enemies on one floor --> brian can attack them --> they drop money --> now you can safely buy candy bars or cups of coffee from the vending machines. lower the health regen on candy bars and coffee so it *truly* feels like this is a last resort. punish the player *effectively*, not just for no reason. "you weren't careful. i know you're saving the cheese to stock up on saves, but then you won't have any health regen items. you'll have to GRIND, and yes, as long as you can get enough money you'll always have health items, but *GRINDING* in itself in a game where you *want* to explore and see new areas / puzzles is an EXTREMELY effective punishment. 

why the hell are there so many vending machines anyways? you have to stock up on batteries for your flashlight, which is arguably the most important item in the game. the only way to get rid of one type of enemy, the floor bombs, is pencils, which you can also stock up on in the store. don't forget those cardboard boxes that are sold too. and those little shrines that cost money. in the end, you are probably going to purchase one coffee in the entirety of the game.

yuppie psycho has a fantastic sense of style. if you just absolutely have to play pixel horror puzzle games, give it a shot. just don't expect to have any fun with it outside of being impressed with the aesthetics of it. a plot that makes you feel bad for getting hyped/invested in it, tedious bosses, horrible boss gimmicks, and a save system that goes against the player (that could've been creatively implemented!) all completely ruin the experience of this game.

66315621.review:
Yuppie Psycho is an inspiringly robust and pretty unique production (adventure-horror?) from a very small team that maintains a certain level of intrigue even throughout the explanation of most of the game's events and backstory, and manages to be more entertaining than frustrating but [i]boy[/i] is it frustrating at times. And buggy.

My first experience with the game is that the animated cutscenes won't play unless replaced with the static cutscene option, but this doesn't resolve the issue of the hidden VHS's you collect also not being visible when played. I got repeatedly caught on and killed by enemies that do ridiculous amounts of damage in an extensive maze area right after doing a handful of optional side objectives, leading to replaying the same 20-40 minute stretch about [i]five times.[/i] Then I lost a half-hour of progress because I turned the corner in a hallway and happened to be instantly blindsided by a new enemy that one-shots you. The first time I got to the final area, it bugged out such that I couldn't progress. And the [i]reason[/i] I lost so much progress, over and over again, is because you're only afforded a limited quantity of save items (ala ink ribbons) which you ALSO need to hoard a backup supply of to afford mandatory plot progression triggers. All in all, a decidedly grating confluence of factors.

That said... still recommend it. Don't want to spoil it. Protip: save your cheese slices.

66082044.review:
The game screams the phrase "fearing the unknown", and has really interesting mechanics that shake up the decision-making in your gameplay. 
The ability to save is one of the more important currencies. You get a consumable item that let's you save at certain points in the game, but you also can/have to use those same items to get key items that let you progress throughout the game. Do you save and play safe, or take the risk and go in hard?

You really, REALLY have to play this game [b]BLIND[/b] in order to really experience how nerve-wrecking both the horror story, and the survival/management aspects of this game can be to you..

However, sometimes it's hard and maybe frustrating just because you missed a small hint that's essential to know to proceed in the next part of the game. It's yimes like this it can be really tempting to look up a walkthrough, but don't do it! Take a break, or even better, put down the game for the day. The game isn't fun when you're spoiled on information that you're supposed to be frightened without.

I've been breaking a cold sweat throughout my first run and I've hit a softlock due to [spoiler]poorly managing my food supplies. I'm getting the conseqences of my actions only right as I hit a point of no return in this story[/spoiler]. I might need to restart essentially my entire playthrough (and I probably will the day after writing this review), but now that I know what to do I might do better.

If you can get this game on a sale, I'd deeply recommend it.

64850278.review:
TL;DR: 7/10, Would definitely recommend if you like a tense, white-knuckle experience dripping with atmosphere. Would NOT recommend if you dislike gore or bodily fluids, even pixelized.

This game deserves better than a 7/10. But I personally experienced a number of crashes that made me drop it that extra point, as well as some deaths that I felt were truly unfair (as in, "full health to dead in under 3 seconds, while stunlocked" unfair). It's a damn good horror title, dripping with atmosphere and the experience of going from "OHGODWHATWASTHAT" to "ordinary, flourescent lit office building" again and again was a wonderful example of tonal whiplash working in favor of a game that left me on edge and disquieted for almost the entire run. It's not without it's flaws, however. The game is fond of smacking the player around with little or no warning- while most enemies will give some kind of warning before attacking, that warning can be easy to miss if you're, say, running for your life with the music up all the way. BAM, you lost some health. And health items, while not super hard to get, don't heal for much, and there's no way to get a free heal that i found. Also, I personally found myself dying several times by getting a HAIR too close to something. No warning, back to the last save. Hope it was pretty recent! It got very irritating. Also, like I mentioned at the top, I crashed 4, 5 times. Might just be my computer, but that too was very trying. AS far as the story goes, (and I'll do my best to avoid spoilers), I only have 3 little problems with it. 1) The witch's accomplice is obvious from almost the word go. 2) The start of the climax hinges on the main character drinking something that he DAMN well should have known not to, after all that he's seen by the time that scene happens. 3) The climax and the ending happen a little too quick, pacing wise. It felt like the game had another hour or so of content before it was ready for things to come to a head. One minute, you're dodging horrors and poison gas, the next, climax, then it's at the endgame, which is very much a "one final mission" kind of deal, with the only side mission involving finding 6 characters scattered around the (Much more dangerous) game. There was also a few times when I honestly had no idea what I needed to do, and jsut had to brute force a solution. Not that I wanted the answers laid out for me, but enough direction that I didn't have to randomly guess as to the solution would have been nice.
Look at all the crap I'm giving this game, and I freakign really enjoyed it! Contructive criticism, I promise. This game is well worth it's asking price, It's got multiple endings, great pixel graphics, and the cutscenes are really well done. Buy it, enjoy it, share it with others cause it deserves it. Just be ready for a little frustration mixed in with all the terror and genuinely heartwarming moments this game has to offer.

63831701.review:
This game starts promising in a weird, Kafka-esque way, but it very quickly devolves into trial and error, which leads to repetition. There are tons of random ways in which you can lose health in this game without the game communicating the danger to you clearly, and even if the danger is communicated, the damage is unavoidable. Try to talk to a guy working on a computer? He starts flailing his arms and you lose health. See fireflies and want to investigate? They attack you and you lose health. See a guy with a box on his head pace around and try to talk to him? Somehow you lose health for that too...

The availability of healing items is limited and their usefulness is limited as they allow you to recover small amounts of health. But there's more, to save the game you also need a special item with limited availability. I'd understand being to save only in specific locations, this has been a mechanic for a very long time, but add to this the Resident Evil requirement to have a specific item to be able to save? Especially with how bad the "combat" and controls in this game are? The movement issue becomes especially glaring once you find the flashlight and it turns out it can only shine in the direction you are moving in.

As such, despite great beginning and atmosphere, I just couldn't get into it because the gameplay mechanics put me off.

63507457.review:
The biggest and only problem I have with this game is the specs needed. The graphics looks simple enough and you'd think the game would be very low-spec, but you really need some decent processor power to be able run those cutscenes. So no, you probably won't be able to run this game on a toaster, like I tried back when it came out and couldn't, with specs definitely above the minimal requirements. I think it's an optimisation issue tied to the fact the game was written in Java (or at least, I think it was written in Java) and as far as I know, the situation hasn't really changed.

Despite the above mentioned problem, it's a very good game. It's not necessarily scary per se, but it does a lot of stuff that made me very interested in it. And after the final story update (which is quite a while back), the game finally has a satisfying conclusion.

Can't wait for more Baroque Decay works.

63375882.review:
Now that I have gotten all the endings and most of the achievements, I am writing this review.
This game is incridibly stylish in both art and sound design. It's a true survival horror experience even if it's not that hard. The plot is okay, I honestly thought it a bit dull and the conclusion was very rushed from the lengthy setup. It does throw a couple red herrings your way, so don't expect to spoil yourself on it.
The gameplay is solid. Mechanics are clearly telegraphed through visuals/sounds and while the stealth is bare-bones, it is very cleverly implemented. The combat (if you can call stabbing with a pencil - combat) is a bit wonky, but once you get used to the inventory system, it's all well and good.
I have encountered rare slight sound popping with no discernible reason, but other than that he game is impeccable technically.

63089157.review: Amazing little puzzle-based survival horror game, with great mechanics that don't overstay their welcome and an ever increasing sense of tension and humor.

This game is absolutely insane. Top to bottom. Like, what did I experience!?
It's hard to put into words. But I can say that I've never played anything else like it. The gameplay is simple and accessible. But the buckwild characters, story, and... everything else, really take the game to the next level.
What really made the game memorable (other than insane visuals) is the soundtrack! Holy CRAP the soundtrack! I swear it's as iconic as something like the Hannibal TV show. 62944017.review:
A neat little game I found by complete accident.

While it has that pixel, Atari-plus art design along with some cool cutscenes, I think this game is a great testament to how effective sound design can be.

A good soundtrack and really superb sound design. Wearing headphones with this game is a must. Good use of visuals and just enough variety in the gameplay to keep you interested.

It mixes creepy, mysterious, and funny in a satisfying way.

While not too innovative, I would highly recommend this to people who are looking for something done extremely well.

62937526.review: This is a phenomenal game that is a bit under the radar. Finishing this game was one hell of a ride and a mindfuck throughout. You are left clueless, wandering about Sintracorp trying to uncover its mysteries. With many twists, great soundtrack, a solid story, humor, terror, and lovable characters, I'd recommend this to any fan of horror.

62904962.review:
Another true adventure game from Baroque Decay that, in my opinion, is the best in its genre.

It's modern, so it doesn't have frustrating puzzles like in many point-and-clicks.
The world and its characters are interesting and develop with the story.
The aesthetics are just perfect, (I love the retro 90s/GITS/psychedelic aesthetic mixed with horror and magic.)
The game uses real tension to drive the horror, not jump-scares. 

It's a real adventure.
